titlestmt.title: Illustrations to Dante's "Divine Comedy": electronic edition
titlestmt.principal:
Editors: Morris Eaves, University of
Rochester;
Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and
Joseph Viscomi , University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 65KB; 204 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 75KB to 2000KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH January 2005 ; Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries February 2015
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a fully searchable electronic edition of Blake’s water color illustrations to Dante’s Divine Comedy . The Archive first published these in January 2005 in our Preview mode. This republication substantially increases the number and range of Blake’s pictorial motifs available for searching on the Archive. The 7 engravings illustrating Dante’s poem continue to be available in the Archive in Preview mode.
Along with the illustrations to Edward Young’s Night Thoughts , the poetry of Thomas Gray, and John Milton’s poems, the 102 Dante water colors are among Blake’s most important series of illustrations of another poet. They were commissioned by John Linnell, the chief patron of Blake’s final years. Although Linnell did not begin to pay for the designs until December 1825, at the rate of about 1 pound a week, Blake probably began work on the drawings by the fall of 1824. They were left at Blake’s death in 1827 in various stages of completion, ranging from pencil sketches to highly finished water colors. Most show an expressive freedom in the handling of color washes far greater than Blake’s earlier works in that medium. In 1826, Blake began to engrave large plates based on 7 of the designs; these were also left incomplete at his death. The water colors remained in Linnell’s collection and estate until their sale at auction in 1918. Through a scheme organized by the National Art Collections Fund, they were dispersed among 7 participating institutions: Ashmolean Museum (3 designs), Birmingham Museums & Art Gallery (6 designs), British Museum (13 designs), Fogg Art Museum (23 designs) National Gallery of Victoria (36 designs), Royal Institution of Cornwall (1 design), and Tate Collection (20 designs). The Archive has brought this dispersed group of water colors together. The digital lightbox feature enables users to compare images within the series and with all other works in the Archive.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.objsize: each approximately 37.0 x 52.5 cm. (horizontal format) or 52.5 x 37.0 cm. (vertical format)
objinfo.leafsize: each approximately 37.0 x 52.5 cm. (horizontal format) or 52.5 x 37.0 cm. (vertical format)
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water colors over pencil Objects 27, 32, 71, 73, 86, and 93 are basically pencil drawings with, in some cases, pen and ink additions or very slight touches of color.
objinfo.watermark: WELGAR 1796 or a fleur-de-lis with WE Each leaf appears to be half of a sheet with the WELGAR watermark on one half and the fleur-de-lis countermark on the other half. The watermark or countermark cannot be seen on the water colors that are pasted down to a backing mat, but are very probably present.
objinfo.pennednumbers: All but objects 14, 22, 27, 44, 50, 57, 97, 98, 100, and 102 are inscribed with the number of the canto or cantos of Dante's poem illustrated by the design. Object 57 is inscribed "95." The sheets bear inscriptions on their versos, including two sets of numbers that would appear to be attempts to indicate the proper sequence of the designs. None of these verso inscriptions is by Blake.
objinfo.binding: The designs may have been bound at one time, but are now disbound and dispersed.

provenance.note: Acquired directly from Blake by John Linnell, who commissioned the designs; sold from Linnell's estate, Christie's, 15 March 1918, lot 148 (£7665 to Alec Martin acting for the National Art Collections Fund, which divided the designs by prior arrangement amongst the seven institutions now owning the Dante water colors).

desc.objtitle:
Dante Running from the Three Beasts Dante Running from the Three Beasts is Rescued by Virgil,
Object 1 (Butlin 812.1)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "4" top right, and "No 2 next at p 6" top center. The latter inscription was also partly erased from the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned male representing Dante appears in the left half of the design. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right and he likely looks toward the animals to the right. Dante's right leg is bent and his left leg is extended backward with the left foot raised on tiptoe; he strides or runs to the left, fleeing from the animals. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees and the palms of both hands are held vertically. A gowned male representing Virgil flies or hovers in the left half of the design. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer. Virgil faces forward with his head turned down slightly; he may look towards the animals pictured to the right. A female wolf with spiky fur stands on a hill in the upper right portion of the design. The wolf has six visible swollen teats. Its mouth is open with the teeth bared and tongue extended. A male lion stands in the right half of the design. Its mouth is open with the teeth visible. A leopard stands in a crouched position in the lower right portion of the design. Mottled coloring on the leopard's body suggests spots. The leopard faces left with its head turned up; its mouth is open with the tongue extended. The trunks of two leafy trees appear above a hill in the upper right portion of the design. An ivy vine climbs up the trunk of the tree on the left in this group. A third tree trunk appears at the left border and divides into several leafy branches that arch to the right. A leafy vine rises along the tree trunk and a thorny vine rests on the ground to the right. A leafy plant appears in lower right, just left of the lion. The plant arches to the left and nine flower buds or berries appear along its stem. A body of water, likely the sea, appears in the lower half of the design. Small waves are visible throughout. The disc of the sun appears on the horizon; it may be sunrise or sunset. Beams of light radiate outward through the sky and three stars appear to the left. The setting is the wilderness, or dark wood, in which Dante wanders.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned male representing Dante appears in the left half of the design. The figure has long hair. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right and he likely looks toward the animals to the right. Dante's right leg is bent and his left leg is extended backward with the left foot raised on tiptoe; he strides or runs to the left, fleeing from the animals. The figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees and the palms of both hands are held vertically. The fingers of his right hand are spread slightly.

A gowned male representing Virgil flies or hovers in the left half of the design. The figure has long, curly hair. His right foot is visible below the hem of his gown. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer. Virgil faces forward with his head turned down slightly; he may look towards the animals pictured to the right.

A female wolf with spiky fur stands on a hill in the upper right portion of the design. The wolf has six visible swollen teats. The wolf faces left in profile. Its mouth is open with the teeth bared and tongue extended.
A male lion stands in the right half of the design. The lion faces left and may look towards the figures to the left. Its mouth is open with the teeth visible.

A leopard stands in a crouched position in the lower right portion of the design. Mottled coloring on the leopard's body suggests spots. The leopard faces left with its head turned up; the animal may look towards the figures to the left. The leopard's mouth is open with the tongue extended.
Green coloring in the lower half of the design indicates grass. A grassy hill or mound rises to the right in the middle distance.

The trunks of two leafy trees appear above a hill in the upper right portion of the design. An ivy vine climbs up the trunk of the tree on the left in this group. A third tree trunk appears at the left border and divides into several leafy branches that arch to the right. A leafy vine rises along the tree trunk and a thorny vine rests on the ground to the right.
A leafy plant appears lower right, just left of the lion. The plant arches to the left and nine flower buds or berries appear along its stem.
A body of water, likely the sea, appears in the lower half of the design. Small waves are visible throughout.

The disc of the sun appears on the horizon; it may be sunrise or sunset. Beams of light radiate outward through the sky and three stars appear to the left. The setting is the wilderness, or dark wood, in which Dante wanders.

lg.l: Lago Lines 1-2 are faintly written in the sea between the lower leg of the hovering figure and the lower torso of the figure striding on the ground.

l.note: Line 3 is written on a diagonal descending from left to right on the ground below and to the right of the right foot of the striding figure.

desc.objtitle:
The Mission of Virgil,
Object 2 (Butlin 812.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: God sits or crouches in the upper half of the design. His right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. God's left leg is bestial and ends in a cloven hoof. Both arms are raised horizontally and God holds a snake-like spiral (of smoke?) in each hand. A gowned male with short hair and a spiked crown kneels on a step in the upper portion of the design. The figure is seen from behind with his head turned to the right in profile. His right eye is raised and he looks up at God. A large Maltese cross with a fleur-de-lis finial and smaller crosses and rectangular and fleur-de-lis motifs appear on the figure's gown. Some of the rectangular shapes may be buildings with central towers. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet are turned out towards the viewer. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees; the forefinger of his left hand is extended and he may point downward. In his right hand he holds a censer suspended by four chains; smoke rises from the censer. Arched bands of color in the upper portion of the design suggests a rainbow; the heads and shoulders of several figures are lightly sketched within the rainbow. A gowned female with long hair sits at a spinning wheel in the upper left portion of the design within a cave-like bower. A distaff wound with a skein of thread rises from the spinning wheel. A rectangular mirror appears above; the reflection of the woman's hair is visible on its surface. Three leafy trees, possibly with a grape vine, arch above. A gowned male representing Dante stands in the lower portion of the design. He is seen from behind with his head turned down and to the left. Dante's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or surprise. His legs are spread apart and at least his right leg is bent. His left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may stride away from the viewer. Dante's arms are raised at 45 degrees and the palms of both hands are turned down. A gowned male representing Virgil stands on a hill or mound in the lower left portion of the design. His eyes are cast down and he looks towards Dante. Virgil's right arm is down at his side and his left arm is bent upward; the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread slightly. The heads of three beasts appear in the lower portion of the design, to the left of Dante. From top to bottom they may represent a tiger, wolf, and dog. All three animals face right and look towards Dante. The wolf's mouth is open with the teeth visible. Green coloring in the lower half of the design indicates grass. Branches and leaves visible above the heads of three animals suggests trees. Additional leaves appear on the ground below. A giant nude male sits or crouches in the lower left portion of the design. The figure faces forward and his body is surrounded by blue flames. His arms are bent and the figure's hands rest together on his knees with the palms turned down. A giant nude male with short, curly hair sits or crouches in the lower right portion of the design. The figure faces forward and his body is surrounded by flames and smoke; dark shapes on the figure's body may indicate ash. His arms are down at his sides and his hands rest on the ground. Shackles appear on the figure's wrists; a single chain link is visible at the right wrist. A dark cloud or perhaps smoke arches above the figures in the lower half of the design. Rose, yellow, and blue wash below the cloud belt may indicate a sky at sunrise or sunset. Three female spirits fly or hover among the clouds. The figure furthest left is positioned horizontally. Her left arm extends horizontally to the right; the palm of her left hand is turned up and she may reach towards the figure to the right. The figure second from the left is seen from behind and is partly upside down with her legs extended upward. She faces left with her head turned up and her eyes raised; she looks towards the figures above. Her mouth may be open slightly. The figure furthest right faces forward with her head turned to the left. The figure's left leg is bent and her ankles are crossed with the right foot prominent. Her arms are bent and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread. The setting may be the entry into hell.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned male with long hair and a beard sits or crouches in the upper half of the design; he represents God. The figure's right leg is bent and drawn up and his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. His left leg is bestial and ends in a cloven hoof. Both arms are raised horizontally and God holds a snake-like spiral (of smoke?) in each hand.

A gowned male with short hair and a spiked crown kneels on a step in the upper portion of the design. The figure is seen from behind with his head turned to the right in profile. His right eye is raised and he looks up at God. A large Maltese cross with a fleur-de-lis finial and smaller crosses and rectangular and fleur-de-lis motifs appear on the figure's gown. Some of the rectangular forms may be buildings with towers. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet are turned out towards the viewer. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees. The forefinger of his left hand is extended and he may point downward. In his right hand he holds a censer suspended by four chains; smoke rises from the censer.
Four steps or stairs are visible in the upper portion of the design.
Arched bands of color in the upper portion of the design suggests a rainbow.
The heads and shoulders of several figures are lightly sketched within the rainbow to the left and right of God.

A gowned female with long hair sits at a spinning wheel in the upper left portion of the design. Both legs are bent. Both arms are bent upward. Her right hand is not clearly visible, and the palm of her left hand is turned out towards the viewer.

A spinning wheel appears in the upper left portion of the design. A distaff wound with a skein of thread rises from the spinning wheel. A rectangular mirror appears above; the reflection of a woman's hair is visible on its surface.

Three leafy trees appear in the upper left portion of the design. Their branches arch above the female figure seated at a spinning wheel to form a cave-like bower. A grape(?) vine coils around the leftmost trunk and extends to the tree to the right; the vine forms four loops.

A gowned male representing Dante stands in the lower portion of the design. The figure has long hair. He is seen from behind with his head turned down and to the left; he may look at the animals pictured to the left. Dante's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or surprise. His legs are spread apart and at least his right leg is bent. His left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may stride away from the viewer. Dante's arms are raised at 45 degrees and the palms of both hands are turned down.

A gowned male with long hair stands on a hill or mound in the lower left portion of the design. He likely represents Virgil. His eyes are cast down and he looks towards the figure below. Virgil's right arm is down at his side and his left arm is bent upward; the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread slightly.

The heads of three beasts appear in the lower portion of the design, to the left of Dante. From top to bottom, they may represent a tiger, wolf, and dog. All three animals face right and look towards Dante. The wolf's mouth is open with the teeth visible.
Green coloring in the lower half of the design indicates grass. Branches and leaves visible above the heads of three animals suggests trees. Additional leaves appear on the ground below.
Virgil stands on a grassy hill or mound topped by a stone platform or step.

A giant nude male sits or crouches in the lower left portion of the design. The figure faces forward and his body is surrounded by blue flames. He is apparently bald with traces of long hair above his shoulders. The figure's eyes are raised and his mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible. Both legs are bent and drawn up. His arms are bent and the figure's hands rest together on his knees with the palms turned down.

A giant nude male with short, curly hair sits or crouches in the lower right portion of the design. The figure faces forward and his body is surrounded by flames and smoke; dark amorphous shapes on the figure's body may indicate ash. The figure's eyes are raised and he may look towards the figures above. His mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible and his expression suggests melancholy. Both legs are bent and drawn up. His arms are down at his sides and his hands rest on the ground. Shackles appear on the figure's wrists; a single chain link is visible at the right wrist.

A gowned female spirit with long hair flies or hovers among clouds in the lower left portion of the design. She faces forward with her body positioned horizontally. The figure's right arm is bent slightly at her side. Her left arm extends horizontally to the right; the palm of her left hand is turned up and she may reach towards the figure to the right.

A gowned female(?) spirit flies or hovers among clouds in the lower half of the design. Her hair is short or perhaps drawn back in a bun. The figure is seen from behind and is partly upside down with her legs extended upward. She faces left with her head turned up and her eyes raised; she looks towards the figures above. Her mouth may be open slightly. The figure's left arm is bent upward and her left hand is not clearly pictured. Her right arm is raised vertically; the palm of her right hand may be turned up, although the thumb appears to be on the incorrect side.

A gowned female spirit with long hair flies or hovers among clouds in the lower right portion of the design. She faces forward with her head turned to the left. The figure's left leg is bent and her ankles are crossed with the right foot prominent. Her arms are bent and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread.

A dark cloud or perhaps smoke arches above the figures in the lower half of the design. Rose, yellow, and blue wash and a few beams of light below the cloud belt may indicate a sky at sunrise or sunset.
The setting may be the entry into hell.

lg.l:
The Angry God of this
World &
Paradise "World" is written over another, illegible inscription that ends with the word "Paradise."

l.note: The line is written diagonally, rising from left to right, just to the left of the top figure's right hand.
Lines 4-5 are written diagonally, descending from left to right, on each side of the spiral descending from the left hand of the top figure.

desc.objtitle:
Dante and Virgil Penetrating the Forest Dante and Virgil Enter the Wood,
Object 3 (Butlin 812.2)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "92" top right, "N 37 next at p. 71" top center, and "Hell Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower half of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the left, likely Virgil, stands with his arms bent upward; the palms of both hands are turned out with the fingers spread. His legs are bent slightly and he may walk away from the viewer. His head is turned to the right and he looks toward Dante. Dante stands with his right leg bent and the right foot raised on tiptoe; he may walk away from the viewer. The figure's arms are down at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down. His head is turned to the left and he looks toward Virgil. The figures stand in a forest; the trunks of two trees rise to the left and two more to the right. Each trunk divides into several leafy branches. Dark wash between the trees suggests shadows. Green coloring at the lower border indicates grass. The setting is Dante's dark wood or wilderness.

component.illusobjdesc: Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower half of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the left, likely Virgil, stands with his arms bent upward; the palms of both hands are turned out with the fingers spread. His legs are bent slightly and he may walk away from the viewer. His head is turned to the right and he looks toward Dante.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower half of the design. Both figures and are seen from behind. The figure to the right, likely Dante, stands with his right leg bent and the right foot raised on tiptoe; he may walk away from the viewer. The figure's arms are down at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down. His head is turned to the left and he looks toward Virgil.

The figures stand in a forest; the trunks of two trees rise to the left and two more to the right. Each trunk divides into several leafy branches. Dark wash between the trees suggests shadows. Green coloring at the lower border indicates grass. The setting is Dante's dark wood or wilderness.

desc.objtitle:
The Inscription over Hell-Gate,
Object 4 (Butlin 812.4)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "3" top right, and "No 1 next at p 4" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower portion of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the left, likely Dante, stands with his right leg bent and his right foot raised on tiptoe; he likely walks away from the viewer. Dante's head is turned up and to the left in profile; he may look towards the archway above. The figure's left arm is raised vertically and the palm of his left hand is turned up. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm of his right hand turned down. The figure to the right, likely Virgil, stands with his left leg bent and his left foot raised above the ground; he likely walks away from the viewer. Virgil's head is turned to the left and he looks over his left shoulder towards Dante. Virgil's right arm is raised at 135 degrees and the palm of his right hand is turned out, away from the viewer. His left arm is down and he might hold Dante's right wrist. Dante and Virgil stand at the threshold of hell, marked by a large archway. The arch is slightly misshapen and may be a natural stone formation. The lower left portion of the threshold is cast in shadow. The trunks of two leafy trees with large visible roots stand to the left and right of the archway. Branches are visible among the leaves of each tree. Green coloring below indicates grass. The distant area visible within the archway represents hell. A body of water, possibly the river Acheron, extends horizontally across the lower portion of the design. Four dark or shadowed hills, probably representing the circles of hell, rise above the river. Flames appear throughout. Several indistinct figures, perhaps six in total, appear among the distant hills in the center of the design. One figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees.

component.illusobjdesc: Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower portion of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the left, likely Dante, stands with his right leg bent and his right foot raised on tiptoe; he likely walks away from the viewer. Dante's head is turned up and to the left in profile; he may look towards the archway above. The figure's left arm is raised vertically and the palm of his left hand is turned up. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm of his right hand turned down.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower portion of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the right, likely Virgil, stands with his left leg bent and his left foot raised above the ground; he likely walks away from the viewer. Virgil's head is turned to the left and he looks over his left shoulder towards Dante. Virgil's right arm is raised at 135 degrees and the palm of his right hand is turned out, away from the viewer. His left arm is down and he might hold Dante's right wrist.

Dante and Virgil stand at the threshold of hell, marked by a large archway. The arch is slightly misshapen and may be a natural stone formation. The lower left portion of the threshold is cast in shadow.
The trunks of two leafy trees with large visible roots stand to the left and right of the archway. Branches are visible among the leaves of each tree. Green coloring below indicates grass.

The distant area visible within the archway represents hell. A body of water, possibly the river Acheron, extends horizontally across the lower portion of the design. Four dark or shadowed hills, representing the circles of hell, rise above the river. Flames appear throughout.
Several indistinct figures, perhaps six in total, appear among the distant hills in the center of the design. One figure's arms are raised at 135 degrees.

lg.l: Lasciate orni speranza voi che in entrate The final two words in line 1 are almost illegible; our reading is conjectural. The final two words in Dante's text are "che entrate."
Leave every Hope you who in Enter

desc.objtitle:
The Vestibule of Hell and the Souls Mustering to Cross the Acheron,
Object 5 (Butlin 812.5)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "7" top right, and "No 30 next at p 64" top center, with the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Dante and Virgil stand on a small hill or step in the lower right corner of the design. The step is cast in dark shadow and spiky shape near the base of the step may represent a leaf or other indeterminate vegetation. Dante faces forward with his head turned to the left and his mouth may be open slightly. Dante's right arm is bent; his left arm is not visible, but is also likely bent. The palms of both hands are held vertically. Virgil stands to the right of Dante; he faces forward with his head turned to the right in profile. As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A male wearing tights or breeches and a shirt stands furthest left. The figure is seen from behind with his head turned up and to the right. His legs are spread apart and his right foot is raised on tiptoe. Two worms wrap around his calves. A sword hangs in a scabbard at his left hip; the scabbard is likely attached to a belt. The figure holds a flagpole with both hands; the flag is triangular, but with two decorative loops, and points to the right. A female with short, curly hair stands second from the left. Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible; the figure's expression may suggest despair. She wears a shirt or gown with lacing visible below her breasts. Her garment is torn at her left hip and two daggers or knives appear at her left side. Red coloring along her torso and legs suggests blood. The figure wears a spiked crown, a beaded or pearl necklace with a cross, and two bracelets. A worm wraps around her right ankle and another may appear at her left knee. Both arms are raised vertically and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer. The figures third through sixth from the left in this group all face left, with heads lowered. Three have their hands covering their faces. The figure seventh from the left wears a torn shirt or tunic. His left arm is bent upward and his left hand covers his face. A bag, purse, or other object hangs from the figure's belt. Two pistols are strapped above his belt. A small object, possibly another gun, is belted around his left calf and a worm rises above his left ankle. A gowned female with long hair stands tenth from the left. The figure wears a crown. A stoppered vial hangs from a string or thread near her left hip. Only the upper bodies of the five figures furthest right are visible. At least seven worms appear on the ground and perhaps eight additional worms wrap around the legs of several figures. A multitude of wasps or hornets flies above. A series stairs or steps appears in the central right portion of the design. A large stone, perhaps a cliffside, rises above. The stone resembles a head turned to the left in profile with its mouth open. Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent the heads of additional figures. The figure furthest left is nude and faces left in profile; his head is turned down and his left hand covers his face. The figure third from the left faces forward with his or her head turned up and mouth open. The figure fourth from the left is seen from behind with his(?) arms down at his sides and the palms of his hands turned down. The figure fifth from the left may hold his or her hands together in prayer. A nude male with long hair and a beard stands sixth from the left; his legs are bent and he may walk to the left. The figures seventh and eighth from the left likely descend the staircase. A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands ninth from the left, elevated slightly above the group; his arms are bent upward with the palms held vertically. The figure tenth from the left crouches slightly and the figure furthest right is seen from behind. Three nude(?) figures appear on the cliff face above. The upper figure straddles the stone with his or her right leg dangling downward. Both arms are bent upward. The figure second from the top stands(?) with his or her left arm raised vertically. The lowest figure of the group is upside down and may be falling; his or her head is not visible and the figure's legs may be bent. Dark water in the center of the design represents the river Acheron. Charon sits in a sail boat near the leftmost shore of the river. The figure's right arm is bent and he holds an oar in his right hand; he is likely rowing the boat across the river. A stone or brick wall rises in several tiers above the left shore of the river. Above the wall are two(?) roofed buildings; above them is another structure or a flat-topped hill. Two figures, probably devils, stand above the wall in the upper left portion of the design. Both figures are cast in dark shadow and they may be winged. The figure to the right stands with his or her left leg bent and the left foot raised on tiptoe; the figure may walk to the left. At least one arm is bent upward and the figure may hold a staff or other object. A multitude of gowned figures stand left of the wall. They face left and many figures have at least one leg bent; they likely walk to the left. The figures along the left border are distinguished only by their heads and they may be seen from behind. Blue wash in the upper portion of the design indicates sky. Red coloring in the upper left may suggest a fire. Smoke or perhaps a cloud extends along the upper border; at least fourteen gowned figures appear within the cloud. Many of the figures are indistinct. A female stands second from the left with her arms bent upward and her hands held beside her head. A male third from the left is seen from behind and may embrace the figure to the right. An old male with long hair and a beard stands sixth from the left; both arms are bent upward and the palms of his hands are turned up. A female eighth from the left bends forward slightly with her head turned down; she may run or walk to the right. The setting is the entry into hell.

component.illusobjdesc: Two gowned males with long hair stand on a small hill or step in the lower right corner of the design. The figure to the left likely represents Dante. He faces forward with his head turned to the left. His mouth may be open slightly. Dante's right arm is bent; his left arm is not visible, but is also likely bent. The palms of both hands are held vertically.

Two gowned males with long hair stand on a small hill or step in the lower right corner of the design. The figure to the right likely represents Virgil. He faces forward with his head turned to the right in profile.

Dante and Virgil stand on a small hill, mound, or step in the lower right corner of the design. The step is cast in dark shadow. A spiky shape near the base of the step may represent a leaf or other indeterminate vegetation.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A male with short hair stands furthest left. He wears a shirt and tights or breeches. The figure is seen from behind with his head turned up and to the right. His legs are spread apart and his right foot is raised on tiptoe. Two worms encircle the figure's calves. A sword appears in a scabbard at his left hip; the scabbard is likely attached to a belt. The figure's left arm is bent and his right arm is bent upward above his head; he holds a flagpole with both hands. The flag is triangular, but with two decorative loops, and points to the right.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A female with short, curly hair stands second from the left. The figure faces forward with her head turned up slightly. Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible; the figure's expression may suggest despair. She wears a shirt or gown with lacing visible below her breasts. Her garment is torn at her left hip and two daggers or knives appear at her left side. Red coloring along her torso and legs suggests blood. The figure wears a spiked crown and a beaded or pearl necklace with a cross. She wears a bracelet on her left wrist and a beaded bracelet on her upper right arm. The figure's legs are bent slightly and her left foot is raised on tiptoe. A worm wraps around her right ankle and another may appear at her left knee. Both arms are raised vertically and her left arm is bent slightly. The palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A gowned figure with long hair stands third from the left; only his or her upper body is clearly visible. The figure faces left with his or her head turned down. The left arm is bent upward and the figure clutches his or her head with the left hand. The figure's posture suggests despair.
As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The head of a figure with short hair appears fourth from the left; he or she is obscured by another figure below.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A gowned figure with long hair crouches fifth from the left. The figure faces left in profile. His or her left leg is bent with the left foot visible. A worm appears on the figure's left ankle. The figure's head is down and his or her shoulders are hunched slightly. The figure's left arm is bent upward with the left hand covering his or her face.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A gowned figure with long hair stands sixth from the left; his or her gown is torn. The figure faces left with his or her head down. Both arms are bent upward and the figure's left hand covers his or her face. The right leg is bent with the right foot raised on tiptoe. A worm is wrapped around the figure's left foot and ankle.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A male(?) with long hair stands seventh from the left; he wears a torn shirt or tunic. The figure faces left with his head turned down. His left arm is bent upward and his left hand covers his face. A bag, purse, or other object hangs from the figure's belt. Two pistols are strapped above his belt. A small object, possibly another gun, is belted around his left calf and a worm rises above his left ankle.
As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. Drapery visible to the either side of the figure seventh from the left likely represents the gown of an obscured figure.
As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The head of a male with long hair and a beard is visible ninth from the left, between the legs of the other figures.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A gowned female with long hair stands tenth from the left. The figure wears a crown. A stoppered vial hangs from a string or thread near her left hip. The figure stands with her left leg bent slightly and her left foot raised on tiptoe. A worm rises along her right ankle. She faces left with her head tilted down and to the right and her mouth may be open. The figure's left arm is bent upward and her left hand clutches at her hair. Her right arm is raised vertically and the palm of her right hand is turned up.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The head of a male with long hair and a beard is visible eleventh from the left. The figure faces right and his mouth may be open.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A partly nude figure with long hair stands twelfth from the left. The figure is seen from behind and bends slightly right. He or she wears a skirt. Both arms are bent upward with the palms held together vertically in prayer or supplication.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The upper body of a gowned male(?) appears thirteenth from the left. The figure faces left with his head turned up slightly and his mouth open.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. A gowned male with long hair and a beard is appears fourteenth from the left; only his upper body is visible. The figure's right arm is raised and the palm of his right hand is turned up.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The upper body of a gowned female appears fifteenth from the left. Her short hair stands on end. The figure faces forward with her head turned up slightly. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised; her expression suggests fear. Both arms are bent upward above her head. The figure's hands are indistinct, but are likely held together in prayer.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. Two disembodied arms are raised above the figures in the lower right portion of the design. One of the arms shows traces of a sleeve, perhaps of a gown. The fingers of both hands are spread and the palms are turned up slightly.

As many as seventeen figures appear across the lower portion of the design. The head of an indistinct figure with long hair appears furthest right. The figure's head is turned up and to the left. His or her right arm is raised vertically with the palm apparently turned out towards the viewer.
At least seven worms appear on the ground in the lower portion of the design; perhaps eight additional worms wrap around the legs of several figures.
A multitude of wasps or hornets flies above the seventeen figures in the lower portion of the design.

A series stairs or steps appears in the central right portion of the design. A large stone, perhaps a cliffside, rises above. The stone resembles a head turned to the left in profile with its mouth open.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A nude male with long hair and a beard stands furthest left. The figure faces left with his head turned down. His left arm is bent upward and his left hand covers his face. The figure's right leg is bent with the left foot raised on tiptoe.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. The figure second from the left is gowned and his or her head is turned down. The figure is largely obscured by the male to the left.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A nude(?) figure stands third from the left with his or her head turned up. The figure's mouth is open.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned figure with long hair stands fourth from the left. He or she is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer. The figure's right leg is bent slightly with the right foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are down at the figure's sides with the palms of both hands turned down.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned figure stands fifth from the left. The figure faces forward with his or her head turned up and to the right. The figure's mouth is open. Both arms are likely bent and the figure's hands are held together in front of his or her chest as if in prayer.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A male with long hair and a beard stands sixth from the left. He may wear a gown or long shirt. Both legs are bent and his right foot is raised on tiptoe; the figure may stride or walk to the left. The figure's arms are bent with the hands held together near or perhaps on his face.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned male with short hair stands seventh from the left. His right leg is bent back and the left foot is likely raised on tiptoe; he may descend the staircase. The figure's arms are bent and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned female stands eighth from the left. The figure faces forward with her head turned to the left in profile. Her hair is drawn back in a bun and her mouth is open slightly. Her feet rest on different steps and the left foot may be raised on tiptoe; she likely descends the staircase. The figure's arms are bent and cross in front of her chest. The palm of her left hand may be held vertically.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands ninth from the left. He faces forward with his head turned slightly right and his mouth open. The figure's left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may descend the staircase. Both arms are bent upward and the palms of his hands are held vertically.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned male(?) with long hair stands tenth from the left. Both legs are bent and he crouches slightly. The figure's left foot is raised on tiptoe. His left arm is bent and his hands may be held together as if in prayer.

Eleven distinct figures stand on the stairs in the central right portion of the design; other indistinct shapes likely represent additional figures. A gowned figure with long hair stands furthest right. The figure is seen from behind and his or her head is turned to the left. The figure's right leg is bent slightly with the right foot raised on tiptoe.

Three nude(?) figures appear on a cliff face in the upper right portion of the design. The upper figure straddles the stone with his or her right leg dangling downward. Both arms are bent upward. The figure second from the top stands(?) with his or her left arm raised vertically. The lowest figure of the group is upside down and may be falling; his or her head is not visible and the figure's legs may be bent.
Dark water in the center of the design represents the river Acheron. Waves are visible throughout.
A boat with a small sail appears on the river in the left portion of the design.

A gowned male with long hair and a beard sits in a boat in the lower left portion of the design. He likely represents Charon. The figure's right arm is bent and he holds an oar in his right hand; he is likely rowing the boat across the river.

A stone or brick wall rises in several tiers above the left shore of the river. Above the wall and the line of figures are two(?) roofed buildings. Above them is another structure or a flat-topped hill.

Two figures, possibly devils, stand above the wall in the upper left portion of the design. Both figures are cast in dark shadow and they may be winged. The figure to the right stands with his or her left leg bent and the left foot raised on tiptoe; the figure may walk to the left. At least one arm is bent upward and the figure may hold a staff or other object.

A multitude of gowned figures stand on the leftmost shore of the Acheron, just left of the wall. They face left and many figures have at least one leg bent; they likely walk to the left. The figures along the left border are distinguished only by their heads and they may be seen from behind.

Blue wash in the upper portion of the design indicates sky. Red coloring in the upper left may suggest a fire. Smoke or perhaps a cloud extends along the upper border. The setting is the entry into hell.

At least fourteen gowned figures appear within a cloud at the upper border of the design. Many of the figures are indistinct. A female stands second from the left with her arms bent upward and her hands held besdie her head. A male third from the left is seen from behind and may embrace the figure to the right. An old male with long hair and a beard stands sixth from the left; both arms are bent upward and the palms of his hands are turned up. A female eighth from the left bends forward slightly with her head turned down; she may run or walk to the right.

desc.objtitle:
Charon and the Condemned Souls,
Object 6 (Butlin 812.6)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "50" over chalk, top right, and "Pg Canto 5 & 6" along the right margin, crossed through. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Grey wash in the lower portion of the design represents the river Acheron. A boat appears on the river in the center of the design. A sail and a rope wrap around the mast and the boat is moored with a heavy rope to a large ring on a pier or other structure to the right. A male figure representing Charon stands on the gunwale of the boat. The figure has long hair and a beard. His mouth is open and he may be speaking or shouting. Charon wears a skirt and an open shirt or coat. Both legs are bent and spread apart; his left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may walk or stride to the right. His arms are raised vertically and he holds an oar in his left hand. The palm of his right hand is held vertically with the fingers spread slightly. The heads and upper bodies of at least fourteen figures are visible in the left half of Charon's boat. Many of the figures are lightly sketched and have no discernible features. A nude male in the upper left braces against the gunwale with his right arm bent. His head is turned up and to the right with his mouth open; his expression suggests fear or despair. Below and to the right, a nude female(?) sits or reclines with both legs bent and drawn up. Two gowned figures stand on a hill in the upper right portion of the design; they likely represent Dante and Virgil. The figure to the left has long hair. He faces forward and his right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm of his right hand turned down. The figure to the right faces left and his left arm may be bent. At least eight gowned figures stand above the pier in the upper right portion of the design. The figures are lightly sketched. The three figures furthest left are hunched over. The figure third from the left has the left arm bent and wrapped around his or her head. A male with long hair and a beard stands fourth from the left. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and the palms of both hands may be turned up. A figure huddles fifth from the left with both arms raised beside his or her face. The figure sixth from the left may have a mustache or beard; both arms are bent upward with the palms turned up. A female with flame-like hair stands seventh from the left; both arms are bent upward. The features of the figure furthest right are not clearly visible. A mountain rises above the river in the left portion of the design. Though not clearly pictured, a wall may appear below the mountain in the lower left portion of the design. The roof of a building appears above the wall; another building appears further up the mountain. Two indistinct figures, perhaps devils, sit on a mountain in the upper left portion of the design. The figures may be winged or are perhaps surrounded by flames. A shepherd's crook appears to the right of each figure; though not clearly pictured, the figures may hold the shepherd's crooks. The figure to the left sits with his or her left leg dangling over the mountain's edge. A group of indistinct figures appears along the left border of the design; they may be seen from behind and climb or ascend the wall and mountainside. Only the heads of several figures are visible. The lower figure stands with his or her right leg bent and left arm raised vertically. Blue wash in the upper right portion of the design indicates sky; white space to the left suggests clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell.

A male figure representing Charon stands on the gunwale of boat in the center of the design. The figure has long hair and a beard. His mouth is open and he may be speaking or shouting. Charon wears a skirt and an open shirt or coat. Both legs are bent and spread apart; his left foot is raised on tiptoe and he may walk or stride to the right. His arms are raised vertically and he holds an oar in his left hand. The blade of the oar includes horn- or spiral-like edges. The palm of his right hand is held vertically with the fingers spread slightly.
A boat appears on the river in the center of the design. A sail and a rope wrap around the mast and the boat is moored with a heavy rope to a large ring on a pier or other structure to the right.
Grey wash in the lower portion of the design represents the river Acheron.

The heads and upper bodies of at least fourteen figures are visible in the left half of Charon's boat. Many of the figures are lightly sketched and have no discernible features. A nude male in the upper left braces against the gunwale with his right arm bent. His head is turned up and to the right with his mouth open; his expression suggests fear or despair. Below and to the right, a nude female(?) sits or reclines with both legs bent and drawn up.

Two gowned figures stand on a hill in the upper right portion of the design; they likely represent Dante and Virgil. The figure to the left has long hair. He faces forward and his right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm of his right hand turned down. The figure to the right faces left and his left arm may be bent.
A hill rises above the pier in the right portion of the design.

At least eight gowned figures stand above the pier in the upper right portion of the design. The figures are lightly sketched. The three figures furthest left are hunched over. The figure third from the left has the left arm bent and wrapped around his or her head. A male with long hair and a beard stands fourth from the left. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and the palms of both hands may be turned up. A figure huddles fifth from the left with both arms raised beside his or her face. The figure sixth from the left may have a mustache or beard; both arms are bent upward with the palms turned up. A female with flame-like hair stands seventh from the left; both arms are bent upward. The features of the figure furthest right are not clearly visible.
A mountain rises above the river in the left portion of the design.

Though not clearly pictured, a wall may appear below the mountain in the lower left portion of the design. The roof of a building appears above the wall with another building further up the mountain. Fire rises above the top of the mountain.

Two indistinct figures, perhaps devils, sit on a mountain in the upper left portion of the design. The figures may be winged or are perhaps surrounded by flames. A shepherd's crook appears to the right of each figure; though not clearly pictured, the figures may hold the shepherd's crooks. The figure to the left sits with his or her left leg dangling over the mountain's edge.

A group of indistinct figures appears along the left border of the design; they may be seen from behind and climb or ascend the wall and mountainside. Only the heads of several figures are visible. The lower figure stands with his or her right leg bent and left arm raised vertically.
Blue wash in the upper right portion of the design indicates sky; white space to the left suggests clouds.

desc.objtitle:
Homer Bearing the Sword and His Companions,
Object 7 (Butlin 812.7)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "16" top right, and "N50 next at p 20" top center, with the latter partly erased from the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A series of four(?) arches appear in the center of the design; the may represent the circles of hell. A rocky cliff face rises along the left border. Light shadows appear along the cliff. A gowned figure representing Dante lies or reclines on the upper portion of the cliff. His eyes are closed and he may be sleeping. Both legs are bent and Dante's right foot is prominent. His arms are not clearly pictured. Virgil kneels or crouches above. His head is turned down and he likely looks at Dante below. Both arms are down and he may reach for or touch Dante with his left hand. A gowned male representing Homer stands in the lower portion of the design. The figure has a long beard and wears a crown or wreath of laurel leaves. He faces forward with his head turned slightly left and looks at the figure to the left. Both feet are visible and Homer's right foot is raised on tiptoe; he likely walks forward towards the viewer. His right arm is down at his side and he holds a sword in his right hand. Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. The figure furthest left is gowned and has short hair. The figure is seen from behind and leans sharply to the right with his or her head turned up. The figure's right foot may be raised on tiptoe. His or her right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm held vertically towards Homer. A gowned male with short hair and a beard appears second from the left; he may be standing, flying, or hovering. The figure's head is turned up slightly. His right arm is down at his side and his left arm may be bent. He may hold the curved object, perhaps a lyre, pictured at his left side. A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands third from the left. He wears a crown or wreath of laurel leaves. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right in profile. The figure's mouth may be open and his right eye is raised; he looks towards Homer to the right. The figure stands with his right leg bent and his right foot raised on tiptoe. His left arm is bent upward and the palm of his left hand is turned down slightly. His right arm is bent and he may reach for or touch Homer's sword. The figure third from the right is gowned and has long, curly hair. The figure is seen from behind with his or her head turned up and to the left. The figure may be standing, flying, or hovering. His or her right arm is raised at 45 degrees. A gowned figure flies or hovers second from the right. He or she may be blindfolded. The figure's right arm is down and he or she holds an open book. A gowned figure flies or hovers furthest right. The figure's features are indistinct, but he or she appears to face left. The figure's left arm is raised at 45 degrees. His or her right arm may be bent upward, or is perhaps raised horizontally. Several lightly sketched figures, perhaps seven or eight in total, fly or hover within the outer arch on the left. The lowest figure raises a single arm vertically. Above, a figure appears with both arms raised horizontally. The figure third from the bottom may cradle a smaller figure, perhaps a child or infant. Three or four figures above are indistinct. A circle upper right with lines of radiance may represent the sun, although it is inscribed "Purgatory." The two outermost arches bear inscriptions, as does the space above them (see the Textual Transcription).

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A series of four(?) arches appear in the center of the design; they may represent the circles of hell. A rocky cliff face rises along the left border. Light shadows appear along the cliff.

A gowned figure representing Dante lies or reclines on a rocky cliff in the upper left portion of the design. His eyes are closed and he may be sleeping. Both legs are bent and Dante's right foot is prominent. His arms are not clearly pictured.

A gowned figure representing Virgil kneels or crouches on a rocky cliff in the upper left portion of the design. His head is turned down and he likely looks at Dante below. Both arms are down and he may reach for or touch Dante with his left hand.

A gowned male representing Homer stands in the lower portion of the design. The figure has a long beard and wears a crown or wreath of laurel leaves. He faces forward with his head turned slightly left and looks at the figure to the left. Both feet are visible and Homer's right foot is raised on tiptoe; he likely walks forward towards the viewer. His right arm is down at his side and he holds a sword in his right hand.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. The figure furthest left is gowned and has short hair. The figure is seen from behind and leans sharply to the right with his or her head turned up. The figure's right foot may be raised on tiptoe. His or her right arm is raised at 45 degrees with the palm held vertically towards Homer.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. A gowned male with short hair and a beard appears second from the left; he may be standing, flying, or hovering. The figure's head is turned up slightly. His right arm is down at his side and his left arm may be bent. He may hold the curved object, perhaps a lyre, pictured at his left side.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands third from the left. He wears a crown or wreath of laurel leaves. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right in profile. The figure's mouth may be open and his right eye is raised; he looks towards Homer to the right. The figure stands with his right leg bent and his right foot raised on tiptoe. His left arm is bent upward and the palm of his left hand is turned down slightly. His right arm is bent and he may reach for or touch Homer's sword.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. The figure third from the right is gowned and has long, curly hair. The figure is seen from behind with his or her head turned up and to the left. The figure may be standing, flying, or hovering. His or her right arm is raised at 45 degrees.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. A gowned figure flies or hovers second from the right. He or she may be blindfolded. The figure's right arm is down and he or she holds an open book.

Six lightly sketched figures appear in the lower portion of the design, three to either side of Homer. A gowned figure flies or hovers furthest right. The figure's features are indistinct, but he or she appears to face left. The figure's left arm is raised at 45 degrees. His or her right arm may be bent upward, or is perhaps raised horizontally.

Several lightly sketched figures, perhaps seven or eight in total, fly or hover within the outer arch. The lowest figure raises a single arm vertically. Above, a figure appears with both arms raised horizontally. The figure third from the bottom may cradle a smaller figure, perhaps a child or infant. Three or four figures above are indistinct.
A circle upper right with beams of radiance may be the sun, although it is inscribed "Purgatory."
The two outermost arches bear inscriptions, as does the space above them. See the Textual Transcription.

l.note: Each of these words is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, below the top margin of the design.

lg.l: Terrestrial Lines 3-4 are written above a circle (the sun?), line 5 within the circle, and line 6 below the circle. They evidently form a syntactic cluster.
It is an Island in Limbo
Every thing in Dantes Comedia shews That for Tyrannical Lines 8-11 are written upper center within the second circle.
Purposes he has made This World the Foundation
of All & the Goddess Nature Memory & not Imagination the Holy Ghost Two carets below the line indicate the insertion of "Memory" and "Imagination."

is his Inspirer These words may be intended to be an insert after "Memory" (line 10), itself an insert. If so, then line 10 would read, with all three inserts, "of All & the Goddess Nature Memory is his Inspirer not Imagination the Holy Ghost."
as Poor Churchill Lines 12-14 would appear to be an extension of the comments in lines 8-11.
round Purgatory is Paradise Lines 15-29 descend through the right side of the second circle.
Moon Lines 30-38 are written as a vertical list near the right margin of the design.

l.hi: Swedenborg does the same in saying that in this World is the Ultimate of Heaven
l.note: Lines 39-40 are inscribed in an arc descending through the third circle toward the right.

l.hi: This is the most damnable Falsehood of Satan and his Anti-christ

lg.l: Homer This inscription appears in the fifth circle, immediately above the head of the large figure lower center.

l.note: These numbers for the circles of hell begin on the rock, center left, and extend toward a point above the raised left hand of the figure immediately to the left of the large central figure. Each inscription is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, in conformity with the arc of the circles.

lg.l:
Satan
This inscription appears in the seventh circle, just left of the face of the large figure lower center.

l.note: These numbers for the circles of hell are inscribed above the head of the figure immediately to the left of the large central figure. Each number is written on its own diagonal, rising from left to right, in conformity with the arc of the circles.

desc.objtitle:
Homer and the Ancient Poets,
Object 8 (Butlin 812.8)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "14" top right, "N 13 next at p 78" top center, and "N13 next a p 78" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. The ground at the lower border of the design is covered with grass and a few scattered leaves. A thick forest of leafy trees appears across the lower half of the design and rises along the cliff to the right. The roots of a tree in the lower right are prominent and the branches of several trees are also visible. Dark wash throughout the design indicates sky; a thick band of clouds or perhaps smoke extends horizontally across the upper portion of the image. A rocky cliff rises in the right half of the design. Two gowned males with long hair stand at the edge of the cliff. The figure to the left represents Dante. He faces left with his head turned down slightly; he likely looks down at the figures below. Both arms are bent and his hands are raised with the palms held vertically. The figure to the right represents Virgil. He faces slightly left and may look towards Dante. Virgil's left arm is bent and the palm of his left hand may be held vertically. Two steps or plinths rising above the trees at the left border of the design suggests an altar; a fire burns on the upper step. A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands to the right of the fire. The figure faces left in profile. His left arm is bent and he holds a vase, censer, or other vessel; smoke rises from the vase. Seventeen nude figures fly or hover in the sky in the center of the design. Seven figures are apparently female, identifiable by long hair or exposed breasts; they may be the mothers of the ten children and infants within the group. Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. Each poet wears a spiky crown or vegetative wreath and three of the figures have long beards. The central figure is probably Homer. From left to right, the figures hold a book, scroll, sword, and lyre; the figure furthest right is partially obscured by a tree trunk. Two gowned figures with long hair stand beneath the clouds or smoke in the lower right portion of the design. Each figure holds and likely plays an instrument; the figure to the left holds a lyre at his or her side and the figure to the right holds a horn to his or her lips. The head of the figure to the left is turned up and he or she likely looks towards the figure to the right. Further down and to the right is a figure with long hair lying prone on the ground, facing down. The figure's left leg is extended, perhaps obscuring the right leg, and the left arm may be bent above or under the figure's head. Three lightly sketched figures sit or kneel together in the lower right portion of the design. The figures may lean against each other.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell.

The ground at the lower border of the design is covered with grass and a few scattered leaves. A thick forest of leafy trees appears across the lower half of the design and rises along the cliff to the right. The roots of a tree in the lower right are prominent and the branches of several trees are also visible.
Dark wash throughout the design indicates sky; a thick band of clouds or perhaps smoke extends horizontally across the upper portion of the image.
A rocky cliff rises in the right half of the design.

Two gowned males with long hair stand at the edge of a cliff in the upper right portion of the design. The figure to the left represents Dante. He faces left with his head turned down slightly; he likely looks down at the figures below. Both arms are bent and his hands are raised with the palms held vertically.

Two gowned males with long hair stand at the edge of a cliff in the upper right portion of the design. The figure to the right represents Virgil. He faces slightly left and may look towards Dante. Virgil's left arm is bent and the palm of his left hand may be held vertically.

A gowned male with long hair and a beard stands on an altar near the left border of the design. The figure faces left in profile. His left arm is bent and he holds a vase, censer, or other vessel; smoke rises from the vase.
Two steps or plinths rising above the trees at the left border of the design suggests an altar; a fire burns on the upper step.

Seventeen nude figures fly or hover in the sky in the center of the design. Seven figures are apparently female, identifiable by long hair or exposed breasts; they may be the mothers of the ten children and infants within the group. The body of the female in the upper left extends horizontally. Both arms are raised horizontally and she may hold hands with the child to the left. The female to the right cradles an infant in her bent right arm and may hold hands with the child to the right. Below, a female appears with her arms raised at 45 degrees; she touches or holds the arm of the child below. To the right, a female appears with both arms bent and her head turned to the right; she may hold hands with the child to the right. Below, a female faces left with her head turned up; her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and she reaches for the child above and to the left. She may also hold hands with the child to the right. Below and to the left, a female is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. Her left arm is bent upward and she holds the infant pictured above; the infant's arms are raised at 135 degrees. To the right, a female cradles an infant with her right arm and may hold hands with the child to the right.

Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. The figure furthest left has short hair and a beard. He wears a spiky crown or perhaps a vegetative wreath. The figure's right arm is down at his side and he holds a book in his right hand.

Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. A figure with long hair and a beard stands second from the left. He wears a spiky crown or perhaps a vegetative wreath. The figure's right arm is bent and he holds a partially rolled scroll in his right hand.

Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. A figure with long hair and a beard appears third from the left. He wears a crown or wreath of leaves extending to his shoulders. His right arm is down at his side and he holds a sword in his right hand. This is probably Homer.

Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. A figure with long hair appears fourth from the left. He wears a crown or wreath of vines and leaves. His right arm is apparently down and he holds a lyre at his side. His left arm is bent and the palm of his left hand is held vertically. The figure faces left with his head turned down slightly. His mouth may be open.

Five gowned males stand in the lower left portion of the design; they likely represent the ancient poets, although only four (Homer, Horace, Ovid, and Lucan) are named in the poem. The figure furthest right is partially obscured by a tree trunk. He wears a spiky crown or perhaps a vegetative wreath. The figure faces slightly left.

Two gowned figures with long hair stand beneath the clouds or smoke in the lower right portion of the design. Both face forward and slightly left. Each figure holds and likely plays an instrument; the figure to the left holds a lyre at his or her side and the figure to the right holds a horn to his or her lips. The head of the figure to the left is turned up and he or she likely looks towards the figure to the right.

A nude figure with long hair lies in a prone position in the lower right portion of the design. The figure's left leg extends down and to the right with the left foot visible. The figure's left arm is apparently bent; the figure's head may rest on his or her left forearm.

A figure with long hair lies prone on the ground, face down, lower right. The left leg is extended, possibly obscuring the right leg, and the left arm may be bent above or under the figure's head. Three lightly sketched figures sit or kneel together in the lower right portion of the design. The figures may lean against each other.

desc.objtitle:
Minos,
Object 9 (Butlin 812.9)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "10" top right, and "No 16 next at p. 44" top center, with the latter in the center of the sheet partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A sea or river of fire is visible in the middle distance, with flames rising in the lower left. A large platform, wall, or step rises above the fiery water. The upper and left portions of the sky are filled with dark clouds or smoke. Five lightning bolts appear below the clouds. Dante stands on a hill or mound in the lower left portion of the design. He faces forward and slightly right. His left arm is bent at his side and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer. Dante's right arm is raised at 135 degrees and his right hand rests on Virgil's shoulder. Virgil faces right in profile with his head turned up slightly. His left leg is bent and his right leg extends backward with the right foot raised on tiptoe; he likely strides to the right up the hill. The figure's right arm is raised at 135 degrees. His right hand is raised and he may point upward with his right forefinger extended. Virgil's left arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds or touches Dante with his left hand. A nude male with long hair and a beard sits on a flaming throne in the center of the design. He wears a crown and represents king Minos. He looks to the left and his mouth is open with the teeth visible. Minos sits with both legs bent and his left foot raised on tiptoe. His right arm is bent upward and the palm of his right hand turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread slightly. His left arm is bent and he holds a spear in his left hand. A serpent's tail rises above Minos's left shoulder. The throne rests atop three stairs or steps forming a plinth and dark smoke rises above. The heads of four figures appear within the smoke. Each figure has long hair and their heads are surrounded by halo-like circles. A nude female with long, flame-like hair flies or hovers in the left portion of the design. A halo is visible around her head. The figure faces down with her head turned up. Her body is positioned horizontally with the right leg extended upward. The figure's left arm is raised horizontally and she points to the right with her left forefinger extended. Her right arm is raised vertically and she holds the hair of the figure above; she may pull him downward. The male figure is upside down and his face is obscured. His lower body is dark, perhaps suggesting shadow. Both legs are bent and the figure's right leg is drawn up sharply. Both arms are bent and may wrap around his head. A nude figure with long hair kneels or perhaps crawls on the ground below Minos. The figure is seen from behind with his or her buttocks prominent. Both hands are raised beside the figure's head. A gowned female(?) with long hair kneels below Minos. The figure is seen from behind and both legs are bent with the soles of her feet turned out towards the viewer. The figure's head is down and may rest on the step below Minos's throne. Her left arm is raised horizontally and her right arm is raised at 135 degrees; the palms of both hands are held vertically. A nude female with short hair kneels in the lower right portion of the design. She is seen partly from behind with her buttocks prominent; her upper body is twisted forward slightly with the right breast exposed and her head is turned to the left. She may try to escape or turn away from the male figure to the right. The female's mouth is open and her teeth may be visible. Both legs are bent and her right leg is drawn up beneath her. Her right arm is down and her right hand may rest on the ground with the palm turned up. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and the palm of her left hand is turned up. A nude male with short, curly hair flies or hovers to the right. A faint halo appears around his head and he may be smiling. The figure may have dark wings and the fingers of his right hand are claw-like; he may represent a demon. The figure's body is positioned horizontally with his legs extended to the right. His upper body is twisted and his left arm is raised horizontally; he holds or embraces the female to the left. A nude female with long hair flies or hovers in the right portion of the design. She faces slightly right with her breasts exposed. Her head is bent back and to the left; her head may rest on her shoulder and her expression suggests despair. The figure's arms are bent upward and the palms of both hands are turned up. Both legs are bent. A nude male with long hair flies or hovers to the right. He is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. The figure's head is turned up and to the right and a lightly sketched halo is visible around his head. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet are turned out towards the viewer. His left arm is bent up and he holds or embraces the female above. The heads of two male(?) figures with short hair appear within the fiery river in the lower right portion of the design. The lower figure may be frowning and the upper figure's mouth is open; his expression suggests fear.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A sea or river of fire is visible in the middle distance, with flames rising in the lower left. A large platform, wall, or step rises above the fiery water. The upper and left portions of the sky are filled with dark clouds or smoke. Five lightning bolts appear below the clouds.

Dante stands on a hill in the lower left portion of the design. He is gowned and has long hair. Dante faces forward and slightly right. His left arm is bent at his side and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer. Dante's right arm is raised at 135 degrees and his right hand rests on Virgil's shoulder.
