Virgil stands on a hill in the lower left portion of the design. He is gowned and has long hair. Virgil faces right in profile with his head turned up slightly. His left leg is bent and his right leg extends backward with the right foot raised on tiptoe; he likely strides to the right up the hill. The figure's right arm is raised at 135 degrees. His right hand is raised and he may point upward with his right forefinger extended. Virgil's left arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds or touches Dante with his left hand.

A nude male with long hair and a beard sits on a flaming throne in the center of the design. He wears a crown and likely represents king Minos. The figure faces forward. He looks to the left and his mouth is open with the teeth visible. Minos sits with both legs bent and his left foot raised on tiptoe. His right arm is bent upward and the palm of his right hand turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread slightly. His left arm is bent and he holds a spear in his left hand. A serpent's tail rises above Minos's left shoulder.
The heads of four figures appear in the smoke to the left and right of Minos's throne. Each figure has long hair and their heads are surrounded by halo-like circles.
Minos sits on a flaming throne in the center of the design; smoke rises above. The throne rests atop three stairs or steps forming a plinth.
Green wash at the lower border of the design may indicate grass; the ground slopes upward towards the center, forming a small hill or mound.
A chain with nine links and a hook appears on the ground in the lower right portion of the design. A less distinct chain extends below and to the right.

A nude female with long, flame-like hair flies or hovers in the left portion of the design. A halo is visible around her head. The figure faces down with her head turned up. Her body is positioned horizontally with the right leg extended upward. The figure's left arm is raised horizontally and she points to the right with her left forefinger extended. Her right arm is raised vertically and she holds the hair of the figure above; she may pull him downward.

A nude male with short hair flies or hovers in the left portion of the design. He is upside down and may be falling. The figure's face is obscured. His lower body is dark, perhaps suggesting shadow. Both legs are bent and the figure's right leg is drawn up sharply. His left foot is visible. Both arms are bent and may wrap around his head. The figure below grabs his hair and may pull him downward.

A nude figure with long hair kneels or perhaps crawls on the ground below Minos. The figure is seen from behind with his or her buttocks prominent. He or she faces right. Both hands are raised beside the figure's head.

A gowned female(?) with long hair kneels below Minos. The figure is seen from behind. Both legs are bent with the soles of her feet turned out towards the viewer. The figure's head is down and may rest on the step below Minos's throne. Her left arm is raised horizontally and her right arm is raised at 135 degrees; the palms of both hands are held vertically.

A nude female with short hair kneels in the lower right portion of the design. She is seen partly from behind with her buttocks prominent; her upper body is twisted forward slightly with the right breast exposed and her head is turned to the left. She may try to escape or turn away from the male figure to the right. The female's mouth is open and her teeth may be visible. Both legs are bent and her right leg is drawn up beneath her. Her right arm is down and her right hand may rest on the ground with the palm turned up. Her left arm is raised at 135 degrees and the palm of her left hand is turned up.

A nude male with short, curly hair flies or hovers in the lower right portion of the design. A faint halo appears around his head and he may be smiling. The figure may have dark wings and the fingers of his right hand are claw-like; he may represent a demon. The figure's body is positioned horizontally with his legs extended to the right. His upper body is twisted and his left arm is raised horizontally; he holds or embraces the female to the left.

A nude female with long hair flies or hovers in the right portion of the design. She faces slightly right with her breasts exposed. Her head is bent back and to the left; her head may rest on her shoulder and her expression suggests despair. The figure's arms are bent upward and the palms of both hands are turned up. Both legs are bent.

A nude male with long hair flies or hovers in the right portion of the design. He is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. The figure's head is turned up and to the right and a light halo is visible around his head. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet are turned out towards the viewer. His left arm is bent up and he holds or embraces the female above.

The heads of two male(?) figures with short hair appear within the fiery river in the lower right portion of the design. The lower figure may be frowning and the upper figure's mouth is open; his expression suggests fear.

desc.objtitle:
The Circle of the Lustful: Francesca Da Rimini The Whirlwind of Lovers,
Object 10 (Butlin 812.10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. Fire appears along the lower border of the design; dark wash among the flames represents smoke. A grassy bank or ledge appears above the flames in the right half of the design. A whirlwind of fire rises from the lower right to the upper left corner; the column forms a single loop. A second column of fire rises above the grassy bank, extending up and to the right. Dark blue wash throughout the design indicates sky. The sun appears in the upper right corner; beams of light radiate outward. A gowned male representing Virgil stands on the grassy ledge. Virgil has long hair and his head is turned down; he likely looks toward Dante, below. Virgil's arm are down at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down. Dante lies supine on the grassy ledge. His body is positioned horizontally with his head to the right. His eyes are closed; he has fainted. Dante's left arm rests on the ground and the palm of his left hand is turned down. Two figures fly or hover within the column of fire and wind pictured above Dante. The figure to the right is a gowned female with long hair. She likely represents Francesca da Rimini. Francesca faces forward with her upper body twisted to the left. Her left arm is bent upward; she reaches for and may touch the male pictured to the left. Francesca's head is turned up and her mouth may be open. Her eyes are raised and she looks at her companion. The figure to the left is a nude male with short hair. He likely represents Paolo Malatesta. Paolo is seen from behind with his upper body twisted to the right. Both legs are bent slightly and his buttocks are prominent. Paolo's right arm is raised at 45 degrees; he reaches for and may touch the female pictured to the right. At least thirty-seven nude figures fly or hover within a large column of flame rising from the lower right to the upper left corner of the design. The column forms a single loop and the figures are likely rising upward as if blown by a wind. Seven figures are seen from behind with their buttocks prominent. Four on the right side of the loop are positioned upside down. At least ten figures are clearly female with exposed breasts. The figures in the upper left are less distinct than the lower figures. Two figures in the upper section of the loop are kissing; the arms of the upper figure at raised horizontally. A male in the lower left points upward with his left arm raised at 135 degrees. A figure near the lower border faces forward with his or her hands raised beside her head; the figure's mouth is open and his or her expression suggests fear or pain. A male to the right displays a wide-eyed expression suggesting surprise. A female with long hair appears in a twisted position in the lower right; both legs are bent and her arms are wrapped around her body. Two figures in the lower right are indistinct; only the head of the upper figure is visible. Two lightly sketched nude figures kneel within the disc of the sun in the upper right corner of the design. The female(?) figure to the right is seen from behind. The figures embrace and are likely kissing. They probably represent Francesca da Rimini (on the right?) and Paolo Malatesta (on the left?).

Dark blue wash throughout the design indicates sky. The sun appears in the upper right corner; beams of light radiate outward.

A gowned male representing Virgil stands on a grassy ledge in the right portion of the design. Virgil has long hair and his head is turned down; he likely looks toward Dante, below. Virgil's arm are down at his sides and the palms of both hands are turned down.

A gowned male representing Dante lies supine in the right portion of the design. His hair is curly. Dante's body is positioned horizontally with his head to the right. His eyes are closed; he has fainted. His left arm rests on the ground and the palm of his left hand is turned down.

Two figures fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design; they are surrounded by a column of fire and wind. The figure to the right is a gowned female with long hair. She likely represents Francesca da Rimini. Francesca faces forward with her upper body twisted to the left. Her left arm is bent upward; she reaches for and may touch the male pictured to the left. Francesca's head is turned up and her mouth may be open. Her eyes are raised and she looks at her companion.

Two figures fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design; they are surrounded by fire and wind. The figure to the left is a nude male with short hair. He likely represents Paolo Malatesta. Paolo is seen from behind with his upper body twisted to the right. Both legs are bent slightly and his buttocks are prominent. Paolo's right arm is raised at 45 degrees; he reaches for and may touch the female pictured to the right.

Two lightly sketched nude figures kneel within the disc of the sun in the upper right corner of the design. The female(?) figure to the right is seen from behind. The figures embrace and are likely kissing. They probably represent Francesca da Rimini (on the right?) and Paolo Malatesta (on the left?).

At least thirty-seven nude figures fly or hover within a large column of flame rising from the lower right to the upper left corner of the design. The column forms a single loop and the figures are likely rising upward as if blown by a wind. Seven figures are seen from behind with their buttocks prominent. Four on the right side of the loop are positioned upside down. At least ten figures are clearly female with exposed breasts. The figures in the upper left are less distinct than the lower figures. Two figures in the upper section of the loop are kissing; the arms of the upper figure at raised horizontally. A male in the lower left points upward with his left arm raised at 135 degrees. A figure near the lower border faces forward with his or her hands raised beside her head; the figure's mouth is open and his or her expression suggests fear or pain. A male to the right displays a wide-eyed expression suggesting surprise. A female with long hair appears in a twisted position in the lower right; both legs are bent and her arms are wrapped around her body. Two figures in the lower right are indistinct; only the head of the upper figure is visible.

desc.objtitle:
The Circle of the Gluttons with Cerberus,
Object 11 (Butlin 812.11 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "ENOCH" upper center, and "Enoch" lower left. The first of these inscriptions might be by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A body of water, perhaps a lake, is visible in the lower half of the design. Two mountains rise above; an archway at the base of the leftmost mountain indicates a cave. Liquid, probably rain, seems to drip along the side of the mountain. Fire is visible on the upper portion of the mountain. Red and yellow coloring in the sky may suggest sunrise or sunset, or perhaps fire. Dark clouds or perhaps smoke appears in the upper right. A distant wall visible between the two mountain peaks may represent the city of Dis. A three-headed dog representing Cerberus appears in the mouth of a cave in the lower left portion of the design. The mouth of each head is open. The leftmost head faces left, the central head is turned up, and the rightmost head faces right. We can see the tongues of all three heads and perhaps teeth on the right head. A group of figures fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design; they are upside down and may be falling. Only the central figure is clearly visible; the figure is female and may be nude. Both legs are bent and her arms are raised at 135 degrees. Lightly sketched circles may suggest the heads of eight or more figures swimming in the lake in the lower portion of the design. Three additional figures may be swimming near the lower border with their arms raised at 135 degrees. Lightly sketched figures appear along the mountainside; two appear above the cave, three or four appear further to the right, and the heads of six figures are visible near the summit. All the figures are probably gluttons.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A body of water, perhaps a lake, is visible in the lower half of the design. Two mountains rise above; an archway at the base of the leftmost mountain indicates a cave. Liquid, probably rain, seems to drip along the side of the mountain. Fire is visible on the upper portion of the mountain.
Red and yellow coloring in the sky may suggest sunrise or sunset, or perhaps fire. Dark clouds or perhaps smoke appears in the upper right.
A distant wall visible between the two mountain peaks may represent the city of Dis.

A three-headed dog representing Cerberus appears in the mouth of a cave in the lower left portion of the design. The mouth of each head is open. The leftmost head faces left, the central head is turned up, and the rightmost head faces right. We can see the tongues on all three heads and perhaps teeth on the right head.

A group of figures fly or hover in the upper right portion of the design; they are upside down and may be falling. Only the central figure is clearly visible; the figure is female and may be nude. Both legs are bent and her arms are raised at 135 degrees.

Lightly sketched circles may suggest the heads of eight or more figures swimming in the lake in the lower half of the design. Three additional figures may be swimming near the lower border with their arms raised at 135 degrees. These figures, and probably the others in this designs, are gluttons.
Lightly sketched figures appear along the mountainside; two appear above the cave, three or four appear further to the right, and the heads of six figures are visible near the summit.

desc.objtitle:
First Version of Cerberus,
Object 12 (Butlin 812.12)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "29" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A dark archway appears in upper portion, perhaps indicating a cave. The interior of the cave is colored red and yellow, suggesting fire. A large stone ledge appears at the right border. A three-headed dog representing Cerberus lies in the center of the design. The mouth of each head is open with the teeth and tongue visible. The leftmost head faces left, the central head is turned up and to the right, and the rightmost head faces forward. Its front legs are spread apart. Cerberus holds a nude male beneath a hand-like front right paw. The figure's body is positioned horizontally and both arms are bent and wrapped around his head. Two additional victims may be visible beneath Cerberus's other paws. Two gowned males appear on a stone ledge in the upper right portion of the design. The figure to the left is likely Virgil. He is seen from behind faces away from the viewer with his head turned down and to the left. Virgil kneels with his left leg extended backward and his right leg bent and drawn up. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees. The figure standing to the right is likely Dante. He is seen from behind and faces slightly left. A liquid, probably heavy rain, descends over the top and left portions of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A dark archway appears in upper portion, perhaps indicating a cave. The interior of the cave is colored red and yellow, suggesting fire. A large stone ledge appears at the right border. A liquid, probably heavy rain, descends over the top and left portions of the design.

A three-headed dog representing Cerberus lies in the center of the design. The mouth of each head is open with the teeth and tongue visible. The leftmost head faces left, the central head is turned up and to the right, and the rightmost head faces forward. Cerberus's front legs are spread apart and he holds perhaps three indistinct figures beneath his hand-like paws.

Cerberus holds a nude male beneath its front right paw. The figure's body is positioned horizontally and both arms are bent and wrapped around his head. Two additional victims may be visible beneath Cerberus's other paws.

Two gowned males appear on a stone ledge in the upper right portion of the design. The figure to the left is likely Virgil. He is seen from behind faces away from the viewer with his head turned down and to the left. Virgil kneels with his left leg extended backward and his right leg bent and drawn up. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees.
Two gowned males appear on a stone ledge in the upper right portion of the design. The figure standing to the right is likely Dante. He is seen from behind and faces slightly left.

desc.objtitle:
Second Version of Cerberus,
Object 13 (Butlin 812.13)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "19" top right, and "Pg Canto 25" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. An arch in the center of the design suggests a cave. Blue flames rise from the mouth of the cave. Green coloring in the lower right may indicate grass. Lightly sketched buildings at right border of the design may indicate the distant city of Dis. Flames rise from the city. A wall, path, or road leads downward from the buildings. Dark clouds or smoke appear in the sky in the upper portion of the design. Vertical lines throughout the design may indicate rain. A three-headed dog representing Cerberus lies below the mouth of a cave in the lower half of the design. The mouth of each head is open with the teeth and tongue visible. The leftmost head is turned up, the central head faces right, and the rightmost head faces forward. Cerberus holds three figures in its hand-like paws. Each figure's head is bent back and the mouth of the leftmost figure is open; his expression may indicate fear or pain. Two gowned males with long hair stand near the right border of the design. Both figures are seen from behind. The figure to the left is likely Virgil; both arms extend horizontally to the left and he offers handfuls of earth to Cerberus. The figure to the right is likely Dante. He stands with his left leg bent slightly and his left foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are apparently bent up and to the right. His right palm is turned up and his left palm may be held vertically; the fingers of both hands are spread slightly. The heads of two lightly sketched figures appear in the lower left corner of the design. Their expressions suggest fear.

Green coloring in the lower right may indicate grass.

Dark clouds or smoke appear in the sky in the upper portion of the design. Vertical lines throughout the design may indicate rain.

He stands with his left leg bent slightly and his left foot raised on tiptoe. Both arms are apparently bent up and to the right. His right palm is turned up and his left palm may be held vertically; the fingers of both hands are spread slightly.

The leftmost head is turned up, the central head faces right, and the rightmost head faces forward. Cerberus holds three figures in its hand-like paws.

Three lightly sketched nude males(?) lie supine in the lower half of the design, pinned beneath Cerberus's paws. Each figure's head is bent back and the mouth of the leftmost figure is open; his expression may indicate fear or pain.
The heads of two lightly sketched figures appear in the lower left corner of the design. Their expressions suggest fear.

desc.objtitle:
Plutus,
Object 14 (Butlin 812.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A large stone ledge appears in the center of the design, possibly forming a cave below. Fire appears throughout the design and dark clouds or smoke rises above. Two gowned males with long hair stand on a stone ledge in the upper portion of the design. The figure to the left likely represents Dante. His right foot is raised on tiptoe and he may walk forward. Dante's right arm is down at his side and his right hand is not pictured. His left arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds or touches Virgil's right arm. Virgil's right leg is bent with the right foot raised on tiptoe; he may walk forward. Virgil's right arm is bent slightly at his side. His left arm is bent and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer. The fingers of his left hand are spread. Virgil's eyes are apparently cast down and may look toward Plutus, below. Plutus is nude; his beard and long hair stand partially on end. His eyes are raised and he looks towards Dante and Virgil above. Plutus's mouth is open with the teeth visible; he may be speaking or shouting. He sits with both legs bent and drawn up; his right foot may be raised on tiptoe. The figure's right arm is raised horizontally and his right hand rests on a bag or jar of coins with the palm turned down. The word "Money" is inscribed just below the coins; see the Textual Transcription. His left arm is raised vertically and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer; his fingers are spread and he may point or otherwise gesture upward.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A large stone ledge appears in the center of the design, possibly forming a cave below. Fire appears throughout the design and dark clouds or smoke rises above.

His left arm is bent and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer. The fingers of his left hand are spread. Virgil's eyes are apparently cast down and may look toward Plutus, below.

A nude male representing Plutus sits in the lower half of the design. Plutus has a beard and his long hair stands partially on end. His eyes are raised and he looks towards Dante and Virgil above. Plutus's mouth is open with the teeth visible; he may be speaking or shouting. Both legs are bent and his left leg is drawn up to his groin. His right foot may be raised on tiptoe. The figure's right arm is raised horizontally and his right hand rests on a bag of coins with the palm turned down. His left arm is raised vertically and the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer; his fingers are spread and he may point or otherwise gesture upward.
Plutus's right hand rests on a lightly sketched bag, jar, or other container filled with coins. The word "Money" is inscribed just below the coins; see the Textual Transcription.

lg.l: Money The word is inscribed on the sack of coins below the extended right hand of the figure lower right.

desc.objtitle:
The Goddess of Fortune,
Object 15 (Butlin 812.16)

objnote.p: The lower right corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "55" top right, "No 19 next a p 80" top center, and "HELL Canto 12" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A series of concentric circles in the lower half of the design suggests a hole or other depression, possibly a spiral vortex. Blue wash at the upper border suggests sky; a dark band of clouds forms a slight arch below. A female flies or hovers in the lower half of the design; she may represent the personification of Fortune. The figure is nude with her breasts exposed. Both arms are bent upward and her hands clutch at her head. Her lower body is twisted with the legs extended up and to the right and the feet together. Two groups of lightly sketched figures appear beneath the cloud belt in the upper portion of the design. Two circular objects, likely stone boulders, appear between the two groups. Both boulders are inscribed with texts, perhaps partly erased; see the Textual Transcription. Most of the figures are indistinct, suggested only by circular heads and rough pencil lines. The most defined figure stands to the left of the boulders with his or her right leg extended backward (to the left); he or she may walk or stride to the right. The figure bends or leans forward and likely pushes the leftmost boulder to the right. The figures on the right may be pushing the other stone. Inscribed texts appear on the dark circle above Fortune; see the Textual Transcription.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A series of concentric circles in the lower half of the design suggests a hole or other depression, possibly a spiral vortex. Inscribed texts appear on the dark circle above the figure lower center; see the Textual Transcription.
Blue wash at the upper border suggests sky; a dark band of clouds forms a slight arch below.

Two groups of lightly sketched figures appear beneath the cloud belt in the upper portion of the design. Two circular objects, likely stone boulders, appear between the two groups. These circles include very lightly inscribed texts, perhaps partly erased; see the Textual Transcription. Most of the figures are indistinct, suggested only by circular heads and rough pencil lines. The most defined figure stands to the left of the boulders with his or her right leg extended backward (to the left); he or she may walk or stride to the right. The figure bends or leans forward and likely pushes the leftmost boulder to the right. The figures on the right may be pushing the other stone.

lg.l:
Celestial
Lines 1-2 are written in a circle, representing the heavens or a celestial globe, left of center. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.
Terrestrial Lines 3-4 are written in a circle, representing the earth or a terrestrial globe, right of center. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

l.hi: The hole of a shit house
l.note: Lines 5-6 are written in an arc above the lower figure.

l.hi: The Goddess Fortune is the devils servant ready to Kiss any ones Arse

desc.objtitle:
The Stygian Lake with the Ireful Sinners Fighting The Stygian Lake with the Angry Sinners Fighting,
Object 16 (Butlin 812.15)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "6" top right, "No 4 next at p 49" and "14 x 49" top center, and "HELL Canto 3" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A body of water representing "the Stygian Lake" dominates the design; waves are visible throughout. Six nude males are submerged in the lake of the center of the design; the figures are fighting and likely swimming. The figure furthest left has long hair and a beard. He may be frowning and his expression suggests anger. Both legs are bent but only the figure's left foot is visible. His upper body is twisted to the right. The figure's right arm is bent upward and his left arm extends to the left across his body; both hands are held in fists. The figure second from the left has short hair. His mouth is open slightly and his expression suggests fear. His right arm is raised vertically and his right hand is raised in a fist. The figure third from the left has short hair. He faces right in profile and his mouth is open; he looks at his opponent to the right and his expression suggests anger. His right arm is bent upward and his right hand is raised in a fist. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees and his left hand clutches at the head of the figure to the right. The figure fourth from the left has long, curly hair. He faces left in profile and looks at his opponent to the left; his expression suggests anger. His right arm is apparently raised at 135 degrees and he clutches at the head of the figure to the left. The figure fifth from the left has short(?) hair and a beard. He faces left and may be frowning slightly. His left arm is raised above his head with the hand closed in a fist. The figure furthest right has long hair and a beard; he wears a cloth band on his forehead. His mouth is open with the teeth visible; his expression suggests fear or surprise. Both legs are apparently bent to the left and both feet are visible. The figure's left arm is bent upward and his right arm is raised vertically; both hands are held in fists above the figure's head. Three figures lie submerged at the bottom of the lake; they are upside down with their heads oriented down, towards the viewer. They may have drowned. A nude(?) male with long hair and a beard appears furthest left. He faces up with his head turned to the left. Both legs are bent and drawn up with the knees prominent. The figure's left arm is bent and rests on the ground beside his head; his left hand is closed in a fist. A male(?) wearing a hood, helmet, or other head covering appears second from the left. His eyes are closed and his mouth is open slightly. The figure faces up with both legs bent to the right. A male with long hair and a beard appears furthest right. He may wear a gown, though his legs appear bare. Both legs are bent and drawn up with the knees prominent. The figure faces up with his upper body twisted to the right. His right arm rests at his side and his left arm is wrapped around his body.

lg.l: The Stygian Lake Canto 7 This inscription is very faint and may have been almost completely erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle:
Dante and Virgil about to Pass the Stygian Lake Dante and Virgil about to Cross towards the City of Dis,
Object 17 (Butlin 812.17)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "15" top right, "N7 next at p. 9" across the top, and an erased inscription in the center of the sheet, probably the same as the one across the top. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A body of water representing "the Stygian Lake" extends across the lower half of the design. Two distant mountains rise above the lake. The sky at the upper border of the design is filled with clouds. Two lightly sketched gowned figures stand on the shore of the lake in the lower right portion of the design. They likely represent Dante and Virgil. The figures are apparently seen from behind and the figure to the left raises his right arm at 45 degrees; they may hold hands. A tower rises above the shore to the right. Two crescent-shaped lamps, similar to crescent moons, are visible near the top of the tower; radiant light surrounds the lamps. A second tower stands on the distant shore of the lake, near the left border of the design. Radiant light appears near the top of the tower. A sailboat with a visible mast appears on the surface of the lake near the lower border. A lightly sketched figure sits or reclines in the sailboat. The figure has short hair and may wear a gown. This may be Phlegyas.

The sky at the upper border of the design is filled with clouds.

desc.objtitle:
Virgil Repelling Filippo Argenti from the Boat of Phlegyas,
Object 18 (Butlin 812.18 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "77" top left, "No 46 next at p 74" across the top, and "25," partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A body of water representing "the Stygian Lake" extends across the lower half of the design; small waves are visible throughout. Distant mountains rise above. Clouds appear in the sky at the upper border of the design. A distant tower appears in the upper right portion of the design; the tower is dark and may be cast in shadow. The stern end of a sail boat appears on the water in the foreground; its rudder is visible to the right. Two gowned males with long hair stand in the boat. The figure to the left represents Dante. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the right; he looks down and to the right towards the figure rising from the water. Dante's arms are down at his sides. The palm of his right hand is turned down; his left hand is turned out, away from the viewer, with the fingers spread. The figure to the right represents Virgil. His legs are spread and he lunges to the right with his left leg bent forward. His head is turned down slightly and he looks at the figure below and to the right. Both arms are bent and Virgil holds the other figure's head and right arm, pushing him back from the boat. The nude figure likely represents Filippo Argenti. He faces forward with his mouth open and the upper row of teeth visible; he may be speaking or shouting. Filippo's expression suggests surprise. Both arms are raised vertically and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer. The fingers of both hands are spread slightly. A gowned male with long hair and a beard sits or reclines in the rightmost section of the boat. He likely represents Phlegyas. Only his upper body is clearly visible. Phlegyas's right arm is bent and rests at his side. His left arm is bent back slightly and his left hand holds or rests on the tiller with the palm turned down.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A body of water representing "the Stygian Lake" extends across the lower half of the design; small waves are visible throughout. Distant mountains rise above.

The palm of his right hand is turned down; his left hand is turned out, away from the viewer, with the fingers spread.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the boat. The figure to the right represents Virgil. His legs are spread and he lunges to the right with his left leg bent forward. His head is turned down slightly and he looks at the figure below and to the right. Both arms are bent and Virgil holds the other figure's head and right arm, pushing him back from the boat.

The upper body of a nude male appears in the center of the design, rising above the edge of the boat. He likely represents Filippo Argenti. The figure has short hair. He faces forward with his mouth open and the upper row of teeth visible; he may be speaking or shouting. Filippo's expression suggests surprise. Both arms are raised vertically and the palms of both hands are turned out towards the viewer. The fingers of both hands are spread slightly.

A gowned male with long hair and a beard sits or reclines in the rightmost section of the boat. He likely represents Phlegyas. Only his upper body is clearly visible. Phlegyas's right arm is bent and rests at his side. His left arm is bent back slightly and his left hand holds or rests on the tiller with the palm turned down.

desc.objtitle:
The Angel Crossing the Styx The City of Dis and the Angel Crossing the Stygian Lake,
Object 19 (Butlin 812.19 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "62" partly erased top right, and "Canto 24 v 60" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A body of water representing the Styx appears lower left; waves are visible throughout. A series of arches above the lake suggest other distant circles of hell. Five lightly sketched figures stand within the arch in the upper right portion of the design. At least one additional figure appears in the arch in the upper left. Dark vertical lines throughout the design may indicate rain. The outer wall of the city of Dis stands on the shore of the Styx in the lower right portion of the design. A closed(?) gate appears in the center of the wall; a step is visible below the threshold. There are slight suggestions of a portcullis in the upper part of this portal. The roof of a building is visible above the wall. Fire rises above the wall. A path or road leads from the shore of the Styx to the gate. Two lightly sketched gowned figures stand at the gate of the city of Dis; they likely represent Dante and Virgil. A whirlwind appears above the Styx, extending from the left border and rising above the city of Dis. The whirlwind forms one or two loops. A multitude of figures are visible within the whirlwind; additional figures appear in the Styx, below. Only the figures' heads are clearly visible. A nude male(?) with long hair lies on the shore of the Styx just below the whirlwind. The figure is positioned upside down with his head oriented down towards the viewer. Both legs are bent and drawn up. His arms extend horizontally, in a cruciform position, and hie hands rest on the ground with the palms turned down. A nude male angel with long hair appears in the lower left corner of the design. The angel runs or strides to the right in a contracted position; both legs are bent and spread wide apart and his left knee is drawn up to his chest. Both arms are bent and the figure's left hand is raised in front of his face.

A nude male angel with long hair appears in the lower left corner of the design. The angel runs or strides to the right in a contracted position; both legs are bent and spread wide apart and his left knee is drawn up to his chest. Both arms are bent and the figure's left hand is raised in front of his face.

lg.l:
Hell Canto 8
This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle:
The Angel at the Gate of Dis,
Object 20 (Butlin 812.20 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "11" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. The outer wall of the city of Dis extends across the center of the design. An entryway in the center of the wall is blocked by a portcullis. An angel stands on a step below the gate. A path or road at the lower border of the design leads to the step below the wall. Fire rises above the wall; grey wash in the upper left and right corners may suggest smoke. Grass appears at the lower border of the design, to the left and right of the pathway. A spiky or thorny vine grows in the lower left corner and a leafy vine rises along the wall in the lower right. Two flowers, possibly sunflowers, with distinct petals appear in the lower right; their stems arch to the left. Two budding stems arch to the right. A nude male angel with long hair stands in the center of the design. He is seen from behind with his wings are outstretched and his buttocks prominent. The figure's right leg extends backward with the right foot raised on tiptoe. His left leg is bent slightly and he climbs onto the step below the wall. The angel's right arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds a staff or walking stick in his right hand. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees; the palm of his left hand is turned out, away from the viewer, with the fingers spread. Three female figures representing the Furies fly or hover at the upper border of the design. Only the figures' heads and arms are pictured. Their mouths are open and they may be speaking or screaming. The figure furthest left has long hair and her head is turned up and to the right. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she holds a musical horn in her right hand; flames emerge from the bell of the horn. The figure furthest right mirrors this pose; she holds a flaming horn in her raised left hand. The central figure has curly hair, possibly representing the serpent-hair of a gorgon. Her head is turned down with the eyes cast down; she looks at the angel below. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees and she holds a snake or serpent in each hand. The serpents' mouths are open with the tongues extended; the serpent to the left may have a crested head. Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower left portion of the design. The figure to the right represents Virgil. Virgil faces forward with his head turned up and to the right; he looks towards the angel and furies above. His left arm is bent an he touches or embraces Dante, covering his eyes. Dante faces left with his head turned down. His left arm is bent upward and he holds his gown to his face. His legs are spread and his left foot is raised on tiptoe; he may walk or stride to the left.

Three female figures representing the Furies fly or hover at the upper border of the design. Only the figures' heads and arms are pictured. Her right arm is raised horizontally and she holds a musical horn in her right hand; flames emerge from the bell of the horn.

Their mouths are open and they may be speaking or screaming. The figure furthest right faces forward with her head turned up slightly. Her left arm is raised horizontally and she holds a horn in her left hand; flames emerge from the bell of the horn.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower left portion of the design. The figure to the right represents Virgil. Virgil faces forward with his head turned up and to the right; he looks towards the angel and furies above. His left arm is bent an he touches or embraces Dante, covering his eyes.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower left portion of the design. The figure to the left represents Dante. Dante faces left with his head turned down. His left arm is bent upward and he holds his gown to his face. His legs are spread and his left foot is raised on tiptoe; he may walk or stride to the left.

desc.objtitle:
Dante Conversing with Farinata Degli Uberti,
Object 21 (Butlin 812.21)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A wall extends across the center of the design and the roofs of several buildings are visible above, representing the city of Dis. A building with a domed roof has four visible pillars or columns. Fire rises among the buildings; a dark shape above the right portion of the wall may represent smoke. Dark clouds appear in the sky. Three graves or tombs appear at the lower border of the design. The tomb lids are propped open and flames rise from each of the graves. Virgil stands at the left border of the design. He is gowned and has long hair. Both arms are down at his sides. Virgil faces forward with his head turned slightly to the right; he looks to the right towards Dante. Dante is gowned and has long hair. Both feet are visible below his gown. His right arm is down at his side and his left arm is bent upward; the palm of his left hand is turned out towards the viewer. Dante faces right in profile with his head turned down slightly; he looks towards the figures in the tomb below. A male figure representing Farinata degli Uberti appears within a grave at the lower border of the design. Only his upper body is clearly visible. He is gowned and has a long beard. He wears a helmet, suggesting that he is a soldier. Farinata's right arm is bent upward; the fingers of his right hand are spread and he may point or otherwise gesture upward. His left arm is down at his side and the fingers of his left hand touch the ground below. The head and shoulders of a male figure appear above the edge of a grave in the lower right portion of the design; he likely represents Cavalcante Cavalcanti. The figure has long hair and a beard. He faces forward with his head turned up and to the left; he looks towards Dante. The figure's hands rest on the ground at the edge of the grave with the fingers spread.

desc.objtitle:
The Circles of Hell Scheme of the Circles of Hell,
Object 22 (Butlin 812.101 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "9" lower right, "6" center left, "N 8 next at p 17" center right, "Hell. Carthew No Canto number. Entitled 'Hell Circles' at end of list of Hell in Christie's Catalogue of Sale" upper right, and "Debris" top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lightly sketched spiral represents the nine circles of hell. Blake's notes are written throughout the diagram (see the Textual Transcription). Rose and grey wash appear in the center of the spiral, perhaps suggesting fire and smoke. The upper body of an angel appears in the uppermost circle. The angel's wings are visible and the figure may be flying or hovering. The figure's arms are likely bent with both hands resting on the side of his or her face. Lightly sketched lines suggesting the angel's lower body appear in the second and third circles from the top.

desc.objtitle:
The Minotaur,
Object 23 (Butlin 812.22 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "83" top left, "No 29 next at p 82 this should be 35" in the center, with the "28" deleted by the "29," and "HELL Canto 18 v 80" along the left margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. Large stones appear at the lower border of the design. A cliff drops off steeply in the lower left. Green coloring in the lower right portion of the design indicates grass. Two gowned males with long hair stand at the edge of the cliff. The figure to the left represents Dante. He faces left with his upper body turned away from the viewer and his head turned up and to the right; he looks toward Virgil above. Dante's legs are bent and his left foot is raised on tiptoe; he likely runs to the left, fleeing from the minotaur. Both arms are bent upward and the palm of his left hand is held vertically. Virgil faces right in profile and looks towards the minotaur. His left arm is raised horizontally with the palm of his left hand held vertically. Virgil's right arm is raised at 45 degrees and he holds hands with Dante. A minotaur stands in the right half of the design. The figure's head and body are covered in fur and his upper body is bare. He faces left with his upper body twisted forward. Two horns rise from the figure's temples and his mouth is open slightly with the teeth visible. The minotaur rears up on his hind legs with the front legs extended up and to the left. His tail rises upward to the right. Both arms are bent upward and the palms of both hands are turned up. A distant wall is visible in the right half of the design; fire rises above. The wall may represent the city of Dis. A building or altar appears in the center of the design. A faint inscription, "MIASTAMU," is visible on the upper portion of the altar. Blue wash at the left border indicates sky. Two dark clouds or smoke rise to the right; grey wash throughout the sky suggests additional clouds or smoke.

lg.l: MIASTAMU This inscription is written, rather obscurely, on the front of the altar in the center of the composition. Neither "A" is crossed; the "M" (if it is an "M") is oddly shaped. There may be another inscription, just barely indicated, on the right side of the altar.
7 The number is awkwardly formed and may simply be an accidental conjunction of two chalk marks.

desc.objtitle:
The Centaurs and the River of Blood,
Object 24 (Butlin 812.23)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "56" top right, "Paradiso Canto 30" bottom right, and "Parad Canto 30" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A river of blood identified in the poem as the Phlegethon flows through a valley in the central portion of the design. A distant hill or mountain may rise above. Green coloring on the banks of the river suggests grass or other vegetation. Two lightly defined cliffs frame the scene, rising along the left and right borders of the design. A male centaur stands at the left border of the design. The figure's upper body is nude and he has long hair. He is seen from behind with his head turned to the left in profile. The figure's right arm is bent and he holds a bow in his right hand. A female centaur with long hair sits at the right border of the design. She faces left with her head turned to the right. Her front leg bent forward; she may be crouching. Her upper body is nude with her breasts exposed. Her left arm is bent at her side. Four centaurs stand on the left bank of the river in the lower portion of the design. The figure furthest left may be female; she is lightly drawn, but may have exposed breasts. Only her upper body is clearly visible. The figure's right arm is bent upward and wraps around her head. The figure second from the left is male and has long hair. He faces right and his right arm is raised at 45 degrees; he holds a bow in his right hand. The figure third from the left faces forward and slightly right. His or her features are indistinct. The figure's left arm is raised at 45 degrees and he or she holds a bow. The figure furthest right is likely male. He stands facing right with his front right leg bent backward. His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds a bow in his left hand. His right arm is bent and he draws back an arrow on the bowstring. He may look toward the figure fleeing to the right. The fleeing figure is nude and may fly or hover above the river in the lower right portion of the design. The figure is seen from behind with his or her buttocks prominent. The figure's right arm is raised at 135 degrees. The figure's right leg is bent and his or her left leg extends backward; he or she may run to the right. At least sixteen lightly sketched figures appear partially submerged within the Phlegethon; the figures are likely standing at various depths. The heads of eight figures appear above the surface of the river in the lower portion of the design. The upper bodies of at least eight figures are visible along the length of the river, appearing singly or in small groups of two and three. One figure in the lower right raises his or her arms horizontally. Some of these figures may be swimming. Four lightly sketched centaurs stand on the upper right bank of the river; one of the centaurs runs or leaps to the left with his or her forelegs raised above the ground.

His left arm is raised horizontally and he holds a bow in his left hand. His right arm is bent and he draws back an arrow on the bowstring. He may look toward the figure fleeing to the right.

The figure is seen from behind with his or her buttocks prominent. The figure's right arm is raised at 135 degrees. desc.objtitle:
The Wood of the Self-Murderers: The Harpies and the Suicides The Wood of the Self-Violators: The Harpies and the Suicides,
Object 25 (Butlin 812.24)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "N21 next at p. 86" top center, the same vertically in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 13" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Six thorny trees appear in the foreground of the design; at least four of the trees are clearly anthropomorphic with human faces and bodies visible along their trunks. These are self-violators transformed into trees. Distant leafy trees appear across the center of the design. White space in the upper half of the design indicates sky; red and yellow coloring at the left border suggests fire. Two gowned males with long hair stand in the center of the design; the figure to the left represents Dante. He stands with his legs spread apart and both feet visible; he may be crouching slightly. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees and extend to the left with the palms turned down. Dante looks at the bleeding branch to the right. The broken section of the branch (with oak leaves?) lies on the ground below Dante's feet. The figure to the right represents Virgil. He faces forward with his left arm down at his side. A male spirit appears in the tree fourth from the left; he represents Pier delle Vigne. Vigne has a beard and his long hair stands on end, rising among the branches of the tree. His head is turned up and slightly left; he looks at his bleeding branch or perhaps the harpy perched above. A female spirit appears upside down in the tree second from the left. She is nude with her breasts exposed. Her long hair falls among the roots of the tree and her mouth may be open. The upper body of a female spirit appears in the tree third from the left. She is nude with her breasts exposed. The head of an indistinct spirit is visible in the tree furthest right. Three harpies sit perched on the upper branches of the anthropomorphized trees; they have the bodies of birds with female faces and breasts. The figures have long hair and beak-like noses. The central figure's wings are spread and her head is turned up; she wears a necklace or other cord tied around her neck.

desc.objtitle:
The Hell-Hounds Hunting the Destroyers of Their Own Goods,
Object 26 (Butlin 812.25)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "78" bottom right, "No 14 next at p 68" bottom center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 8" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. Yellow wash in the center of the design suggests grass. The trunks of four trees are visible in the foreground at the left and right borders of the design. The trunks divide into several leafy branches and a leafy vine or other vegetation appears on the trees to the left. Additional trees appear across the design in the distance. White space in the upper half of the design suggests a cloud-filled sky. A nude male with short hair kneels in the lower left corner of the design; he likely represents Giacomo da Sant' Andrea. He is seen from behind and faces left with his head turned over his left shoulder. His expression suggests fear. Giacomo's right leg extends backward and he likely crawls or flees from the dogs pictured to the right. Both arms are bent upward and Giacomo grasps or touches the trunk of a tree. A nude male with long hair stands in the left portion of the design; he likely represents Lano da Siena. The figure's genitals are clearly visible. His right leg is bent with the right foot raised on tiptoe. He leans or bends to the right and he may flee from the dogs pictured below. Lano's right arm is bent upward and wraps around his head; the palm of his right hand is turned down. His left arm is raised horizontally with his left palm held vertically. Lano's eyes are cast down and he looks at the dogs; his expression suggests fear. Three dogs with spiky fur appear in the lower half of the design. The dogs run to the left, pursuing the fleeing figures. The dog furthest left bites the right buttock of Giacomo da Sant' Andrea. The other dogs' mouths are open with their teeth and tongues visible. Two harpies perch in the trees in the upper corners of the design; they have the bodies of birds with female faces and breasts. The figures have long hair and beak-like noses. Their wings are folded at the sides and their talons clutch the tree branches. They may be smiling. The harpy to the left tilts her head down slightly; her eyes are cast down and she looks at the figures below.

desc.objtitle:
The Blasphemers with the Usurers and the Sodomites,
Object 28 (Butlin 812.26)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "85" top left, "Hell Canto 18" along the right margin, and an erased inscription, probably repeating the inscription on the right margin, in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. Fire appears throughout the design, raining down from a dark cloud at the upper border. Two gowned males with long hair stand at the right border of the design. The figure to the left represents Dante. He faces forward with his head turned to the left. Dante's left arm is down at his side with the palm of his left hand turned down. His right arm is bent upward with the palm of his right hand turned up slightly. The figure to the right represents Virgil. He faces left in profile and is largely obscured by Dante. Four nude figures stand among flames in the right half of the design; they represent the sodomites. The figure furthest left is female and has long hair. Her left leg is bent with the left foot raised on tiptoe. Her right leg extends to the left and she runs to the right; she is likely fleeing from the fiery rain. Her right arm is bent upwards and her left arm is raised vertically. The palms of both hands are turned upward. Her mouth is open and her expression suggests fear. Only the buttocks and legs of the figure second from the left are visible; the figure strides to the right and his or her left foot is raised on tiptoe. A male with short, curly hair appears third from the left. He faces forward and his genitals are covered by flames. The figure's right leg is bent and his left foot is raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent upward; his left palm is turned up and his right palm is held vertically. The figure's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or pain. The figure furthest right is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. The figure strides to the right with his or her right leg bent and the left foot raised on tiptoe. Four gowned figures sit among flames in the lower left portion of the design; they represent the usurers. At least two of the figures sit with their legs bent and drawn up. The figure third from the left sits with his or her legs crossed at the ankles. Both arms are bent upward and his or her hands are held together in prayer or supplication. The figure furthest right bends his or her left arm upward with the palm held vertically. At least two of the figures mouths are open; their expressions suggest fear or despair. At least four figures lie among flames in the lower left corner of the design; they represent the blasphemers. The nude figure in the foreground lies prone with his or her body extended horizontally across the design. Above, a figure raises his or her head slightly. Two other figures lie supine to the right; both figures are lightly sketched with only their upper bodies clearly visible. There may be the face of a fifth figure in the flames far left.

A male with short, curly hair appears third from the left. He faces forward and his genitals are covered by flames. The figure's right leg is bent and his left foot is raised on tiptoe. Both arms are bent upward; his left palm is turned up and his right palm is held vertically. The figure's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or pain. The figure furthest right is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. The figure strides to the right with his or her right leg bent and the left foot raised on tiptoe.

Four gowned figures sit among flames in the lower left portion of the design; they represent the usurers. At least two of the figures sit with their legs bent and drawn up. The figure third from the left sits with his or her legs crossed at the ankles. Both arms are bent upward and his or her hands are held together in prayer or supplication. The figure furthest right bends his or her left arm upward with the palm held vertically. At least two of the figures mouths are open; their expressions suggest fear or despair.

At least four figures lie among flames in the lower left corner of the design; they represent the blasphemers. The nude figure in the foreground lies prone with his or her body extended horizontally across the design. Above, a figure raises his or her head slightly. Two other figures lie supine to the right; both figures are lightly sketched with only their upper bodies clearly visible. There may be the face of a fifth figure in the flames far left.

desc.objtitle:
Capaneus the Blasphemer,
Object 29 (Butlin 812.27)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "43" top right, "N 27 next at p 83" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "43 Hell Canto 17" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Flames rise throughout the design, particularly around a reclining figure. Fire and smoke rain down from the sky, particularly in the upper left. Four lightning bolts extend down from the upper border; three of them may strike the reclining figure. Green coloring at the lower border on the left indicates grass; yellow wash among the flames may suggest sand. Two gowned males representing Dante and Virgil stand at the left border of the design. Both figures have long hair. The figure to the left faces forward and slightly right. His right foot visible. His left arm is down and the palm of his left hand is turned down. The figure to the right faces right in profile and may look towards the reclining figure. The coloring of their gowns indicates that the figure on the left is Dante in red; the figure on the right is Virgil (blue). A nude male with short, curly hair reclines in the right portion of the design. He represents Capaneus, a blasphemer. The figure's body is surrounded by flames, creating a halo around his head. He faces forward with his legs extended to the left. His left leg is bent slightly. Capaneus' right arm is bent and rests against his thigh. His left arm is down and his left hand braces against the ground with the palm turned down.

The coloring of their gowns indicates that the figure on the left is Dante in red; the figure on the right is Virgil in blue.

He faces forward with his legs extended to the left. His left leg is bent slightly. Capaneus' right arm is bent and rests against his thigh. His left arm is down and his left hand braces against the ground with the palm turned down.

desc.objtitle:
The Symbolic Figure of the Course of Human History Described by Virgil The Course of Human History Personified,
Object 30 (Butlin 812.28 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "54" top right, "N 12 next at p 6" top center, with the "6" written over a partly erased "14," "No 12 next at p 14" in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 7" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene is set in hell. A nude male, perhaps a king, stands in the center of the design; he represents the personification of human history as described in canto 14 of the "Inferno." The figure has long, curly hair and he wears a spiked crown. Yellow coloring on the figure's head suggests gold. A halo of rose wash appears around his head. Tears flow from the figure's eyes and his expression suggests grief or despair. Water flows down the figures body and divides to the left and right by his feet; the poem indicates that this is the source of the rivers of Hell. The figure is partly nude; his groin is covered with scales, and he apparently wears armor on his forearms and shins. Red coloring on his right foot and shin suggests clay. The figure's left arm is bent and he holds a lightly sketched scepter decorated with a fleur-de-lis. His right arm is down at his side and he holds an orb decorated with a cross. A mountain representing Mt. Ida rises in the center of the design. Two lightly sketched figures recline on the mountain in the upper portion of the design. The figure to the right, possibly female, has long hair. The figure to the left, probably male, may have a beard; he apparently holds a dagger or sword. Two leafy trees appear to the left and right of the central figure. The trunks each divide into two distinct branches. Light green coloring below the tree on the left may indicate grass.

A nude male, perhaps a king, stands in the center of the design; he represents the personification of human history as described in canto 14 of the "Inferno." The figure has long, curly hair and he wears a spiked crown. Yellow coloring on the figure's head suggests gold. A halo of rose wash appears around his head. Tears flow from the figure's eyes and his expression suggests grief or despair. Water flows down the figures body and divides to the left and right by his feet; the poem indicates that this is the source of the rivers of Hell. The figure is partly nude; his groin is covered with scales, and he apparently wears armor on his forearms and shins. Red coloring on his right foot and shin suggests clay. The figure's left arm is bent and he holds a lightly sketched scepter decorated with a fleur-de-lis. His right arm is down at his side and he holds an orb decorated with a cross.
A mountain representing Mt. Ida rises above the figure in the center of the design.

Two lightly sketched figures recline on the mountain in the upper portion of the design. The figure to the right, possibly female, has long hair. The figure to the left, probably male, may have a beard; he apparently holds a dagger or sword.
Two leafy trees appear to the left and right of the central figure. The trunks each divide into two distinct branches. Light green coloring below the tree on the left may indicate grass.

lg.l: Hell Canto 14 Lines 1-2 are very faint and may have been partly erased. Our reading of the second word in each line is conjectural.

desc.objtitle:
The Punishment of Jacopo Rusticucci and His Companions Jacopo Rusticucci and His Companions,
Object 31 (Butlin 812.29)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "88" top right, and "Paradise Canto 27 v 25" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Two gowned figures with long hair stand on a grassy hill or mound near the left border. The figure to the left represents Virgil; he is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer with his head turned to the right. The figure to the right represents Dante; he faces right with his head turned down slightly. A single tear is visible below Dante's right eye and he may be frowning. He looks towards the figures to the right and his expression suggests grief. Three nude male figures fly or hover within a whirlwind of fire and smoke. They likely represent Jacopo Rusticucci, Guido Guerra, and Tegghiaio Aldobrandi. The figure in the lower left is seen from behind and twists away from the viewer. His head is turned up and to the left, and he looks towards Dante; his mouth is open and he may be speaking. Both legs are bent and the figure's left buttock is prominent. His right arm is bent upward with the palm turned out, away from the viewer. His left arm is raised vertically and the palm of his left hand is turned upward. The figure in the upper right faces forward with his head turned slightly to the left; he looks towards Dante and Virgil. The figure's right leg extends downward and his left leg is bent and drawn up. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees, and his left arm is raised at 135 degrees with the palm turned up. The figure in the lower right faces left and his eyes are raised. Both legs are bent and spread apart with the genitals visible. The figure may run to the left with his right foot raised on tiptoe. His right arm is bent upward with the palm of his right hand held vertically. His left arm is raised horizontally with the palm turned up.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell.
A grassy hill or mound appears in the lower left corner of the design.

Two gowned figures with long hair stand on a grassy hill or mound near the left border. The figure to the left represents Virgil; he is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer with his head turned to the right.

A single tear is visible below Dante's right eye and he may be frowning. He looks towards the figures to the right and his expression suggests grief.
A whirlwind appears in the right half of the design. Red and yellow wash indicates fire; grey and blue suggests smoke.

Three nude male figures fly or hover within a whirlwind of fire and smoke. They likely represent Jacopo Rusticucci, Guido Guerra, and Tegghiaio Aldobrandi. The individual figures cannot be identified specifically.

The figure in the lower right faces left and his eyes are raised. Both legs are bent and spread apart with the genitals visible. The figure may run to the left with his right foot raised on tiptoe. His right arm is bent upward with the palm of his right hand held vertically. His left arm is raised horizontally with the palm turned up.

l.note: The number, obscured by blue wash, is written on a diagonal rising from right to left.

desc.objtitle:
The Usurers,
Object 32 (Butlin 812.30)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Lightly sketched lines above four kneeling figures represents a rain of fire. A gowned male with long hair stands at the left border of the design; he likely represents Dante. The figure is lightly sketched. He is seen from behind and faces to the right. His right arm is bent with the right palm turned up. Four gowned males kneel in the lower right portion of the design; they represent usurers. The figure furthest left wears a crown and a beaded necklace with a cross. A purse, decorated with an indistinct design, hangs around his neck. His left hand rests on the purse; his forefinger is extended and he may point up and to the left. His right arm is bent upward and the fingers of his right hand are spread. His mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible. Red coloring at his mouth may represent a bloody or fiery tongue. The figure second from the left has long hair and a beard. He wears a crown and a purse hands around his neck; the purse is decorated with the image of a bird, perhaps a goose or duck. Both arms are bent upward. The palms of his hands are turned out, towards the viewer, with the fingers spread. The figure third from the left faces left in profile. He has a long beard and wears a crown. A purse hangs around his neck; an indistinct design appears on the purse. The figure's left arm is raised vertically and his right arm is bent upward. The palms of both hands are held vertically. The figure furthest right is lightly sketched; he is seen from behind and faces left in profile with both arms raised vertically.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. Lightly sketched lines above four kneeling figures represents a rain of fire.

A gowned male with long hair stands at the left border of the design; he likely represents Dante. The figure is lightly sketched. He is seen from behind and faces to the right. His right arm is bent with the right palm turned up.

Four gowned males kneel in the lower right portion of the design; they represent usurers. The figure furthest left wears a crown and a beaded necklace with a cross. A purse, decorated with an indistinct design, hangs around his neck. His left hand rests on the purse; his forefinger is extended and he may point up and to the left. His right arm is bent upward and the fingers of his right hand are spread. His mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible. Red coloring at his mouth may represent a fiery or bloody tongue.

He wears a crown and a purse hands around his neck; the purse is decorated with the image of a bird, perhaps a goose or duck. Both arms are bent upward. The palms of his hands are turned out, towards the viewer, with the fingers spread.

A purse hangs around his neck; an indistinct design appears on the purse. The figure's left arm is raised vertically and his right arm is bent upward. The palms of both hands are held vertically.

Four gowned males kneel in the lower right portion of the design; they represent the usurers. The figure furthest right is lightly sketched. He is seen from behind and faces left in profile. The figure has long hair. Both arms are raised vertically.

desc.objtitle:
Geryon Conveying Dante and Virgil Down Towards Malebolge Geryon Carries Dante and Virgil Towards Malebolge,
Object 33 (Butlin 812.31 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "44" top right, "N 17 next at p 84" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 10" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A mountain is visible in the upper right corner; two small hills appear in the lower left. Fire rises along the lower border of the design. Blue wash in the upper half represents sky; white clouds appear in the upper left, and dark clouds or smoke rise above the mountain in the upper right. The monster Geryon flies or hovers in the center of the design. The figure has the head and chest of a human male, with the body of a serpent, a scorpion-like stinger, and two lion-like claws. The figure has long hair. Scales are visible along the length of Geryon's body, and his tail forms a single loop. Two gowned males with long hair appear on Geryon's left shoulder; they represent Virgil and Dante. The figure to the left sits with his right leg bent and his right hand resting on his knee. The coloring of his gown indicates that this is Dante. His left arm is apparently bent and he may hold hands with the figure to the right. The figure to the right kneels and faces left in profile. The coloring of his gown indicates that this is Virgil. His right arm is down and he braces against Geryon's shoulder with the palm turned down. At least three figures run or stride to the left along the hills in the lower left portion of the design; they may be fleeing Geryon or perhaps flee from the fire. One figure is female; her torso twists forward with breasts clearly visible. As many as four additional, lightly sketched figures may appear further left.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A mountain is visible in the upper right corner; two small hills appear in the lower left. Fire rises along the lower border of the design. Blue wash in the upper half represents sky; white clouds appear in the upper left, and dark clouds or smoke rise above the mountain in the upper right.

The monster Geryon flies or hovers in the center of the design. The figure has the head and chest of a human male, with the body of a serpent, a scorpion-like stinger, and two lion-like claws. The figure has long hair. Scales are visible along the length of Geryon's body, and his tail forms a single loop.

Two gowned males with long hair appear on Geryon's left shoulder; they represent Virgil and Dante. The figure to the left sits with his right leg bent and his right hand resting on his knee. His left arm is apparently bent and he may hold hands with the figure to the right. The figure to the right kneels and faces left in profile. His right arm is down and he braces against Geryon's shoulder with the palm turned down. The coloring of their gowns indicates that the figure on the left is Dante; the figure on the left is Virgil.

At least three figures run or stride to the left along the hills in the lower left portion of the design; they may be fleeing Geryon or perhaps flee from the fire. One figure is female; her torso twists forward with breasts clearly visible. As many as four additional, lightly sketched figures may appear further left.

desc.objtitle:
Demons Tormenting the Panders and Seducers in Malebolge Demons Tormenting the Pimps and Seducers in Malebolge,
Object 34 (Butlin 812.32)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "84" top left, "N18 next at p 55" just below the top margin, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Minotaur. Hell Canto 12" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A broken wall or other stone structure stands in the lower left portion. A chain connects to a wheel(?) or toothed gear to the left of the wall. A steep cliff rises above. A body of water, perhaps a fiery lake or river, is visible in the lower right. Two arches, perhaps the circles of hell, rise above the water. Blue, purple, and yellow coloring represents sky. Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower left portion of the design; they represent Dante and Virgil. Both figures' arms are bent with the palms apparently held vertically. The figure to the left (Dante) faces right, while the figure to the right (Virgil) faces forward. A male figure lies supine in the lower left portion of the design; his body extends horizontally with his head to the right. He wears a helmet and may represent a soldier. The figure's eyes are closed and he may be dead. His left arm is at his side with the hand resting on the ground; there may be a shackle on the figure's wrist. A demon crouches over the corpse of a soldier in the lower portion of the design. The demon has bat-like wings and its right leg is bent at extreme angles. Some of its characteristics, such as the right leg, suggest an insect such as a grasshopper. Its head is down against the soldier's throat. Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. Three horned male demons with bat-like wings fly in the right half of the design. Two of the demons have serpent-like tails, and all three hold whips or switches. The central demon holds the wrist of one of the seducers below. Two groups of lightly sketched figures appear on the arched structures in the upper portion of the design. As many as seven figures, perhaps seducers, stand on the leftmost arch; they may run or flee to the left. A figure, likely a demon, flies or hovers above; the figure's right arm is raised horizontally and he or she holds a whip. The figure(s) on the rightmost arch, perhaps seducers, may lay or crawl on the ground. Two demons with serpent-like tails fly or hover above; each holds a handle of a whip or stick in his or her right hand.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A broken wall or other stone structure stands in the lower left portion. A chain connects to a wheel(?) or toothed gear to the left of the wall. A steep cliff rises above. A body of water, perhaps a fiery lake or river, is visible in the lower right. Two arches, perhaps the circles of hell, rise above the water. Blue, purple, and yellow coloring represents sky.

Two gowned males with long hair stand in the lower left portion of the design; they represent Dante and Virgil. Both figures' arms are bent with the palms apparently held vertically. The figure to the left faces right, while the figure to the right faces forward. The coloring of their gowns indicates that the figure on the left is Dante; the figure on the right is Virgil.

A male figure lies supine in the lower left portion of the design; his body extends horizontally with his head to the right. He wears a helmet and may represent a soldier. The figure's eyes are closed and he may be dead. His left arm is at his side with the hand resting on the ground; there may be a shackle on the figure's wrist.

A demon crouches over the corpse of a soldier in the lower portion of the design. The demon has bat-like wings and its right leg is bent at extreme angles. Some of the beast's characteristics, such as the right leg, suggest an insect such as a grasshopper. Its head is down against the soldier's throat.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The uppermost figure kneels or crouches at the edge of the cliff; he or she crawls to the left.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The figure second from the top stands just below the edge of the cliff with his or her left arm bent and right arm raised horizontally; the figure may be climbing. The figure faces forward with his or her head turned to the right.
