Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The figure third from the top may be female; she is seen from behind and the curve of her left breast is visible. She stands or leans against the cliff with her left arm bent upward and her right leg dangling below; she may be climbing.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The figure fourth from the top is female; her breasts are visible and she has long hair. She runs or leaps to the left with both legs bent and her right leg drawn up. Her left arm is raised horizontally and she reaches towards the cliff. The figure faces left with her head turned to the right; her mouth is open and her expression may suggest surprise or fear.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The figure fifth from the top (male?) stands at the bottom of the wall and likely climbs upward with his right leg bent and drawn up. His upper body is twisted away from the viewer and the figure's head is bent back. Both arms are raised 135 degrees and the palms of his hands are turned up.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The figure sixth from the top is apparently female. She may have long hair; alternately, the wavy line at the figure's right size may represent a serpent, worm, vine, or a trail of fire. She stands with both legs bent. Her right arm is raised horizontally with the palm held vertically; her left arm is bent upward and the demon above holds her left wrist. The figure's head is turned up and she looks towards the demon.

Seven nude figures appear along the cliff in the upper left down to the shore in the lower right; the figures likely represent the seducers. They flee from the demons flying above. The lowest figure is seen from behind with the buttocks prominent. The figure may have long hair; alternately, the wavy line at the figure's left size may represent a serpent, worm, vine, or a trail of fire. The figure stands with his or her legs bent and the right foot raised on tiptoe; the figure walks or strides to the left. Both arms are raised at 135 degrees with at least the right palm turned up. The figure's head rests on his or her right shoulder.

Three male demons with bat-like wings fly in the right half of the design. The leftmost demon has curved horns. He flies to the left with his body horizontal and his legs extended up and to the right. Both arms are raised at 45 degrees with respect to his body and he holds a whip or switch in his right hand.

Three horned male demons with bat-like wings fly in the right half of the design. The demon second from the left has a serpent-like tail. He flies down and to the left with his upper body turned forward. His left arm is bent and he holds the wrist of the figure below. The demon's right arm is bent upward and he holds the handle of a whip or stick in his right hand.

Three horned male demons with bat-like wings fly in the right half of the design. The demon furthest right faces left with his body horizontal. His serpent-like tail forms a single loop. His left arm is held at his side and his right arm is bent upward; he holds the handle of a whip or stick in his right hand.

Two groups of lightly sketched figures appear on the arched structures in the upper portion of the design. As many as seven figures, probably seducers, stand on the leftmost arch; they may run or flee to the left. A figure, likely a demon, flies or hovers above; the figure's right arm is raised horizontally and he or she holds a whip. The figure(s) on the rightmost arch, perhaps seducers, may lay or crawl on the ground. Two demons with serpent-like tails fly or hover above; each holds a handle of a whip or stick in his or her right hands.

lg.l:
HELL
Lines 1-2 are inscribed on the wall just below the center of the design.

desc.objtitle:
Dante and Virgil Gazing into the Ditch of the Flatterers Dante and Virgil Looking into the Ditch of the Flatterers,
Object 35 (Butlin 812.33)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "13" top right, "N6 next at p 15" below the top margin, and "Hell Canto 4" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A dark river or lake of excrement appears at the lower border. Two hills or mountains rise above. The sky at the upper border is a dark purple in the upper left and a light rose in the upper right. A dark cloud extends across the center of the design; fire rains down from the left portion of the cloud. Two gowned males with long hair kneel or crouch on a hill in the upper right corner of the design; they represent Virgil and Dante. Both figures hold the fabric of their gowns up to cover their noses. Dante (right) and Virgil (left) both look towards the figures below with their eyes cast down. The figure to the left gestures downward with the palm of his left hand turned out towards the viewer and the fingers slightly spread. The figure to the right rests his right hand on his knee. This right leg is bent and drawn up with the right foot visible. The upper body of a male figure rises above the river or lake of excrement in the lower left portion of the design. He likely represents Alessio Interminei, one of the flatterers. Alessio's hair is curly. His eyes are raised and he looks towards Dante and Virgil, above. His mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible and he may be speaking. Both arms are bent upward and his hands clutch at his head. A nude female with long hair begins to crouch, bending left and forward, in the river or lake of excrement in the lower right portion of the design; only her feet are submerged, and her left foot is apparently raised on tiptoe. The figure likely represents Thas, one of the flatterers. She wears a crown or wreath of beads in her long hair. The figure faces forward with her breasts exposed. Her head is turned up and her eyes are raised; she looks towards Dante and Virgil above. Thas' right arm is raised at 45 degrees. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm of her left hand turned up. The heads of five figures appear in the river or lake of excrement in the lower half of the design; the figures are likely male and they represent the flatterers. Four figures to the left of Alessio Interminei have short, curly hair. Flames appear above two of the figures' heads; one figure's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or pain. Another figure's head is turned up and to the left in profile; his mouth is slightly open and his eyes may be closed. A figure to the right of Alessio has long hair and a beard. The arms of a sixth figure rise vertically above the river of lake; the palms are turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread. A nude figure, possibly female, with long hair flies, hovers, or perhaps runs along a hill in the upper left portion of the design. The figure's right leg is bent and drawn up; his or her left leg extends backward. The figure's left arm is raised at 135 degrees and the fingers of the figure's left hand are spread. The right arm is bent and wraps around the figure's head with his or her right palm held vertically. The figure faces left with his or her head turned to the right; the figure's mouth is open and his or her expression suggests fear. The figure may represent a seducer from the previous design, fleeing from the demon to the right. A nude female, likely a demon, flies or hovers in the upper portion of the design; she pursues the figure fleeing to the left. The demon has long, curly hair, and has two coiled horns rising from her forehead. Her head is upside down. She is seen from behind with her buttocks prominent. The figure's body is positioned horizontally and her upper body is twisted slightly; her right breast is visible. Both legs are bent and the soles of her feet are turned out towards the viewer. Her right arm is bent and she holds the handle of a whip in her right hand.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A dark river or lake of excrement appears at the lower border. Two hills or mountains rise above. The sky at the upper border is a dark purple in the upper left and a light rose in the upper right. A dark cloud extends across the center of the design; fire rains down from the left portion of the cloud.

Two gowned males with long hair kneel or crouch on a hill in the upper right corner of the design; they represent Virgil and Dante. Both figures hold the fabric of their gowns up to cover their noses. Dante and Virgil both looks towards the figures below with their eyes cast down. The figure to the left gestures downward with the palm of his left hand turned out towards the viewer and the fingers slightly spread. The figure to the right rests his right hand on his knee. His right leg is bent and drawn up with the right foot visible. The color of their gowns indicate that Virgil is the figure on the left; Dante is on the right.

The upper body of a male figure rises above the river or lake of excrement in the lower left portion of the design. He likely represents Alessio Interminei, one of the flatterers. Alessio's hair is curly. His eyes are raised and he looks towards Dante and Virgil, above. His mouth is open with the upper row of teeth visible and he may be speaking. Both arms are bent upward and his hands clutch at his head.

A nude female with long hair begins to crouch, bending left and forward, in the river or lake of excrement in the lower right portion of the design; only her feet are submerged, and her left foot is apparently raised on tiptoe. The figure likely represents Thas, one of the flatterers. She wears a crown or wreath of beads in her long hair. The figure faces forward with her breasts exposed. Her head is turned up and her eyes are raised; she looks towards Dante and Virgil above. Thas' right arm is raised at 45 degrees. Her left arm is bent upward with the palm of her left hand turned up.

The heads of five figures appear in the river or lake of excrement in the lower half of the design; the figures are likely male and they represent the flatterers. Four figures to the left of Alessio Interminei have short, curly hair. Flames appear above two of the figures' heads; one figure's mouth is open and his expression suggests fear or pain. Another figure's head is turned up and to the left in profile; his mouth is slightly open and his eyes may be closed. A figure to the right of Alessio has long hair and a beard. The arms of a sixth figure rise vertically above the river of lake; the palms are turned out towards the viewer with the fingers spread.

A nude figure, possibly female, with long hair flies, hovers, or perhaps runs along a hill in the upper left portion of the design. The figure's right leg is bent and drawn up; his or her left leg extends backward. The figure's left arm is raised at 135 degrees and the fingers of the figure's left hand are spread. The right arm is bent and wraps around the figure's head with his or her right palm held vertically. The figure faces left with his or her head turned to the right; the figure's mouth is open and his or her expression suggests fear. The figure may represent a seducer from the previous design, fleeing from the demon to the right.

A nude female, likely a demon, flies or hovers in the upper portion of the design; she pursues the figure fleeing to the left. The demon has long, curly hair, and has two coiled horns rising from her forehead. Her head is upside down. She is seen from behind with her buttocks prominent. The figure's body is positioned horizontally and her upper body is twisted slightly; her right breast is visible. Both legs are bent and the soles of her feet are turned out towards the viewer. Her right arm is bent and she holds the handle of a whip in her right hand.

lg.l: Hell Canto 18 This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle:
The Simoniac Pope,
Object 36 (Butlin 812.35)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "8" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in the Eighth Circle of Hell, where the simoniac popes are inserted one after another into a well of fire. The well appears in the lower half of the design, with tongues of flame rising from its opening. The well is at least partly transparent. Pope Nicholas III appears upside down within the well. He is nude. Seen from behind, he faces away but bends to the left at the waist and turns his head to look up. His mouth is open as if he is speaking. Both of his arms are bent out from his body, with palms facing out and fingers spread. His legs extend from the top of the well. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet face out toward the viewer. Tongues of flame leap from inside the well and from his feet. He has short hair. Virgil kneels at or strides through the mouth of a cave in the upper portion of the design. His left leg is bent forward and his bent right leg is extended backward, with the right foot resting on tiptoe. He is gowned and has long hair. Virgil embraces or holds Dante, bending and leaning forward and to the right with his head turned down slightly. Virgil's arms are down and bent around the torso of Dante. Virgil's mouth is slightly open. Dante is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer with his head bent back and turned to the right. Dante is gowned and his hair is long and curly. His mouth is slightly open. Dante's lower body is not clearly pictured. His right arm may be raised and wrapped around Virgil's head. The pair approaches the well through the mouth of a cave. Its craggy walls fill much of the left and right sides of the design. Light and shadow seem to flicker on these rocky surfaces, as if from the flames in the well. Clouds (or cloud-like rocks) appear below the well, adding to the unearthly appearance of the scene. Flames and perhaps clouds of smoke appear in the distance to either side of Dante and Virgil. Vaguely defined shapes on either side also suggest distant rocky outcroppings or distant hills. There may be some vegetation on the side of the cave right of Virgil's head.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in the Eighth Circle of Hell, where the simoniac popes are inserted one after another into a well of fire. The well appears in the lower half of the design, with tongues of flame rising from its opening. The well is at least partly transparent.

The simoniac Pope Nicholas III (Gian Gaetani degli Orsini) appears upside down within the transparent walls of a well of fire, which is located in the lower half of the design. He is nude. Seen from behind, he faces away but bends to the left at the waist and turns his head to look up. His mouth is open as if he is speaking. Both of his arms are bent out from his body, with palms facing out and fingers spread. His legs extend from the top of the well. Both legs are bent and the soles of his feet face out toward the viewer. Tongues of flame leap from inside the well and from his feet. He has short hair.

Virgil kneels at or strides through the mouth of a cave in the upper portion of the design. His left leg is bent forward and his bent right leg is extended backward, with the right foot resting on tiptoe. He is gowned and has long hair. Virgil embraces or holds Dante, bending and leaning forward and to the right with his head turned down slightly. Virgil's arms are down and bent around the torso of Dante. Virgil's mouth is slightly open.

Virgil carries Dante in the upper portion of the design. Dante is seen from behind and faces away from the viewer with his head bent back and turned to the right. Dante is gowned and his hair is long and curly. His mouth is slightly open. Dante's lower body is not clearly pictured. His right arm may be raised and wrapped around Virgil's head.

Virgil and Dante approach the partly transparent well through the mouth of a cave. The craggy walls of the cave fill much of the left and right borders of the design. Light and shadow seem to flicker on these rocky surfaces, as if from the flames in the well. Clouds (or cloud-like rocks) appear below the well, adding to the unearthly appearance of the scene. Flames and perhaps clouds of smoke are visible in the distance to either side of Dante and Virgil. Vaguely defined shapes on either side also suggest distant rocky outcroppings or hills.
There may be a bit of vegetation, perhaps a plant with leaves or lichens, on the side of the cave right of Virgil's head.

desc.objtitle:
The Necromancers and Augers The Necromancers,
Object 37 (Butlin 812.36)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "65" top right, and "N 61, last in the Inferno unless...Dante lifted by Virgil..." in the center of the sheet, partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in Hell. A cloud billows behind the figures of the four necromancers, beneath a rocky bridge. Wash beyond the cloud below the bridge, as well as surrounding Dante and Virgil at the top of the design, suggests the sky at sunrise or sunset. The four figures at the bottom of the design walk in single file across bare earth or floor. These represent the Necromancers and Augurs punished in the fourth trench of the Eighth Circle. Their lower bodies face away and to the left, but their heads have been turned to face forward and to the right. The figures step carefully backwards, to the right. The leftmost figure is a man who raises his arms up to the left at 135 degrees, palms out. He steps backwards with his bent right leg; his bent left leg is slightly forward of his body. He is bald but bearded. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised. The female figure second to left is Manto, stepping behind her with her bent left leg on tiptoe. Her left arm is down and bent across her chest, while her bent right arm is raised at not quite 135 degrees. The palms of both open hands face out. Manto has long, curly hair and wears a small beribboned hat. Her mouth may be slightly open. She bends backward at the waist. Third from left walks a male figure bending forward slightly with his left arm down by his side, palm down. His right arm is raised vertically and bent, with palm out. His thick long hair and full beard cover much of his upper body. His right foot, clad in a sandal, is visible beneath the hem of his gown. The fourth figure bends backward slightly and tilts his head down. He has long hair and a long beard. All three males seem to be old. Above them, a rock bridge arches across the top of the design. Dante and Virgil, depicted roughly in pencil sketches, sit together on the bridge. On the left, Virgil seems to lean to the left with his bent right elbow braced on an outcropping of the bridge. His bent legs seem to be drawn up to the right, and he rests his bent left arm on his knees. Though he faces forward and leans left, he turns and bends his head to the right, towards Dante. Dante sits or kneels facing forward and left, with his bent right leg drawn up and his left seemingly extended down to the right. His left arm is down between his legs, and his left hand rests on the rock bridge. His right arm is bent up and supported partially by his right leg. He props his chin on his right hand, which may in turn rest on his right knee. Both figures have long hair and seem to be clad in robes.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in Hell. A cloud billows behind the figures of the four necromancers, beneath the bridge. Wash beyond the cloud below the bridge, as well as surrounding Dante and Virgil at the top of the design, suggests the sky at sunrise or sunset.
The four figures at the bottom of the design walk across bare earth or floor.

Dante and Virgil, depicted roughly in pencil sketches, sit together on a rock bridge that spans the top of the design. On the left, Virgil seems to lean to the left with his bent right elbow braced on an outcropping of the bridge. His bent legs seem to be drawn up to the right, and he rests his bent left arm on his knees. Though he faces forward and leans left, he turns and bends his head to the right, towards Dante. Dante sits or kneels facing forward and left, with his bent right leg drawn up and his left seemingly extended down to the right. His left arm is down between his legs, and his left hand rests on the rock bridge. His right arm is bent up and supported partially by his right leg. He props his chin on his right hand, which may in turn rest on his right knee. Both figures have long hair and seem to be clad in robes.
A rocky bridge arches across the top of the design. Shadows appear above and below the bridge on its rocky surfaces.

Four figures wearing transparent or partly transparent gowns walk in single file across the lower border of the design. These represent the Necromancers and Augurs punished in the fourth trench of the Eighth Circle. Their lower bodies face away and to the left, but their heads have been turned to face forward and to the right. The figures step carefully backwards, to the right. The leftmost figure is a man who raises his arms up to the left at 135 degrees, palms out. He steps backwards with his bent right leg; his bent left leg is slightly forward of his body. He is bald but bearded. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised. The female figure second to left is Manto, stepping behind her with her bent left leg on tiptoe. Her left arm is down and bent across her chest, while her bent right arm is raised at not quite 135 degrees. The palms of both open hands face out. Manto has long, curly hair and wears a small beribboned hat. Her mouth may be slightly open. She bends backward at the waist. Third from left walks a male figure bending forward slightly with his left arm down by his side, palm down. His right arm is raised vertically and bent, with palm out. His thick long hair and full beard cover much of his upper body. His right foot, clad in a sandal, is visible beneath the hem of his gown. The fourth figure bends backward slightly and tilts his head down. He has long hair and a long beard. All three males seem to be old.

lg.l:
Hell Canto 20
This inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle:
The Devil Carrying the Lucchese Magistrate to the Boiling Pitch Pool of Corrupt Officials A Devil Carrying the Lucchese Peculator to the Lake of Boiling Pitch,
Object 38 (Butlin 812.37)

objnote.p: The lower left corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "68" top right, "No 15 next at p 10" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 8" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A boiling pool of pitch stretches across the bottom of the design. Rocky ledges of varying heights form the bank of the pitch pool. A demon crouches on the highest ledge near the top of the design, holding a sinner on his shoulders. Facing forward and slightly left, the demon's bent right leg is drawn forward, his bent left leg extended backward. His head is down. Both feet seem to be on tiptoe, and his toes also suggest claws. He bends forward sharply at the waist beneath the weight of the figure on his shoulders, who represents a peculator (embezzler) from Lucca. The demon's bat-like wings are spread wide on either side of his body, and he lifts his bent arms overhead to grasp the sinner with both hands. The muscular demon is nude with visible genitals, and has short curly hair. The peculator on his back kneels facing right, bent forward at the waist so that his torso rests on his thighs in a contracted posture. His head is down. He is sketchily drawn in pencil, with only a few lines inked, but he seems to hold his right arm along his lap. He may be nude, and he has short curly hair. Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side near the left side of the design, on a slightly lower ledge. They face forward. Sketched lightly in pencil, with a few inked lines, the figures' identities are difficult to distinguish. The one on the right stands slightly forward of the other, with his weight resting on his left leg and his right leg slightly bent. His left arm is bent across his torso and his right seems to be down by his side, though it may be bent upward at the elbow. The figure on the left has his right arm by his side. His left leg may be bent forward slightly. Both figures turn their heads slightly to the right. They have long hair and wear gowns. Two additional demons sit on a low ledge near the lower right corner. The demon on the right faces forward with his bent right leg drawn up and his bent left leg down. His right arm is down and bent across his chest at the elbow; his right finger is raised in a pointing gesture. He leans down to the left and may prop his right elbow against the demon to the left. His right hand may also rest on his right knee. His left arm is visible only at the shoulder. He bends his head back sharply, smiling slightly, and looks up to the left at the demon above who casts the peculator back into the pool. Only the upper body and perhaps the knees of the demon on the left are visible beyond the demon on the right. This leftmost demon faces forward but turns his head to the right. His right arm is raised and bent up at the elbow, and he grasps a large spear or spike with a hook in this hand. His bent knees may be visible to the left of the elbow of the demon on the right. Both demons are nude and have short curly hair. The points of their folded bat-like wings rise above their heads. Tusks grow from the face of the demon on the left, who turns his head slightly right. The genitals of the one on the right are visible. Blake has sketched in pencil additional raised hooks above the demons' wings. Wash surrounding the figures in the upper half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. A boiling pool of pitch stretches across the bottom of the design. Rocky ledges of varying heights form the bank of the pitch pool.

A demon crouches on the highest ledge near the top of the design, holding a sinner on his shoulders. Facing forward and slightly left, the demon's bent right leg is drawn forward, his bent left leg extended backward. His head is down. Both feet seem to be on tiptoe, and his toes also suggest claws. He bends forward sharply at the waist beneath the weight of the figure on his shoulders, who represents a peculator (embezzler) from Lucca. The demon's bat-like wings are spread wide on either side of his body, and he lifts his bent arms overhead to grasp the sinner with both hands. The demon's position suggests that he is about to toss the sinner into the boiling pitch below. The muscular demon is nude with visible genitals, and has short curly hair. The peculator on his back kneels facing right, bent forward at the waist so that his torso rests on his thighs in a contracted posture. His head is down. He is sketchily drawn in pencil, with only a few lines inked, but he seems to hold his right arm along his lap. He may be nude, and he has short curly hair.

Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side near the left side of the design, on a slightly lower ledge. They face forward. Sketched lightly in pencil, with a few inked lines, the figures' identities are difficult to distinguish. The figure to the right stands slightly forward of his companion, with his right leg slightly bent. His left arm is bent across his torso and his right seems to be down by his side, though it may be bent upward at the elbow. The figure to the left has his right arm by his side. His left leg may be bent forward slightly. Both figures turn their heads slightly to the right. Both have long hair and wear gowns.

Two additional demons sit on a low ledge near the lower right corner. The demon on the right faces forward with his bent right leg drawn up and his bent left leg down. His right arm is down and bent across his chest at the elbow; his right finger is raised in a pointing gesture. He leans to the left and may prop his right elbow against the demon to the left. His right hand may also rest on his right knee. His left arm is visible only at the shoulder. He bends his head back sharply, smiling slightly, and looks up to the left at the demon above who casts the peculator into the pool. Only the upper body and perhaps the knees of the demon on the left are visible beyond the demon on the right. This leftmost demon faces forward but turns his head to the right. His right arm is raised and bent up at the elbow, and he grasps a large spear or spike with a hook in this hand. His bent knees may be visible to the left of the elbow of the demon on the right. Both demons are nude and have short, curly hair. The points of their folded bat-like wings rise above their heads. Tusks grow from the face of the demon on the left, who turns his head slightly right. The genitals of the one on the right are visible. Blake has sketched in pencil additional raised hooks above the demons' wings.
Wash surrounding the figures in the upper half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
The Devils Under the Bridge,
Object 39 (Butlin 812.34)

objnote.p: The lower right corner of the design bears the collection stamp of the National Gallery of Victoria. Inscribed on the verso, "82 N 30 next at p 64" top center, the same partly erased from the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
The scene takes place in hell. The lake of boiling pitch from the previous design extends across the bottom of the design. Near its far shore, just below the left side of the bridge in the distance, tongues of fire burn on the tar. The near bank, along the bottom of the design, is bare earth. The far bank, visible only at the left edge of the design, seems similarly bare. A wavering line above the heads of Dante and Virgil on the left and the leftmost seducers suggest a higher ledge or crag. Wash in the upper two-thirds of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset. On the horizon beneath the far bridge appear faintly delineated shapes that may be the heads and shoulders of sinners punished by insertion in the lake. Jagged lines above their heads suggest steam or smoke. The peculator (embezzler) from the previous design appears immersed in the lake of boiling pitch. He is visible from the shoulders up, facing left. His left arm reaches out horizontally near the surface of the tar. He bends his head back and turns it forward, his eyes raised and his mouth open in pain. His right arm is raised vertically and bent over his head. A group of demons standing on the near shore of the lake, in the lower right corner of the design, harass the peculator. The leftmost demon faces away, but turns his head left. He strides or lunges with his left leg extended back and to the left, and his right leg bent forward to the right. His left foot is on tiptoe; it casts a small shadow on the ground below. He holds his arms out horizontally and bends forward towards the peculator on the left. With his left hand he holds the haft of a hook that he uses to prod the peculator in the lake. His right hand may hold the buttocks of the demon to the right. His spiky, bat-like wings are spread wide. The three demons to the right are sketched in pencil standing shoulder-to-shoulder. The leftmost of the three may be female. She faces away and twists her head and torso slightly to the right. She stands with her right leg bent across in front of her left, her right foot on tiptoe. Her wings are folded backwards. Her hair may be short and curly, or may be drawn up into a bun. The middle demon rests his weight largely on his right leg and crosses his bent left leg over the right, with left foot on tiptoe. His left arm is draped over the shoulders of the rightmost demon. He turns his head partly to the left and seems to hold his mouth open and his eyes raised. He has short curly hair. The spikes of his bat-like wings appear over his head. The rightmost demon also faces forward, but turns his head to look left. His mouth may be open. He stands with right leg straight and left leg bent forward slightly. His left arm is bent upward at the elbow and he grasps the haft of a hook with this hand. He has short curly hair as well. Fainter pencil lines above his head suggest his wings. All three standing demons are nude, though a sort of breechcloth of scales covers the rightmost demon's genitals.
A stone bridge arches up from the lower left foreground and crosses the top of the design to descend along the right ledge. Within the bridge or arch, large human shapes are visible, including a face with long hair and beard, an ear, two feet, and perhaps a muscled abdomen or breasts. The lightly penciled shape of a small, seated female figure above the ear may represent a petrified spirit. This figure faces forward and is mainly visible as a head and upper body, with the faint suggestion of bent legs to the left.
A second stone bridge or arch is visible in the distance, through the arch in the foreground. Blake has lightly sketched several groups of human figures running across this distant bridge. They are probably the seducers. Near the left side of the bridge, two figures run together. The figure on the right, higher on the bridge, faces forward with arms spread roughly horizontally. This figure's left leg is bent forward; its right leg is extended backward. It seems to turn its head back to look at the figure behind. This second figure is less clearly defined, but seems to face right and step forward with one leg and extend the other leg backwards. Near the top of the arch a second group of figures runs facing right. One crawls along the ground on hands and knees, with its body horizontal. Its left leg is drawn up and its right leg is extended backwards. To the right of the crawling figure, another leaps with right leg extended backwards and left leg bent and drawn up. This figure leans forward sharply and curls its right arm up around its head. Two more figures appear on the bridge to the right of the leaping figure. Both of these figures run facing right with one leg forward and one leg extended backwards. They lean forward. The one on the left may raise its arms. Just to the right of these figures, additional sketched lines may represent additional figures, or perhaps shadows. Three demons fly above these tiny figures, chasing them. The demons are sketched lightly in pencil and their shapes are indistinct, but they seem to fly shoulder to shoulder facing forward with their heads bent back and their bodies stretched horizontally to the left. They each raise one or both bent arms overhead, brandishing large whips. Dante and Virgil stand side by side on the distant bank of the pitch lake, next to the design's left edge. They seem to face forward and to wear long gowns. Their figures, sketched faintly in pencil, are otherwise difficult to discern.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. The lake of boiling pitch from the previous design extends across the bottom of the design. Near its far shore, just below the left side of the bridge in the distance, tongues of fire burn on the tar. On the horizon beneath the far bridge appear faintly delineated shapes that may be the heads and shoulders of sinners punished by insertion in the lake. Jagged lines above their heads suggest steam or smoke.

The peculator (embezzler) from the previous design appears immersed in the lake of boiling pitch. He is visible from the shoulders up, facing left. His left arm reaches out horizontally near the surface of the tar. He bends his head back and turns it forward, his eyes raised and his mouth open in pain. His right arm is raised vertically and bent over his head. He may be nude, or is perhaps wearing a shirt. His hair appears to be long and curly.

A group of demons standing on the near shore of the lake, in the lower right corner of the design, harass the peculator. The leftmost demon faces away, but turns his head left. He strides or lunges with his left leg extended back and to the left, and his right leg bent forward to the right. His left foot is on tiptoe; it casts a small shadow on the ground below. He holds his arms out horizontally and bends forward towards the peculator on the left. With his left hand he holds the haft of a hook that he uses to prod the peculator in the lake. His right hand may hold the buttocks of the demon to the right. He is nude and has short, curly hair. His spiky, bat-like wings are spread wide. The three demons to the right are sketched in pencil standing shoulder-to-shoulder. The leftmost of the three may be female. She faces away and twists her head and torso slightly to the right. She stands with her right leg bent across in front of her left, her right foot on tiptoe. Her wings are folded backwards. Her hair may be short and curly, or may be drawn up into a bun. The middle demon rests his weight largely on his right leg and crosses his bent left leg over the right, with left foot on tiptoe. His left arm is draped over the shoulders of the rightmost demon. He turns his head partly to the left and seems to hold his mouth open and his eyes raised. He has short curly hair. The spikes of his bat-like wings appear over his head. The rightmost demon also faces forward, but turns his head to look left. His mouth may be open. He stands with right leg straight and left leg bent forward slightly. His left arm is bent upward at the elbow and he grasps the haft of a hook with this hand. He has short curly hair as well. Fainter pencil lines above his head suggest his wings. All three standing demons are nude, though a sort of breechcloth of scales covers the rightmost demon's genitals.

A stone bridge arches up from the lower left foreground and crosses the top of the design to descend along the right edge. Within the bridge or arch, large human shapes are visible. A large face forms part of the base of the left side of the arch. It looks forward, and has long hair, a beard, and lowered eyes. Its hair may extend past the base of the arch along the ground at the left. A right foot with claw-like toes protrudes from the base of the arch below and to the right of the face. To the left of the face, a vaguely defined shape suggests a knee and lower leg. Lines above the face hint at breasts or a muscled abdomen. An ear appears above. Lines to left and right of the ear suggest curly hair. Above and to the right of the ear, a right foot with toes and clearly defined toenails is visible. The lightly penciled shape of a small, seated female figure above the ear may represent a petrified spirit. This figure faces forward and is mainly visible as a head and upper body, with the faint suggestion of bent legs to the left. Sketchily drawn lines on either side of the foot to the right suggest hair (on the left) and a nose and open mouth (on the right). Other lightly sketched lines along the top and especially the right side of the arch indicate additional undefined human shapes.
A second stone bridge or arch is visible in the distance, through the arch in the foreground.

Blake has lightly sketched several groups of human figures running across the distant bridge. They are probably the seducers. Near the left side of the bridge, two figures run together. The figure on the right, higher on the bridge, faces forward with arms spread roughly horizontally. This figure's right hand may be touching the figure behind, or helping that figure climb up the bridge. This figure's left leg is bent forward; its right leg is extended backward. It seems to turn its head back to look at the figure behind. This second figure is less clearly defined, but seems to face right and step forward with one leg and extend the other leg backwards. Near the top of the arch a second group of figures runs facing right. One crawls along the ground on hands and knees, with its body horizontal. Its left leg is drawn up and its right leg is extended backwards. To the right of the crawling figure, another leaps with right leg extended backwards and left leg bent and drawn up. This figure leans forward sharply and curls its right arm up around its head. Two more figures appear on the bridge to the right of the leaping figure. Both of these figures run facing right with one leg forward and one leg extended backwards. They lean forward. The one on the left may raise its arms. Just to the right of these figures, additional sketched lines may represent additional figures, or perhaps shadows.

Three demons fly above the bridge in the distance, chasing the seducers. They are sketched lightly in pencil and their shapes are indistinct, but they seem to fly shoulder to shoulder facing forward with their heads bent back and their bodies stretched horizontally to the left. They each raise one or both bent arms overhead, brandishing large whips.

Dante and Virgil stand side by side on the distant bank of the pitch lake, next to the design's left edge. They seem to face forward and to wear long gowns. Their figures, sketched faintly in pencil, are otherwise difficult to discern.

The near bank, along the bottom of the design, is bare earth or rock. The far bank, visible only at the left edge of the design, seems similarly bare. A wavering line above the heads of Dante and Virgil and the leftmost seducers suggests a higher ledge or crag. Wash in the upper two-thirds of the design suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
Virgil Abashing the Devils Virgil Converses with the Devil Malacoda,
Object 40 (Butlin 812.38)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. The lake of boiling pitch from the previous designs appears in the lower half of the design. Two large rocks or boulders rest to the right of the lake. Additional rocks form the bank of the lake at the left. Dark wash in the upper left corner of the design suggests a dark sky. Malacoda's muscular figure fills much of the middle of this design. The devil sits facing forward and turning his head slightly to the right to look at Virgil. His mouth is slightly open and horns curl up from his forehead. His right leg is bent and his knee is drawn up; his bent left leg is down. Both feet may rest on tiptoe. His left arm is extended down by his side, and his left hand may rest on his left knee. He raises his right arm vertically overhead, with his palm facing out. He is nude, but his genitals are concealed behind scales between his legs. He has large bat-like wings. His abandoned hook rests at his feet. Virgil stands to the right of the devil, facing left and raising his left arm vertically overhead. He points upward with his left index finger. His right forearm is visible in front of his torso, bent up at the elbow. He may be making a fist with this hand, or may raise one finger. His right leg is extended backwards and this foot seems to be on tiptoe. Virgil's clothing is difficult to discern but he seems to wear a long gown and to have long hair. Two additional devils stand behind Virgil at the right edge of the design, facing left. The foremost devil, which is also the one most clearly defined in Blake's penciled lines, stands with left foot slightly forward. His left arm, by his side, is bent up at the elbow and his left hand is at his chin. His head is bent slightly. He holds a tall hook propped in the crook of his left wrist; its haft extends nearly to the ground below. He has short curly hair, a protruding belly, and bat-like wings. To the right, above the first devil's wings, the head of a second devil faces left and slightly forward. He has short curly hair also. His legs, below, face left. Sketched lines above this devil's head may indicate wings or weapons. Both devils seem to be nude. Dante huddles at the left side of the enormous boulder at the center of the design, where he is hidden from view of the devils. He presses his upper body against the rock, facing forward but with eyes swiveled right towards the devils and Virgil. His right arm is bent up at the elbow in front of his chest; his right hand is at his chin and he may be resting his head on this hand. His lower body is difficult to discern but seems to extend to the left above another rock. He seems to be wearing a long gown. He may have long hair, or may have a scarf or similar piece of clothing wrapped around his head like a hood. He may help to cast the largest of the shadows that fall in the crevices between the rocks below.

component.illusobjdesc: The scene takes place in hell. The lake of boiling pitch from the previous designs appears in the lower half of the design. Two large rocks or boulders rest to the right of the lake. Additional rocks form the bank of the lake at the left. Dark wash in the upper left corner of the design suggests a dark sky.

Malacoda's muscular figure fills much of the middle of the design. The devil sits facing forward and turning his head slightly to the right to look at Virgil. His mouth is slightly open and horns curl up from his forehead. His right leg is bent and his knee is drawn up; his bent left leg is down. Both feet may rest on tiptoe. His left arm is extended down by his side, and his left hand may rest on his left knee. He raises his right arm vertically overhead, with his palm facing out. He is nude, but his genitals are concealed behind scales between his legs. He has large bat-like wings. His abandoned hook rests at his feet.

Virgil stands to the right of Malacoda, facing left and raising his left arm vertically overhead. He points upward with his left index finger. His right forearm is visible in front of his torso, bent up at the elbow. He may be making a fist with this hand, or may raise one finger. His right leg is extended backwards and this foot seems to be on tiptoe. Virgil's clothing is difficult to discern but he seems to wear a long gown and to have long hair.

Two additional devils stand behind Virgil at the right edge of the design, facing left. The foremost devil, which is also the one most clearly defined in Blake's penciled lines, stands with left foot slightly forward. His left arm, by his side, is bent up at the elbow and his left hand is at his chin. His head is bent slightly. He holds the haft of a tall hook propped in the crook of his left wrist; its haft extends nearly to the ground below. He has short curly hair, a protruding belly, and bat-like wings. To the right, above the first devil's wings, the head of a second devil faces left and slightly forward. He has short curly hair also. His legs, below, face left. Sketched lines above this devil's head may indicate wings or weapons. Both devils seem to be nude.

Dante huddles at the left side of the enormous boulder at the center of the design, where he is hidden from view of the devils. He presses his upper body against the rock, facing forward but with eyes swiveled right towards the devils and Virgil. His right arm is bent up at the elbow in front of his chest; his right hand is at his chin and he may be resting his head on this hand. His lower body is difficult to discern but seems to extend to the left above another rock. He seems to be wearing a long gown. He may have long hair, or may have a scarf or similar piece of clothing wrapped around his head like a hood. He may help to cast the largest of the shadows that fall in the crevices between the rocks below.

desc.objtitle:
The Devils Setting Out with Dante and Virgil Dante and Virgil Set Out Accompanied by the Devils,
Object 41 (Butlin 812.39 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "52" top right, "N 45 next at p 77" top center, and "Hell Canto 25 Cacus" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The demon Barbariccia walks to the right, but twists his body forward and turns his head to the left; he looks left at Dante, Virgil and the group of devils standing at the left border of the design. His right leg is forward and his left leg is extended backward. He extends his right arm up at 135 degrees and draws it back towards the group at the left. His palm is raised upward. His left arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; he holds a large shepherd's crook or hook in his left hand. Nude, he has large bat-like wings spread wide, and a long tail that curves between his legs. Horns grow from his forehead. He has short curly hair. His mouth curves in a smile. Virgil and Dante stand together between Barbariccia and the other devils. They both face right with slightly lowered heads. Both men have long hair and wear gowns. Faint coloring indicates that Dante (in red) stands farther right, slightly in front of Virgil. Dante turns his head forward and lowers his eyes. His right arm is down by his side. One or both feet may be visible beneath the hem of his gown. Virgil looks to the right with eyes raised. A small crowd of nude demons stands together at the left side of the design. All four of the most clearly delineated demons seem to be male. Farthest left a particularly muscular devil stands facing away with his legs spread. His bent right arm is raised and extended out to the right at 45 degrees, with palm down. His right index finger may be extended in a pointing gesture. He turns his head to the left so that his face is visible in partial profile, looking down. He has short curly hair and bat-like wings. A long tail falls between his legs. At the right of the crowd, a second devil faces forward in a contrapposto position, with his weight resting mostly on his left leg and his right leg bent and possibly crossed behind the left at the ankle. The large tusks that protrude from his open mouth identify this devil as Ciriatto. Additional teeth are visible between his lips. His bat-like wings are curled around his body at the waist and hips, so that they help to hide his genitals. His lower left arm is raised at his side and he grasps the handle of a hook with this hand. His right arm is bent across his chest and he rests his right index finger on the hook in a pointing gesture. He has short curly hair and prominent eyebrows over eyes turned sharply to the right to look at Dante and Virgil. Two devils are penciled lightly in between Ciriatto and the devil seen from behind at the left. The leftmost of these two in the middle faces forward and turns his head slightly to the right. His eyes are swiveled to the right. He may be smiling with an open mouth. His left leg is forward. His left forearm is bent up at his side and he holds the haft of an upraised hook in this hand. His bat-like wings appear above his head. He has short curly hair. The head of the second devil in the middle is visible above Ciriatto's right shoulder, turned slightly right to look torwards Dante and Virgil. The devil curls his lips in a somewhat silly smile. This may be Rubicant. He seems to have short hair; two small horns may spring from his forehead, one above each eye. His bent leg appears to the right of Ciriatto's bent right leg. Faint pencil lines just visible above and to the left of the demon farthest left may indicate yet another demon, the fifth in this grouping. The group of demons bristles with raised hooks. One hook appears above the right shoulder of the demon farthest left. The lightly penciled demon second to left holds a hook in his upraised left hand. Ciriatto, farthest right, holds one in his left hand. A fourth hook is raised to the left of Ciriatto's head. The figures stand or stride along a path of bare earth that runs the length of the bottom of the design. The lake of boiling pitch appears in the middle distance across the design. Its bank, above the path, may be covered with grass. A rocky mound rises in the background at the right, on the far bank of the lake. Fire burns on the lake, particularly along its edges. More flames and possibly smoke fill the upper right corner of the design. Wash above and around the figures suggests a fiery sky.

component.illusobjdesc: The demon Barbariccia walks to the right, but twists his body forward and turns his head to the left; he looks left at Dante, Virgil and the group of devils standing at the left border of the design. His right leg is forward and his left leg is extended backward. He extends his right arm up at 135 degrees and draws it back towards the group at the left. His palm is raised upward. His left arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; he holds a large hook or shepherd's crook in his left hand. Nude, he has large bat-like wings spread wide, and a long tail that curves between his legs. Horns grow from his forehead. He has short curly hair. His mouth curves in a smile.

Virgil and Dante stand together between Barbariccia and the other devils. They both face right with slightly lowered heads. Both men have long hair and wear gowns. Faint coloring indicates that Dante (in red) stands farther right, slightly in front of Virgil. Dante turns his head forward and lowers his eyes. His right arm is down by his side. One or both feet may be visible beneath the hem of his gown. Virgil looks to the right with eyes raised. Of his right arm, only the upper portion is visible, raised forward at about 45 degrees.

A small crowd of nude demons stands together at the left side of the design. All four of the most clearly delineated demons seem to be male. Farthest left a particularly muscular devil stands facing away with his legs spread. His bent right arm is raised and extended out to the right at 45 degrees, with palm down. His right index finger may be extended in a pointing gesture. He turns his head to the left so that his face is visible in partial profile, looking down. He has short curly hair and bat-like wings. A long tail falls between his legs.

A small crowd of nude demons stands together at the left side of the design. At the right of the crowd, a second devil faces forward in a contrapposto position, with his weight resting mostly on his left leg and his right leg bent and possibly crossed behind the left at the ankle. The large tusks that protrude from his open mouth identify this devil as Ciriatto. Additional teeth are visible between his lips. His bat-like wings are curled around his body at the waist and hips, so that they help to hide his genitals. His lower left arm is raised at his side and he grasps the handle of a hook with this hand. His right arm is bent across his chest and he rests his right index finger on the hook in a pointing gesture. He has short curly hair and prominent eyebrows over eyes turned sharply to the right to look at Dante and Virgil.

A small crowd of nude demons stands together at the left side of the design. Two devils are penciled lightly in between Ciriatto and the devil seen from behind at the left. The leftmost of these two in the middle faces forward and turns his head slightly to the right. His eyes are swiveled to the right. He may be smiling with an open mouth. His left leg is forward. His left forearm is bent up at his side and he holds the haft of an upraised hook in this hand. His bat-like wings appear above his head. He has short curly hair.

A small crowd of nude demons stands together at the left side of the design. Two devils are penciled lightly in between Ciriatto and the devil seen from behind at the left. The head of the second devil in the middle is visible above Ciriatto's right shoulder, turned slightly right to look towards Dante and Virgil. The devil curls his lips in a somewhat silly smile. He may be Rubicant. He seems to have short hair; two small horns may spring from his forehead, one above each eye. His bent leg appears to the right of Ciriatto's bent right leg.
Faint pencil lines just visible above and to the left of the demon farthest left may indicate yet another demon, the fifth in this grouping.

The group of demons at the left side of the design bristles with raised hooks. One appears above the right shoulder of the demon farthest left. The lightly penciled demon second to left holds the haft of a hook in his upraised left hand. Ciriatto, farthest right, holds one in his left hand. A fourth hook is raised to the left of Ciriatto's head.

This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The figures stand or stride along a path of bare earth that runs the length of the bottom of the design. The lake of boiling pitch appears in the middle distance across the design. Its bank, above the path, may be covered with grass. A rocky mound rises in the background at the right, on the far bank of the lake. Fire burns on the lake, particularly along its edges. More flames and possibly smoke fill the upper right corner of the design. Wash above and around the figures suggests a fiery sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Devils with Dante and Virgil by the Side of the Pool Dante and Virgil with the Devils by the Lake of Pitch,
Object 42 (Butlin 812.40)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "81" top left. This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The setting of this design is the lake of pitch in the eighth circle of hell. The lake extends across the design. A great stone bridge arches over the foreground. It is anchored at left and right on the bare bank that runs along the bottom of the design. Three additional bridges over the lake recede away. Fire burns on the pitch beneath the farthest bridge (in the middle of the design) and the second farthest bridge (at the left side of the design). A group of figures in the lower left corner includes Dante, Virgil, Barbariccia, and their devil companions. Barbariccia is farthest right, standing or walking facing away with his legs spread. He extends his left arm up at higher than 135 degrees with his palm facing up. His bent right arm is raised at 135 degrees and he grasps the handle of a large hook or staff with his right hand. The other end of the staff may rest on the ground. His bat-like wings are spread and he turns his head to the left to look at his followers. He is nude and has short hair. Dante and Virgil stand or walk shoulder-to-shoulder to the left of Barbariccia. They are difficult to distinguish from each other. Both face forward and to the right, wear long gowns, and have long hair. The figure to the left partly blocks his companion. This figure's right arm is down by his side; his left forearm is bent up before him with his left hand raised and left palm forward and out. The figure to the right, slightly behind, bends his head down. Neither of his arms are visible. A group of indistinct devils appears to the left of Dante and Virgil. The two easiest to distinguish among Blake's penciled lines face right in single file. The rightmost devil walks with his right arm slightly forward and bent up. He holds the haft of a hook in his upraised right hand. His left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe. His head may be lowered. The leftmost devil walks with his right leg bent and his right foot on tiptoe. His right arm may be bent across his torso. Both demons seem to be nude, and may have spiky bat-like wings behind their backs. Penciled sketches between the devils and to the left of the leftmost devil indicate additional devils, difficult to distinguish from each other. At least three more hooks appear above the devils' heads. Six or perhaps seven heads emerge from the water near the bank in the lower right corner of the design. These are the heads of sinners immersed in the pitch. One at the right may extend his or her arm and hand horizontally along the bank to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: The setting of this design is the lake of pitch in the eighth circle of hell. The lake extends across the design. A great stone bridge arches over the foreground. It is anchored at left and right on the bare bank that runs along the bottom of the design. Three additional bridges over the lake recede away. Fire burns on the pitch beneath the farthest bridge (in the middle of the design) and the second farthest bridge (at the left side of the design).

A group of figures in the lower left corner includes Dante, Virgil, Barbariccia, and their devil companions. Barbariccia is farthest right, standing or walking facing away with his legs spread. He extends his left arm up at higher than 135 degrees with his palm facing up. His bent right arm is raised at 135 degrees and he grasps the handle of a large hook or staff with his right hand. The other end of the staff may rest on the ground. His bat-like wings are spread and he turns his head to the left to look at his followers. He is nude and has short hair.

Dante and Virgil stand or walk shoulder-to-shoulder to the left of Barbariccia. They are difficult to distinguish from each other. Both face forward and to the right, wear long gowns, and have long hair. The figure to the left partly blocks his companion. This figure's right arm is down by his side; his left forearm is bent up before him with his left hand raised and left palm forward and out. The figure to the right, slightly behind, bends his head down. Neither of his arms are visible.

A group of devils appears to the left of Dante and Virgil. The two easiest to distinguish among Blake's penciled lines face right in single file. The rightmost devil of these two walks with his right arm slightly forward and bent up. He holds the haft of a hook in his upraised right hand. His left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe. His head may be lowered. He seems to be nude and have bat-like wings.

A group of devils appears to the left of Dante and Virgil. The two easiest to distinguish among Blake's penciled lines face right in single file. The leftmost devil walks with his right leg bent and his right foot on tiptoe. His right arm may be bent across his torso. He seems to be nude, and may have spiky bat-like wings behind his back.

A group of devils appears to the left of Dante and Virgil. The two easiest to distinguish among Blake's penciled lines face right in single file. Penciled sketches between these devils and to the left of the leftmost devil indicate additional devils, difficult to distinguish from one another.
The devils clustered in a group at the left side of the design brandish hooks. The rightmost devil holds one in his upraised right hand. At least three more hooks appear above the devils' heads.

Six or perhaps seven heads emerge from the water near the bank in the lower right corner of the design. These are the heads of sinners immersed in the pitch. One at the right may extend his or her arm and hand horizontally along the bank to the left.

desc.objtitle:
Ciampolo the Barrator Tormented by the Devils Ciampolo Tormented by the Devils,
Object 43 (Butlin 812.41)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "31" top right, and "Pg Canto 22" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. Ciampolo, a corrupt former public servant, stands at the left side of the design. His right arm is bent forward at the elbow and he holds his right hand out with his palm forward. His left arm, slightly bent, is down and his palm is out. The hook that the devil to the right brandishes rips a loop of flesh from the bicep of Ciampolo's left arm. Ciampolo's head rests on his left shoulder. His mouth is open with teeth and tongue showing, and his eyes are swiveled to look in pain and horror at the wound to his arm. Blood and gore drips from the torn flesh. He has short, curly hair and is nude with visible genitals. At the right side of the design, several nude male demons perch together on a boulder. The body of the demon in the front faces right, but he twists his neck back and left to look torwards Ciampolo. His face, with his mouth open in a smile, is seen in three-quarters profile. He is nude and he has a beard and short, curly hair. His right leg is bent and drawn in towards the rock, while his bent left leg dangles. (Alternatively, his left heel may rest gently against the rock below, near the pitch.) His right arm is raised at about 45 degrees and extended to the right, in front of him. He holds a staff, spear, or similar weapon in his right hand. His bat-like wings are wrapped around his shoulders and arms. Behind him, the second demon, Libicocco, straddles the rock facing forward and extends his right leg down to the left. His right foot rests on the bank on tiptoe. His left leg is out to the right, bent with left heel propped against the rock. His head is tilted right but he looks forward, mouth open in a smile and eyes looking out to the right. He has long curly hair and bat-like wings spread wide on either side of his body. He reaches his right arm horizontally out to the left and uses a sharp hook to wound Ciampolo. The head of a third demon is visible above the second demon's right arm, facing forward and to the left and tilted back to look up. His eyes are raised. This demon has short curly hair. His wings are visible above his head. Lightly penciled lines indicate the head and shoulders of a fourth demon near the upper right corner of the design. This demon faces forward and left with lowered eyes. Tusks grow from his mouth, identifying him as Ciriatto. He has short curly hair and bat-like wings visible to the right of his head. The three seated demons perch on a rock at the right side of the design. A similar rock is partly visible at the left side of the design. Both rocks sit on a bare, rocky bank or shore of the lake of boiling pitch, which appears between the rocks. Penciled lines above the pitch suggest flames or steam rising from the surface of the pitch. Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: Ciampolo, a corrupt former public servant, stands at the left side of the design. His legs are slightly bent; his lower body faces slightly right, but he twists at the waist and turns his upper body slightly left. His right arm is bent forward at the elbow and he holds his right hand out with his palm forward. His left arm, slightly bent, is down and his palm is out. The hook that the devil to the right brandishes rips a loop of flesh from the bicep of Ciampolo's arm. His head faces forward but is bent to the right, resting on his left shoulder. His mouth is open with teeth and tongue showing, and his eyes are swiveled to look in pain and horror at the wound to his arm. Blood and gore drips from the torn flesh. He has short, curly hair and is nude with visible genitals.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons perch together on a boulder. The body of the demon in the front faces right, but he twists his neck back and left to look towards Ciampolo. His face, with his mouth open in a smile, is seen in three-quarters profile. He is nude and he has a beard and short, curly hair. His right leg is bent and drawn in towards the rock, while his bent left leg dangles. (Alternatively, his left heel may rest gently against the rock below, near the pitch.) His right arm is raised at about 45 degrees and extended to the right, in front of him. He holds a staff, spear, hook, or similar weapon in his right hand. His bat-like wings are wrapped around his shoulders and arms.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons perch together on a boulder. Second from front, the second demon, Libicocco, straddles the rock facing forward and leaning to the right. He extends his right leg down to the left. His right foot rests on the bank on tiptoe. His left leg is out to the right, bent with left heel propped against the rock. His head is tilted right but he looks forward, mouth open in a smile and eyes looking out to the right. He has long curly hair and bat-like wings spread wide on either side of his body. He reaches his right arm horizontally out to the left and uses a sharp hook to cut flesh from Ciampolo's left arm.

At the right side of the design, several nude male demons perch together on a boulder. The head of the third demon, farthest from front, is visible above the second demon's right arm, facing forward and to the left and tilted back to look up. His eyes are raised. This demon has short, curly hair. His wings are visible above his head.

Lightly penciled lines indicate the head and perhaps the shoulders of a fourth demon near the upper right corner of the design. This demon faces forward and left with lowered eyes. Tusks grow from his mouth, identifying him as Ciriatto. He has short, curly hair and bat-like wings visible to the right of his head.

This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The three seated demons perch on a boulder at the right side of the design. Green coloring on the rock hints at vegetation, possibly grass or moss. A similar rock is partly visible at the left side of the design. Both rocks sit on a bare, rocky bank or shore of the lake of boiling pitch, which appears between the rocks. Penciled lines above the pitch suggest flames or steam rising from the surface of the pitch.
Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: HELL Canto 22 line 70 The full inscription was first written in pencil, and then "Hell Canto 22" was over-written in ink.

desc.objtitle:
The Baffled Devils Fighting The Devils Fighting,
Object 44 (Butlin 812.42)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The lake of boiling pitch stretches across the lower border of the design. Its liquid roils in whirls or waves. Flames lick up from its surface, particularly at the banks and in the troughs of waves. Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other. The devil on the left flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position. His torso faces down, though he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders and tilts his head back to look to the right. He twists at the waist so that his hips and legs face away towards the far shore of the lake, and are seen from behind. His left leg, slightly bent, extends to the left while his right leg is bent at the knee. The soles of both feet are visible. His bent arms are spread wide, with the right down and the left up. With the right palm down and left palm vertical and out, he spreads his fingers like talons. His jagged, bat-like wings rise up to the left from behind his shoulders. He has short, curly hair and his open mouth is drawn into a smile or a grimace. On the right, the opposing devil flies or hovers with his lower body extended to the right, facing forward. His right leg is bent and his genitals are visible. He twists at the waist; his torso faces down but he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders to look forward. His head is turned slightly left. He raises his right arm vertically and bends it right, over his head. His left arm is raised horizontally and bent up at the elbow, palm up and out towards the viewer. Like his opponent, his mouth is open in a smile or grimace. His teeth are visible. He has short, curly hair. His bat-like wings extend from his back. Gentle hills form the far bank of the lake. Groups of demons sit on several of these mounds at the right. Sitting and standing, they seem to have gathered to watch the pair of demons fight over the water. A larger hill rises on the left, and craggy mountains appear in the distance on the right. A path rises up from the lower left and circles around the larger hill. Flames rise from what appears to be a smaller pool of pitch in the bank at the left edge of the design. Larger and more threatening tongues of fire burn above the mountains on the right, at the horizon. Wash above the hill on the left suggests the sky, which becomes dark over the fire on the right, perhaps with clouds of smoke. Two figures representing Dante and Virgil stand on the path near the top of the design. They are sketched faintly in pencil, but seem to face forward and to wear long gowns.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. The lake of boiling pitch stretches across the lower border of the design. Its liquid roils in whirls or waves. Flames lick up from its surface, particularly at the banks and in the troughs of waves.

Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other. The devil on the left flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position. His torso faces down, though he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders and tilts his head back to look to the right. He twists at the waist so that his hips and legs face away towards the far shore of the lake, and are seen from behind. His left leg, slightly bent, extends to the left while his right leg is bent at the knee. The soles of both feet are visible. His bent arms are spread wide, with the right down and the left up. With right palm down and left palm vertical and out, he spreads his fingers like talons. His jagged, bat-like wings rise up to the left from behind his shoulders. He has short, curly hair and his open mouth is drawn into a smile or a grimace.

Two devils attack one another in the air over the lake. Nude and muscular, they use the sharp claws on their hands to assail each other The devil on the right flies or hovers with his lower body extended to the right, facing forward. His right leg is bent and his genitals are visible. He twists at the waist; his torso faces down but he bends backwards or lifts his shoulders to look forward. His head is turned slightly left. He raises his right arm vertically and bends it right, over his head. His left arm is raised horizontally and bent up at the elbow, palm up and out towards the viewer. Like his opponent, his mouth is open in a smile or grimace. His teeth are visible. He has short, curly hair. His bat-like wings extend from his back.

Gentle hills form the far bank of the lake. Groups of demons sit on several of these mounds at the right. A larger hill rises on the left; a path rises up from the lower left and circles around this larger hill.
Craggy mountains appear in the distance on the right.

Flames rise from what appears to be a smaller pool or tiny lake of pitch in the bank at the left edge of the design. Larger and more threatening tongues of fire burn above the mountains on the right, at the horizon.
Wash above the hill on the left suggests the sky, which becomes dark over the fire on the right, perhaps with clouds of smoke.
Two figures representing Dante and Virgil stand on the path near the top of the design. They are sketched faintly in pencil, but seem to face forward and to wear long gowns.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. They all seem to be nude. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the grouping, facing forward. The demon on the right stands with his right leg bent and right foot on tiptoe. His genitals are faintly visible. His right arm is raised vertically with palm up and out. His left arm is down by his side and the haft of a large hook or staff rests against his left shoulder. He may hold the haft with his left hand. His head is bent slightly; he has short, spiky hair and perhaps horns above his forehead. He also has bat-like wings.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. They all seem to be nude. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. The standing demon to the left raises his right hand with palm up and out. He has spiky, bat-like wings. His mouth may be open. He may hold in his raised left hand the staff or hook rising well above him.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. On the same hill to the left, two demons sit next to each other. The seated demon on the right faces forward but turns his head slightly left, his mouth open in a smile. His left leg is bent with knee drawn up, and his right leg dangles. He seems to be bald, and may have a beard. His spiky wings rise above his shoulders.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Two of these demons stand together near the middle of the groupings, facing forward. On the same hill to the left, two demons sit next to each other. The seated demon on the left faces forward and left with legs spread, bending forward slightly. His bent right leg rests horizontally along the hill; his bent left leg hangs down. This demon has short, curly hair and an open-mouthed smile. His bent left arm is down and his left hand rests on the ground. His bat-like wings appear over his shoulders.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The leftmost of these three faces left with legs extended left along the hill and right arm raised horizontally with palm up. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but they are probably males.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The middle demon in this group faces forward, with bent right leg lying to the left and bent left leg forward. This figure's right arm is raised horizontally with palm up. Its left arm may be bent and down. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but they are probably males.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The grouping farthest left includes three demons that sit together on a far hill. The rightmost demon of this group sits facing forward with both arms lifted vertically overhead and at least the right palm facing up. Jagged lines above this figure's head and to the right of its torso suggest bat-like wings. Other features of this sketched figure, including gender, are difficult to discern, but they are probably males.

Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. Near the middle of this grouping, two of these demons stand together, facing forward. To the right of the standing demons, another demon sits facing forward with bent legs spread and head turned to the left. This demon is nude and seems to have female breasts. Her right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent upward at the elbow with palm forward. Her left arm is bent up at the elbow, which may be propped on her left thigh. Her spiky wings are spread on either side of her body.
