Several groups of demons have gathered on the far shore of the lake, at the right, watching the pair of demons fight over the water. The shoulders and faces of two demons sitting closely side-by-side appear near the right edge of the design, above a seated female demon with visible breasts. These two sitting together face forward and slightly left. The one on the right may be holding a hook or other indistinct object in its upraised left hand. Other features of these sketched figures are difficult to discern.

desc.objtitle:
Dante and Virgil Escaping from the Devils Dante and Virgil Escape from the Devils,
Object 45 (Butlin 812.43 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "70" top left, and "Hell Canto 24 v. 30" partly erased bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A rock bridge spans the design. The right leg of the bridge extends down the right side of the design. A slender path is carved into this leg on the inside, near the bottom. Below the bridge, Dante and Virgil flee the demons massed above. Virgil carries Dante and runs rightward with his bent left leg drawn forward and his right leg extended behind him to the left. His left foot rests precariously on tiptoe at the edge of a slender path carved into the underside of the bridge. He leans forward sharply, but twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. Virgil grasps Dante around the waist with both of his arms bent. He turns his head to look up to the left at the demons, his eyes raised and his mouth open. Dante's body rests on Virgil's hip and torso, facing forward and nearly horizontal. Dante's right leg is not visible; his left is extended straight out to the left. Dante twists his shoulders down to the right and clasps Virgil with his left arm; his left hand rests on Virgil's left shoulder. Dante extends his right arm straight in front of him, with palm out. Like Virgil, he turns his head up to the left and raises his eyes to look at the demons. Both Dante and Virgil have long curly hair and wear long transparent gowns that swirl around their legs and billow behind them. Gentle hills sloping away into the distance are visible through the arch of the bridge. These hills seem to be covered with grass. Wash at the horizon suggests a distant lake or similar body of water. Hooded sinners punished for hypocrisy stand or walk in a line circling a near hill on the left. Only their upper bodies are visible, bending forward with bowed heads and hunched shoulders. Their heavy cowls obscure their features. A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. Their grouping bristles with hooks or similar weapons. Their faces are turned to look at the two fleeing figures below. A cloud floats over the distant landscape, visible through the arch of the stone bridge. Wash in this area and around the demons above suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A rock bridge spans the design. The right leg of the bridge extends down the right side of the design. A slender path is carved into this leg on the inside, near the bottom. Shadow lines the underside of the bridge.

Below the bridge, Dante and Virgil flee the demons massed above. Virgil carries Dante and runs rightward with his bent left leg drawn forward and his right leg extended behind him to the left. His left foot rests precariously on tiptoe at the edge of a slender path carved into the underside of the bridge. He leans forward sharply, but twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. Virgil grasps Dante around the waist with both of his arms bent. He turns his head to look up to the left at the demons, with his eyes raised and his mouth open. He has long curly hair and wears a transparent gown that billows in folds around his legs.

Dante rests on his side against Virgil's hip and torso, with his body facing forward and nearly horizontal. Dante's right leg is not visible; his left is extended straight out to the left. Dante twists his shoulders down to the right and clasps Virgil with his left arm; his left hand rests on Virgil's left shoulder. Dante extends his right arm horizontally in front of him, with palm out. Like Virgil, he turns his head up to the left and raises his eyes to look at the demons. He has long curly hair and wears a long transparent gown that extends past his foot.

Gentle hills sloping away into the distance are visible through the arch of the bridge. These hills seem to be covered with grass. Wash at the horizon suggests a distant lake or similar body of water.

Hooded sinners punished for hypocrisy stand or walk in a line circling a near hill on the left. Only their upper bodies are visible, bending forward with bowed heads and hunched shoulders. Their heavy cowls obscure their features.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. The demon in the front, a male, flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position facing forward. He twists at the waist so that his torso is also turned partly downward, and his face shows in three-quarters profile looking towards Dante and Virgil. His mouth may be open slightly. His right arm is raised at 45 degrees relative to his body. He raises his left arm horizontally (vertically relative to his body) and brandishes a hook in his left hand. He is nude; scales cover his genitals. He has short curly hair. His wings rise up from his back.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. The demon in the front, a male, flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position facing forward. Between his upraised wings the lightly sketched head of another demon appears, facing forward with lowered or closed eyes and mouth perhaps open slightly. Jagged lines around the head may represent its curly hair, while larger sharp shapes to either side may be its wings. A sketched foot visible above the first demon's right hand may belong to this second demon.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. Above the foremost of these demons, and just below the top edge of the design, appears the head of another demon. Faintly sketched, this head seems to face forward and up. The demon may hold its mouth open. It may have short curly hair.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. To the left of the first, foremost demon, nearer the upper left corner of the design, another demon flies or hovers with horizontal torso facing forward. This demon tilts his head back and turns it down to the right slightly; his eyes are raised and his mouth is open to show his teeth. His bent legs extend together diagonally up towards the upper left corner. His left foot appears beyond his right knee. He holds a hook in his left hand; this arm is by his side. His right arm is down but bent up at the elbow with palm out. He is nude and has short curly hair. His wings are visible above his shoulders.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. The demon in the front, a male, flies or hovers with his body in a horizontal position facing forward. Another demon, who may be female, is partly visible above this foremost demon's horizontally extended left arm. This female demon's head faces forward and down, with partly open mouth and long curly hair. She reaches her left arm out to the right and grasps a hook, spear, or similar weapon (not clearly delineated) in this hand. Her wings rise above and to the right of her head.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. At the right side of the grouping the faintly sketched heads of two demons appear. The lower one is visible between the left hand and left wing of a female demon to the left. It looks forward with mouth open. This demon's head may have a beard and short hair.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. At the right side of the grouping the faintly sketched heads of two demons appear. Above and to the left of this head appears yet another, even more faintly sketched, looking forward.

A group of muscular demons, massed at the top of the design, pursue Virgil and Dante. Many of the demons brandish hooks or similar weapons. At least three hooks that aren't clearly connected to an individual figure bristle from the group of demons rightward into the top right corner.
A cloud floats over the distant landscape, visible through the arch of the stone bridge. Wash in this area and around the demons above suggests the sky, perhaps at sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
The Hypocrites with Caiaphas,
Object 46 (Butlin 812.44 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "71" top left, "N38 next at p 72" top center, the same in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 23 v 40" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the sixth trench of the eighth circle of hell. Four hills fill the middle and background. A shadowed cavelike cavity opens in the nearest hill. The ground is flat and bare, though wash on the far hill on the right suggests grass. A rock or boulder fills the lower left corner. The flat, bare foreground is slightly lower than the plane of the middle ground. A third, slightly higher level of ground appears in the mid-distance on the left, above the boulder. Wash at the top of the design suggests a dark sky, particularly at the right side. Dante and Virgil stand together at the right side of the design. Their figures are sketched lightly in pencil, making it difficult to tell which is Dante and which Virgil. Both wear long gowns and have long hair. The man on the left faces forward and slightly left, but turns his head to the right to look at his companion. His right arm is down by his side, palm facing down. His left arm is bent across his torso. The man on the right faces left, with his head bent forward. His mouth may be open. His left arm is bent up across his body and his left hand is raised, perhaps with palm facing up. His left foot may emerge from below his gown. To the left of Dante and Virgil lies a male figure stretched on a cross on the ground. This is Caiaphas, the Jewish high priest who recommended the death of Jesus for political convenience. In this image he lies supine, turning his head to face forward. His legs are extended to the left; large nails or stakes driven through his feet hold them to the wood beneath. His left arm is extended out horizontally from his body, stretching down to the right along the beam of the cross. A nail pierces his open palm to anchor it to the cross. He is nude except for a cloth wrapped around his pelvis, but his long curly beard spills over his torso and hides much of it. His long hair falls backwards onto the ground below. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open. A line of hypocrites files around the left side of the nearest hill, rising as the figures come rightward and closer to Caiaphas. They bend over, hunched beneath their friars' habits, their heads bowed under heavy cowls that cover their faces completely. Their arms are bent up at the elbow and their hands are hidden. The hypocrite nearest Caiaphas steps on him, with his right leg bent and drawn up and his right foot resting on Caiaphas' torso. Otherwise this figure maintains his hunched posture. The line of hypocrites resumes below Caiaphas, now marching facing left. More distant hypocrites in single file are also visible before the far hill on the left, as a series of lightly sketched shapes. A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The body of the demon farthest right is horizontal. His lower body faces down, with right leg extended and left leg bent and drawn forward, but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. His head is bent back and his mouth may be open and smiling. Both feet are pointed into tiptoes. He reaches his right arm horizontally past his head to the left, and his left arm out to the right; with his left hand he grasps a large hook shaped like a shepherd's crook. He has short, curly hair. Bat-like wings rise from his shoulders. The demon second from right is seen from behind, his lower body facing down and his body mostly horizontal. He flies or hovers with legs extended to the right, and reaches his arms horizontally out to either side. The soles of both of his feet are visible. He lifts his upper body to face away and to the left. His head is bent back and he seems to have short hair. His bat-like wings are spread wide. The demon nearest the top edge of the design flies or hovers with body facing down and extended away from the viewer, but head bent back to look forward. He has drawn his bent right leg up and extends his left leg out to the right. His right arm reaches up at 135 degrees and he seems to hold a hook in this upraised right hand. His bat-like wings are raised above his back. He seems to have short hair. Below him and to the left a fourth demon stretches diagonally towards the upper left corner of the design, facing forward with right leg bent and drawn up and left leg extended obliquely down to the right. Both feet are pointed into tiptoes. He turns his head to the left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile; his head is bent back as well. He raises his right arm at 135 degrees, brandishing a hook in his upraised right hand. His bat-like wings appear above his shoulders. He seems to be bald, but a small horn sprouts from his left temple. The demon nearest the left edge of the design dives or falls diagonally down to the left, his body facing forward though he turns his head to look down. He bends left at the waist. Both legs are bent, the left more than the right. His genitals are visible. His left arm is raised and bent over his head while his right is extended down to the left. He holds a hook in his right hand. He has short hair. He does not have visible wings.

component.illusobjdesc: Dante and Virgil stand together at the right side of the design; the scene takes place in the sixth trench of the eighth circle of hell. The figures are sketched lightly in pencil, making it difficult to tell which is Dante and which Virgil. Both wear long gowns and have long hair. The man on the left faces forward and slightly left, but turns his head to the right to look at his companion. His right arm is down by his side, palm facing down. His left arm is bent across his torso. The man on the right faces left, with his head bent forward. His mouth may be open. His left arm is bent up across his body and his left hand is raised, perhaps with palm facing up. His left foot may emerge from below his gown.

To the left of Dante and Virgil lies a male figure stretched on a cross on the ground. This is Caiaphas, the Jewish high priest who recommended the death of Jesus for political convenience. In this image he lies supine, turning his head to face forward. His legs are extended to the left; large nails or stakes driven through his feet hold them to the wood beneath. His left arm is extended out horizontally from his body, stretching down to the right along the beam of the cross. A nail pierces his open palm to anchor it to the cross. He is nude except for a cloth wrapped around his pelvis, but his long curly beard spills over his torso and hides much of it. His long hair falls backwards onto the ground below. His eyes are wide and his mouth is open.

This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. Four hills fill the middle and background. A shadowed cavelike cavity opens in the nearest hill. The ground is flat and bare, though wash on the far hill on the right suggests grass. A rock or boulder fills the lower left corner. The flat, bare foreground is slightly lower than the plane where Caiaphas lies stretched on the cross. A third, slightly higher level of ground appears in the mid-distance on the left, above the boulder.
Wash at the top of the design suggests a dark sky, particularly at the right side.

A line of hypocrites files around the left side of the nearest hill, rising as the figures come rightward and closer to Caiaphas. They bend over, hunched beneath their friars' habits, their heads bowed under heavy cowls that cover their faces completely. Their arms are bent up at the elbow and their hands are hidden. The hypocrite nearest Caiaphas steps on him, with his right leg bent and drawn up and his right foot resting on Caiaphas' torso. Otherwise this figure maintains his hunched posture. The line of hypocrites resumes below Caiaphas, now marching facing left. More distant hypocrites in single file are also visible before the far hill on the left, as a series of lightly sketched shapes.

A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The body of the demon farthest right is horizontal. His lower body faces down, with right leg extended and left leg bent and drawn forward, but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. His head is bent back and his mouth may be open and smiling. Both feet are pointed into tiptoes. He reaches his right arm horizontally past his head to the left, and his left arm out to the right; with his left hand he grasps a large hook shaped like a shepherd's crook. He has short, curly hair. Bat-like wings rise from his shoulders.

A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The demon second from right is seen from behind, his lower body facing down and his body mostly horizontal. He flies or hovers with legs extended to the right, and reaches his arms horizontally out to either side. The soles of both of his feet are visible. He lifts his upper body to face away and to the left. His head is bent back and he seems to have short hair. His bat-like wings are spread wide.

A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The demon nearest the top edge of the design flies or hovers with body facing down and extended away from the viewer, but head bent back to look forward. He has drawn his bent right leg up and extends his left leg out to the right. His right arm reaches up at 135 degrees and he seems to hold a hook in this upraised hand. His bat-like wings are raised above his back. He seems to have short hair.

A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The demon nearest the top edge of the design flies or hovers with body facing down and extended away, but head bent back to look forward. Below him and to the left a fourth demon stretches diagonally towards the upper left corner of the design, facing forward with right leg bent and drawn up and left leg extended obliquely down to the right. Both feet are pointed into tiptoes. He turns his head to the left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile; his head is bent back as well. He raises his right arm at 135 degrees, brandishing a hook in his upraised right hand. His bat-like wings appear above his shoulders. He seems to be bald, but a small horn sprouts from his left temple.

A group of nude, muscular demons flies or hovers in the sky near the upper left corner of the design. The demon nearest the left edge of the design dives or falls diagonally down to the left, his body facing forward though he turns his head to look down. He bends left at the waist. Both legs are bent, the left more than the right. His genitals are visible. His left arm is raised and bent over his head while his right is extended down to the left. He holds a hook in his right hand. He has short hair. He does not have visible wings.

desc.objtitle:
The Laborious Passage Along the Rocks,
Object 47 (Butlin 812.45 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "86" top right, "N 22 next at p 42" top center, "Paradiso Canto 26 v 81" bottom left, "3" left center, and "14 hell Canto 14" partly erased top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell, in the wreckage of a rock bridge, now only a cliff. The enormous boulders of this fallen bridge fill the left side of the design. Although the rocky masses are only lightly sketched, wash indicates areas of shadow. Even fainter lines in the lower right corner of the design may indicate more rock. A cloud curves up from the lower right corner through the right side of the design. The tiny figures of Dante and Virgil appear on the tumbled boulders of the ruined bridge. Dante stands higher than Virgil, facing left. He reaches both arms overhead at 135 degrees. He may wear a gown. One of his legs may be extended backwards; alternatively this line may represent merely the shape of his clothing. Other features are difficult to discern. Virgil is positioned below and to the right of Dante, facing left and leaning forward. He climbs from a lower boulder onto the one on which Dante stands. His left leg is bent and drawn up, with knee and lower leg resting on the higher rock. His right leg is extended down behind him to the right, and his right foot is planted on the lower rock. One arm (perhaps his right) is extended in front of him nearly horizontally; this hand may rest on the higher rock. The other arm (perhaps his left) seems to be bent and drawn back behind him. Other features, including his clothing, are difficult to discern.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell, in the wreckage of a rock bridge, now only a cliff. The enormous boulders of this fallen bridge fill the left side of the design. Although the rocky masses are only lightly sketched, wash indicates areas of shadow. Even fainter lines in the lower right corner of the design may indicate more rock.
A cloud curves up from the lower right corner through the right side of the design.

The tiny figures of Dante and Virgil appear on the tumbled boulders of the ruined bridge. Dante stands higher than Virgil, facing left. He reaches both arms overhead at 135 degrees. He may wear a gown. One of his legs may be extended backwards; alternatively this line may represent merely the shape of his clothing. Other features are difficult to discern.

Virgil is positioned below and to the right of Dante, facing left and leaning forward. He climbs from a lower boulder onto the one on which Dante stands. His left leg is bent and drawn up, with knee and lower leg resting on the higher rock. His right leg is extended down behind him to the right, and his right foot is planted on the lower rock. One arm (perhaps his right) is extended in front of him nearly horizontally; this hand may rest on the higher rock. The other arm (perhaps his left) seems to be bent and drawn back behind him. Other features, including his clothing, are difficult to discern.

lg.l: 87 This inscription is faint and may have been partly erased.

l.note: This line is written vertically, reading from bottom to top, in the upper right margin. The inscription is very faint and may have been partly erased.

desc.objtitle:
The Laborious Passage Along the Rocks Continuing Passage Along the Rocks,
Object 48 (Butlin 812.46)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "69" top left, "N 40 next at p 75" top center, and "Hell Canto 24 v 60" bottom left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell, amid the wreckage of a ruined rock bridge. One half of its original arch still stands, and is visible at the left of the design. It is rooted in the ground at the left edge of the design and curves up to the right. Stone rubble from the fallen half of the original bridge fills much of the right side of the design. Large boulders from the bridge now form a tumbled pile. A hill or low mountain appears in the distance, visible between the rubble of the bridge at the right, and the half of the arch that still stands at the left. Faint lines above and to the left of this mountain suggest a second, more distant hill or mountain. Wash that surrounds the broken arch at the left suggests the sky. A long cloud, or series of clouds, curl up from above the distant mountain and around the broken arch of the bridge. Dante and Virgil appear on the rubble of the broken bridge at the right. Dante stands above, facing forward and to the right. His arms are by his side and bent forward, with his hands raised. At least his left palm seems to face up. He wears a long gown, but otherwise his features are difficult to distinguish. Virgil stands or climbs below Dante to the right. He faces away and bends slightly to the right at the waist. He rests his weight on his right leg and his left leg is extended backwards; his left foot may be on tiptoe. He seems to be wearing a gown, but other features are difficult to distinguish. Two faint figures are barely visible above the standing half of the bridge, near the top of the design at the left. These may represent demons that Blake sketched and then erased or covered with wash. They seem to stand side by side facing forward. Their other features are indistinguishable.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell, amid the wreckage of a ruined rock bridge. One half of its original arch still stands, and is visible at the left of the design. It is now only a cliff. It is rooted in the ground at the left edge of the design and curves up to the right.

This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell, amid the wreckage of a ruined bridge. Stone rubble from the fallen half of the original bridge fills much of the right side of the design. Large boulders from the bridge now form a tumbled pile.

A hill or low mountain appears in the distance, visible between the rubble of the bridge at the right, and the half of the arch that still stands at the left. Faint lines above and to the left of this mountain suggest a second, more distant hill or mountain.
Wash that surrounds the broken arch at the left suggests the sky. A long cloud, or a series of clouds, curl up from above the distant mountain and around the broken arch of the bridge.

Dante and Virgil appear on the rubble of the broken bridge at the right. Dante stands above, facing forward and to the right. His arms are by his side and bent forward, with his hands raised. At least his left palm seems to face up. He wears a long gown, but otherwise his features are difficult to distinguish.

Dante and Virgil appear on the rubble of the broken bridge at the right. Virgil stands or climbs below Dante to the right. He faces away and bends slightly to the right at the waist. He rests his weight on his right leg and his left leg is extended backward; his left foot may be on tiptoe. He seems to be wearing a gown, but other features are difficult to distinguish.

Two faint figures are barely visible above the standing half of the bridge, near the top of the design at the left. These may represent demons that Blake sketched and then erased or covered with wash. They seem to stand side by side facing forward. Their other features are indistinguishable.

lg.l: Canto 24 This inscription is very faint.

HELL Canto 24
v 30 "v 30" is very faint; our reading is conjectural. It forms a syntactic unit with line 1 and not with line 2.

desc.objtitle:
The Thieves and the Serpents,
Object 49 (Butlin 812.47 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "74 No 47 next at p 73" bottom center, the same partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Canto 25" top center partly erased. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell, where thieves are punished. Flames lick up from the floor almost to the top edge of the design. Dark wash between the flames at the left suggests smoke or a dark sky. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth. A cliff appears at the right side of the design, in the middle distance. The tiny figure of a demon stands at the edge of the cliff. This figure faces forward, slightly crouched with both legs bent. Its left foot may be on tiptoe. It raises both arms at 45 degrees and holds a club or similar weapon, or possibly a cross, in its left hand. Leaning and bending to the left, it lowers its head and peers down over the edge of the cliff. It may be nude; other features are difficult to distinguish. A sinner hurtles down past the left side of the cliff. Head down, this figure faces forward or away with extended arms straight overhead. Other features are difficult to distinguish. Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. The rightmost of them, a male, runs facing left. His bent right leg is drawn forward and his weight rests on this foot; his bent left leg is extended backward with the toes pointed into tiptoe. Nude, he has visible genitals. His left arm is at his side and bent up behind his back at the elbow; his left forearm rests on his right forearm at the small of his back. His right hand lies on his hip with palm down and fingers spread. A serpent may bind his arms and wrap his waist. Leaning forward, he also bends his head back sharply to look up. His mouth is open. His short curly hair flies behind his head. The second from right is a nude female with visible breasts who stands facing forward and to the right with her arms drawn behind her back: her right arm is visible to the elbow, while only the very top of her upper left arm can be seen. She stands with both legs slightly bent and her lower body facing forward and to the right. Bending right at the waist, she twists her torso forward and turns her head to the left so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile looking up to the left. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. She seems to have short curly hair. The body of a snake curls down from behind her right hip. The figure in the middle is a male who kneels on the ground with his legs together. His lower body faces left but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. He leans backwards, and tilts his head back so sharply that his face is only partly visible. His left arm is not visible. His right arm, visible only to the elbow, is by his side and drawn back. The body of a snake coils around his waist from the right side of his torso into his lap. A nude male stands second from left, facing away. His weight rests on his right leg, while his left leg is slightly bent and extended behind him. His left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are down, bent across the small of his back, and crossed at the wrists. Several snakes have coiled themselves around his wrists to bind them; one snake's head lies along the man's left forearm while the other is lifted above his right forearm. His hands dangle, palms vertical and facing out. His head is bent down and his long hair drapes over his face and down between his shoulder blades. The thief farthest left is a nude woman who lies on the ground on her side, facing forward. Her bent left leg is visible to the knee. Her right arm lies horizontally along the ground, bent up at the elbow around her head, which is turned to look up. Her left arm is hidden. Her mouth is open. Her long hair falls back from her temple and spills onto the ground near her elbow. The body of a large serpent is wound around her waist. Another large snake undulates across the ground from left to right in the middle distance, near the left edge of the design. The creature has the torso and breasts of a woman, lifted from the ground and facing forward. Instead of arms, however, it raises wings that form a hood over her head. Smaller feathers emerge from its armpits. Its skull-like head, with bird-like eyes, a beaky nose, and a gruesome smile, is turned slightly left. It has short, curly hair, or perhaps its head is covered with smaller feathers. Its body extends to the left. Above the large serpent with the torso of a woman, a second snake appears further in the distance. It curls its body in an incomplete loop raised from the ground. Its body extends to the left. It has a human-like head, facing forward and to the left. Its nose also suggests the nasal cavity of a skull; its mouth curls in an open smile. It may be bald, or may have short wispy hair. Above the two snakes on the ground, a third lifts its body vertically, head facing up and mouth open. This snake has several scaly appendages extending from its body, and one (crest-like) from the top of its head.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell, where thieves are punished. Flames lick up from the floor almost to the top edge of the design. Dark wash between the flames at the left suggests smoke or a dark sky.
A cliff appears at the right side of the design, in the middle distance.
The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth.

Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. The rightmost of them, a male, runs facing left. His bent right leg is drawn forward and his weight rests on this foot; his bent left leg is extended backward with the toes pointed into tiptoe. Nude, he has visible genitals. His left arm is at his side and bent up behind his back at the elbow; his left forearm rests on his right forearm at the small of his back. His right hand lies on his hip with palm down and fingers spread. A serpent may bind his arms and wrap his waist. Leaning forward, he also bends his head back sharply to look up. His mouth is open. His short curly hair flies behind his head.

Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. The second from right is a nude female with visible breasts who stands facing forward and to the right with her arms drawn behind her back: her right arm is visible to the elbow, while only the very top of her upper left arm can be seen. She stands with both legs slightly bent and her lower body facing forward and to the right. Bending right at the waist, she twists her torso forward and turns her head to the left so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile looking up to the left. Her mouth is open and her eyes are raised. She seems to have short curly hair. The body of a snake curls down from behind her right hip.

Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. The figure in the middle is a male who kneels on the ground with his legs together. His lower body faces left but he twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward. He leans backwards, and tilts his head back so sharply that his face is only partly visible, from below. His left arm is not visible. His right arm, visible only to the elbow, is by his side and drawn back. The body of a snake coils around his waist from the right side of his torso into his lap.

Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. A nude male stands second from left, facing away. His weight rests on his right leg, while his left leg is slightly bent and extended behind him. His left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are down, bent across the small of his back, and crossed at the wrists. Several snakes have coiled themselves around his wrists to bind them; one snake's head lies along the man's left forearm while the other is lifted above his right forearm. His hands dangle, palms vertical and facing out. His head is bent down and his long hair drapes over his face and down between his shoulder blades.

Five thieves occupy the foreground of the design. The one furthest left is a nude woman who lies on the ground on her side, facing forward. Her bent left leg is visible to the knee. Her right arm lies horizontally along the ground, bent up at the elbow around her head, which is turned to look up. Her left arm is hidden. Her mouth is open. Her long hair falls back from her temple and spills onto the ground near her elbow. The body of a large serpent is wound around her waist.

A large serpent undulates across the ground from left to right in the middle distance, near the left edge of the design. The creature has the torso and breasts of a woman, lifted from the ground and facing forward. Instead of arms, however, it raises wings that forms a hood over her head. Smaller feathers emerge from its armpits. Its skull-like head, with bird-like eyes, a beaky nose, and a gruesome smile, is turned slightly left. It has short, curly hair, or perhaps its head is covered with smaller feathers. Its body extends to the left.

Above the large serpent with the torso of a woman, a second snake appears further in the distance. It curls its body in an incomplete loop raised from the ground. Its body extends to the left. It has a human-like head, facing forward and to the left. Its nose also suggests the nasal cavity of a skull; its mouth curls in an open smile. It may be bald, or may have short wispy hair.

Above the two snakes on the ground, a third lifts its body vertically, head facing up and mouth open. This snake has several scaly appendages extending from its body, and one, crest-like, from the top of its head.

The tiny figure of a demon stands at the edge of the cliff in the middle distance on the right. This figure faces forward, slightly crouched with both legs bent. Its left foot may be on tiptoe. It raises both arms at 45 degrees and holds a club or similar weapon, or perhaps a cross, in its left hand. Leaning and bending to the left, it lowers its head and peers down over the edge of the cliff. It may be nude; other features are difficult to distinguish.
A sinner hurtles down past the left side of the cliff at the right. Head down, this figure faces forward or away with arms extended straight overhead. Other features are difficult to distinguish.

desc.objtitle:
The Punishment of the Thieves,
Object 50 (Butlin 812.102)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "80" top left, and "N 20 next at p 79" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc:
This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. At least seven thieves and three serpents appear. A flat bank runs across the bottom edge of the design; above it a stream rippled with wavelets is visible, especially nearer the right edge of the design. A small flat island is visible in the stream, right of center. A rock or small boulder appears above the lower left corner. Wash across the top of the design suggests a dark sky, except for a lighter area in the upper left corner. One of the sinners, a female, kneels at the left side of the design. Nude with visible breasts, she faces forward and to the right, with her legs bent and her right leg drawn up beneath her body. Her torso leans away and bends to the left slightly, and she may be resting some of her weight on her right arm, which is down. Her right hand rests on the ground, palm down. She leans her head sharply to the left so that her right cheek touches her right shoulder. Her head is also bent back, and her long curly hair cascades down behind her right arm. One strand of her hair lies along her left shoulder. The head and right arm of another female thief are visible above and to the left of the female kneeling at the left side of the design. This second female's arm is down, and her right hand rests on the ground with palm down. Her head is tilted back and to the left, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile looking left. She leans her right cheek on her right shoulder. Her eyelids are lowered or closed. Her mouth may be open slightly. She has long curly hair. An indistinct shape in the upper left corner of the design may be part of another thief. The upper body of another thief, a nude male, appears to the right. His torso faces forward and to the left. He seems to lean back and may bend to the right slightly; he tilts his head back and turns it right, so that he looks up to the right. His left cheek may rest on his left shoulder. His eyes are raised and his mouth is slightly open. A female thief stands at the center of the design, curving her nude body dramatically rightward. His legs are together, slightly bent at the knees and facing away. Her lower body is thus seen from behind. She twists and bends to the right at the waist, curling her upper body over so that her shoulders and breasts face down. Her head is lowered and turned slightly forward, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile beneath her right arm, which is raised horizontally and bent behind her head. Her long curly hair hangs down past her head. Her open left hand, with palm down and fingers spread, appears to the right of her head.
The body of another thief is positioned nearest the upper right corner of the design, seated on a small flat island within the stream. This figure seems to be male. His head is hidden behind the head of the woman who stands at the center and curls her body rightward. He sits with his legs extended down to the left. His left leg is bent and raised slightly higher than the right. Both legs are hidden below the knee, and seem to be immersed in the waters of the stream. He twists forward at the waist, and leans back. His upper right arm is visible almost to the elbow, down by his side. His left forearm is visible below his torso, down and drawn back. His left hand rests on the ground, palm down. Irregular lines above his hand may be his long curly hair, or may be more of the long hair of the woman whose head obscures his own. A serpent's body undulates up between the knees of this male thief who sits near the upper right corner of the design. It curls over his left thigh, touching the ground next to his hip before lifting its head to look up. A thief, visible between eyes and knees, lies supine in the lower right corner of the design. Though this figure is nude, it is difficult to tell whether the thief is male or female. Neither arm is visible. The figure's head is turned slightly forward. A snake lies along the torso of this thief lying face-up in the lower right corner of the design. Its head is near the thief's breastbone, while its tail curls between the thief's legs. The nude buttocks and waist of another thief, sitting in the distance and facing away, are visible above the hips of a male thief sitting near the upper right corner of the design. The position of his or her waist suggests this thief is leaning back slightly. A serpent lies along the ground in the lower left corner of the design. It lifts its head to look up with an open mouth. Its head casts a shadow on the stone or earth below.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. A flat bank runs across the bottom edge of the design; above it a stream rippled with wavelets is visible, especially nearer the right edge of the design. A small flat island is visible in the stream, right of center. A rock or small boulder appears above the lower left corner.
Wash across the top of the design suggests a dark sky, except for a lighter area in the upper left corner.

One of the sinners, a female, kneels at the left side of the design. Nude with visible breasts, she faces forward and to the right, with her legs bent and her right leg drawn up beneath her body. Her torso leans away and bends to the left slightly, and she may be resting some of her weight on her right arm, which is down. Her right hand rests on the ground, palm down. She leans her head sharply to the left so that her right cheek touches her right shoulder. Her head is also bent back, and her long curly hair cascades down behind her right arm. One strand of her hair lies along her left shoulder.

The head and right arm of another female thief are visible above and to the left of the female kneeling at the left side of the design. This second female's arm is down, and her right hand rests on the ground with palm down. Her head is tilted back and to the left, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile looking left. She leans her right cheek on her right shoulder. Her eyelids are lowered or closed. Her mouth may be open slightly. She has long curly hair.
An indistinct shape in the upper left corner of the design may be part of another thief.

One of the sinners, a female, kneels at the left side of the design facing forward and to the right. The upper body of another thief, a nude male, appears above and to the right of this female. His torso faces forward and to the left. He seems to lean back and may bend to the right slightly; he tilts his head back and turns it right, so that he looks up to the right. His left cheek may rest on his left shoulder. His eyes are raised and his mouth is slightly open.

A female thief stands at the center of the design, curving her nude body dramatically rightward. Her legs are together, slightly bent at the knees and facing away. Her lower body is thus seen from behind. She twists and bends to the right at the waist, curling her upper body over so that her shoulders and breasts face down. Her head is lowered and turned slightly forward, so that her face is visible in three-quarters profile beneath her right arm, which is raised horizontally and bent behind her head. Her long curly hair hangs down past her head. Her open left hand, with palm down and fingers spread, appears to the right of her head.

The body of another thief is positioned nearest the upper right corner of the design. This figure seems to be male. His head is hidden behind the head of the woman who stands at the center and curls her body rightward. He sits with his legs extended down to the left. His left leg is bent and raised slightly higher than the right. Both legs are hidden below the knee. He twists forward at the waist, and leans back. His upper right arm is visible almost to the elbow, down by his side. His left forearm is visible below his torso, down and drawn back. His left hand rests on the ground, palm down. Irregular lines above his hand may be his long curly hair, or may be more of the long hair of the woman whose head obscures his own.

A serpent's body undulates up between the knees of the male thief who sits near the upper right corner of the design. It curls over his left thigh, touching the ground next to his hip before lifting its head to look up.

A thief, visible between eyes and knees, lies supine in the lower right corner of the design. Though this figure is nude, it is difficult to tell whether the thief is male or female. Neither arm is visible. The figure's head is turned slightly forward.
A snake lies along the torso of the thief lying face-up in the lower right corner of the design. Its head is near the thief's breastbone, while its tail curls between the thief's legs.

The nude buttocks and waist of another thief, sitting in the distance and facing away, are visible above the hips of a male thief sitting near the upper right corner of the design. The position of his or her waist suggests this thief is leaning back slightly.
A serpent lies along the ground in the lower left corner of the design. It lifts its head to look up with an open mouth. Its head casts a shadow on the stone or earth below.

l.note: The word is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. This inscription is faint, in part because it is covered with blue wash.

desc.objtitle:
The Serpent Attacking Vanni Fucci The Serpent Biting Vanni Fucci,
Object 51 (Butlin 812.48)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat, bare earth. Three mountains cross the design above the floor of the trench: one mountain rises in the middle, overlapped by another to either side. Lines across the bottom of the mountain on the left and across the ridge of the mountain on the right suggest a road or path. Vanni Fucci, a thief who lied about having robbed the church of San Zeno, runs leftward in the foreground of this design. He strides facing left with his bent left leg forward and his bent right leg extended backward. His right foot is on tiptoe. He bends forward at the waist and tilts his head back, turning his face up to look up over his shoulder to the right. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open. His right arm is extended at 45 degrees in front of him, slightly bent; his right hand is open with fingers spread and palm down. His left arm is also slightly bent and raised at 45 degrees, but drawn back. His left palm is down. The head of a serpent is poised in the act of biting Vanni Fucci in the left shoulder. The reptile's body curls up to the right and then down behind Fucci's torso to the ground before his left foot. A row of fire burns across the design, in front of the mountains. More flames appear between Fucci's feet. Smaller flames may be visible in the distance on either side of Fucci's right hand and to the left and right of his left calf. Another serpent lies along the ground in the lower left corner of the design. This serpent's head is raised and looks forward. Its body curls to the right and then the left as it approaches the bottom of the design. Large spikes rise from its back along the length of its body. A third snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. Its head is raised and looks up to the right; it is seen from above and behind. Its body forms a loop below and to the left of its head. It may cast a thin shadow on the ground. A fourth snake undulates along the ground before the mountain on the right. Its head is raised and looks forward, while its body forms two or perhaps three curls extending to the left. A large cloud fills much of the sky above the central mountain. Rays of light stream from the sun as it sets behind the mountain. Wash around the rays suggests the ambient light from the sunset. Dark wash in the upper right and left corners of the design suggests a dark sky.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat, bare earth.

Three mountains cross the design above the floor of the trench: one mountain rises in the middle, overlapped by another to either side. Lines across the bottom of the mountain on the left and across the ridge of the mountain on the right suggest a road or path.

Vanni Fucci, a thief who lied about having robbed the church of San Zeno, runs leftward in the foreground of this design. He strides facing left with his bent left leg forward and his bent right leg extended backward. His right foot is on tiptoe. He bends forward at the waist and tilts his head back, turning his face up to look up over his shoulder to the right. His face is visible in three-quarters profile. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open. His right arm is extended at 45 degrees in front of him, slightly bent; his right hand is open with fingers spread and palm down. His left arm is also slightly bent and raised at 45 degrees, but drawn back. His left palm is down. He is nude and has rather long hair that streams behind his head.
Vanni Fucci casts a shadow on the ground between his feet.

The head of a serpent is poised in the act of biting Vanni Fucci in the left shoulder. The serpent's mouth is open around Fucci's trapezius muscle. Its body curls up to the right and then down behind Fucci's torso to the ground before his left foot. Spiky scales or a crest rises from its head.

A row of fire burns across the design, in front of the mountains. More flames appear between Fucci's feet. Smaller flames may be visible in the distance on either side of Fucci's right hand and to the left and right of his left calf.

A serpent lies along the ground in the lower left corner of the design. This serpent's head is raised and looks forward. Its body curls to the right and then the left as it approaches the bottom of the design. Large spikes rise from its back along the length of its body.

A third snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. Its head is raised and looks up to the right; it is seen from above and behind. Its body forms a loop below and to the left of its head. It may cast a thin shadow on the ground.
A fourth snake undulates along the ground before the mountain on the right. Its head is raised and looks forward, while its body forms two or perhaps three curls extending to the left.
A large cloud fills much of the sky above the central mountain.
Rays of light stream from the sun as it sets behind the central mountain. Wash around the rays suggests the ambient light from the sunset.
Dark wash in the upper right and left corners of the design suggests a dark sky.

l.note: The line is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. This inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Blue-gray wash obscures the final word.

desc.objtitle:
Vanni Fucci Making Figs Against God Vanni Fucci Makes a Blasphemous Gesture,
Object 52 (Butlin 812.49 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "34" top right, and "Pg Canto 9" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench, at the bottom of the design, consists of several levels of flat earth. Shadows cross the nearest level, closest to the bottom of the design. A rock bridge crosses from the lower right corner past the left edge of the design. A line of flames is visible rising from the ground beneath the arch of the bridge. Dark wash between the tongues of fire and the bridge suggests smoke. A rock cliff is visible at the right side of the design, beyond the base of the rock bridge. Dante and Virgil stand together at the right side of the design, facing forward. Dante, on the left, hides his companion slightly. He turns his head to the left so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His right arm (and apparently his left) are down by his side and bent up at the elbow; both of his hands are raised with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. Virgil, on the right, stands with his head turned slightly to the left as well. His left forearm is raised in front of his torso and his vertical palm faces out. The two figures stand on a small, flat rock ledge in the lower right corner of the design. The thief Vanni Fucci stands to the left of Dante and Virgil, facing forward. His right leg is bent and at least his right foot is on tiptoe. Both of his slightly bent arms are raised vertically. He uses both hands to taunt the gods with the sign of the "figs." His eyes are raised and his mouth is open. His short hair stands on end. A serpent circles Vanni Fucci's upraised left arm. Its head is raised, looking up with mouth open. Its body loops his arm loosely before undulating towards the ground below. Its tail dangles. Another serpent tightly encircles Vanni Fucci's neck, with its head lying facing down on his chest and its tail extended up above his head. Its mouth is open and its forked tongue emerges. A third serpent springs up towards Fucci's right arm, its head pointed up and to the right and its undulant body extended down to the left. Its mouth is open. Another, smaller snake lies on the ground behind Fucci's legs. It lifts its head up to the right. A large serpent is partially visible above the flat middle ground in front of the flames. Its body curls up and over to the left, so that its head faces down to the right. It is consuming a smaller snake. Only the tail of this second snake is visible, emerging from the larger creature's open mouth. Dark clouds cross the top of the design. Lightning snakes jaggedly down towards Vanni Fucci from the upper left corner. Flames burst from the dark clouds above and on either side of Fucci's upraised hands. Wash between the mountains and the clouds at the top of the design suggests the sky.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the seventh trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench, at the bottom of the design, consists of several levels of flat earth. Shadows cross the nearest level, closest to the bottom of the design.
A rock bridge crosses from the lower right corner past the left edge of the design.
A line of flames is visible rising from the ground beneath the arch of the bridge. Dark wash between the tongues of fire and the bridge suggests smoke.
A rock cliff is visible at the right side of the design, beyond the base of the rock bridge.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the right side of the design, facing forward. Dante, on the left, hides his companion slightly. He turns his head to the left so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His right arm (and probably his left) are down by his side and bent up at the elbow; both of his hands are raised with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. He wears a long gown and has long curly hair. The toes of his right foot peek from beneath the hem of his gown.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the right side of the design, facing forward. Virgil, on the right, is slightly behind his companion. He turns his head slightly to the left, so that his face is seen in partial profile. His left forearm is raised in front of his torso and his vertical palm faces out. He wears a long gown; his right foot is visible beneath its hem. He has long curly hair.
Dante and Virgil stand on a small, flat rock ledge in the lower right corner of the design.

The thief Vanni Fucci stands to the left of Dante and Virgil, facing forward. He is nude with visible genitals and well-defined musculature. His right leg is bent and at least his right foot is on tiptoe. Both of his slightly bent arms are raised vertically. He uses both hands to taunt the gods with the sign of the "figs." His eyes are raised and his mouth is open. His short hair stands on end.

A serpent circles Vanni Fucci's upraised left arm. Its head is raised, looking up with mouth open. Its body loops his arm loosely before undulating towards the ground below. Its tail dangles. Spiky scales or a crest appears on its head.

Another serpent tightly encircles Vanni Fucci's neck, with its head lying facing down on his chest and its tail extended up above his head. Its mouth is open and its forked tongue emerges. Small spiky scales or a crest appears behind its head.

A third serpent springs up towards Fucci's right arm, its head pointed up and to the right and its undulant body extended down to the left. Its mouth is open. Spiky scales or a crest appears on its head.
Another, smaller snake lies on the ground behind Fucci's legs. It lifts its head up to the right. Its body lies along the ground to the right. It may have small spiky scales behind its head.

A large serpent is partially visible above the flat middle ground in front of the flames. Its body curls up and over to the left, so that its head faces down to the right. It is consuming a smaller snake. Only the tail of this second snake is visible, emerging from the larger creature's open mouth.

Dark clouds cross the top of the design. Lightning snakes jaggedly down towards Vanni Fucci from the upper left corner. Flames burst from the dark clouds above and on either side of Fucci's upraised hands.
Wash between the mountains and the clouds at the top of the design suggests the sky.

desc.objtitle:
The Centaur Cacus The Centaur Cacus Threatens Vanni Fucci,
Object 53 (Butlin 812.50)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth. The figure of Cacus, a magnificent Centaur with the body of a horse and the head and torso of a man, fills the design. He stands on his hind legs facing left. His bent right foreleg is raised horizontally while his left foreleg is bent and drawn up beneath his body. His nude human torso twists forward at the waist and he extends his arms out horizontally to either side. He clasps a scepter or staff between the thumb and forefinger of his upraised left hand. The head of this scepter may be a pine cone. His right hand is open, with the palm down. His head is tilted left, and may be bent forward as well. He has a beard and long hair that cascades past his shoulders and rump. His horse's tail billows similarly. A small, scaly dragon perches on Cacus' head, its claws clutching his skull. Facing forward, it leans its head down to the left past Cacus' right temple. Its mouth is open, displaying its tongue and perhaps teeth. It expels a gust of fire and/or wind over Cacus' right shoulder. Spikes emerge from its head, shoulders, and back. Its bat-like wings are spread wide to either side of its body. Its long tail ripples behind Cacus, beneath his left arm. A faintly drawn rock bridge crosses the length of the design, behind Cacus. Wash at the top of the design, on either side of Cacus' torso, suggests the sky. Flames spring from the ground along the bottom of the design, particularly around Cacus' rear hooves. They are also visible in the distance under Cacus' abdomen. At least two serpents(?) lie on the ground in the distance, to the left of Cacus' left foreleg. They are sketched faintly, but seem to face forward with raised heads.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth.

The figure of Cacus, a magnificent Centaur with the body of a horse and the head and torso of a man, fills the design. He stands on his hind legs facing left. His bent right foreleg is raised horizontally while his left foreleg is bent and drawn up beneath his body. His nude human torso twists forward at the waist and he extends his arms out horizontally to either side. He clasps a scepter or staff between the thumb and forefinger of his upraised left hand. The head of this staff may be a pine cone. His right hand is open, with the palm down. His head is tilted left, and may be bent forward as well. He has a beard and long hair that cascades past his shoulders and rump. His horse's tail billows similarly.

A small, scaly dragon perches on Cacus' head, its claws clutching his skull. Facing forward, it leans its crested head down to the left past Cacus' right temple. Its mouth is open, displaying its tongue and perhaps teeth. It expels a gust of fire and/or wind over Cacus' right shoulder. Spikes emerge from its head, shoulders, and back. Its bat-like wings are spread wide to either side of its body. Its long tail ripples behind Cacus, beneath his left arm.
A faintly drawn rock bridge crosses the length of the design, behind Cacus.
Wash at the top of the design, on either side of Cacus' torso, suggests the sky. A few twisting lines, particularly on the right, might be flames.
Flames spring from the ground along the bottom of the design, particularly around Cacus' rear hooves. They are also visible in the distance under Cacus' abdomen.
At least two serpents(?) lie on the ground in the distance, to the left of Cacus' left foreleg. They are sketched faintly, but seem to face forward with raised heads.

lg.l: HELL Canto 25 The ink inscription, particularly the number, is offset to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle:
The Six-Footed Serpent Attacking Agnolo Brunelleschi The Six-Footed Serpent Attacks Agnello Brunelleschi,
Object 54 (Butlin 812.51 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "76" bottom left, "N 42 next at p 95" bottom center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Vanni Fucci Hell Canto 24" partly erased along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth. A mountain range with two low peaks crosses the design in the distance. A smaller, lower mound or hill appears in front of each mountain. Fire burns in the sky between the two mountains. Wash above the mountain range suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. It is dark near the upper right corner of the design, but light above the mountain on the left. Cianfa Donati, in the form of a many-limbed serpent, assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. Facing forward, Brunelleschi stands in a slightly crouching posture with his bent right leg forward and his bent left leg back slightly. His head is bent sharply left by the serpent, which bites his jaw, and his mouth and eyes are wide with horror and pain. His slightly bent right arm is extended at 45 degrees and drawn back. His right hand is open, with fingers spread and palm out. His left arm is at his side, bent up at the elbow with the palm of this hand facing the viewer and the fingers spread. The giant serpent attacking Brunelleschi bends or hunches forward over the man's back and clutches him with all six clawed feet, its limbs bent around his body. It lowers its head over the man's left shoulder to seize his jaw in its own open mouth. Its long, snake-like tail emerges from between Brunelleschi's legs and coils twice around his right leg before trailing onto the ground. The monster's large, bat-like wings appear above its shoulders. A small rocky outcropping rises in the lower left corner of the design. It may be covered with indistinct vegetation, perhaps grass. Dante and Virgil stand together on a ledge in this outcropping. Dante stands to the left, facing forward and partly hiding Virgil. His straight arms are down by his side; his hands are open with palms down and fingers spread. He bends his head down to the right, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile, with his eyes lowered. Virgil, slightly to the right of Dante, stands facing forward and to the right. His head is lowered and he holds his forearms across his torso. Two male figures stand together at the right side of the design. Nude, they represent the spirits of Puccio Sciancato and Buoso Donati, Brunelleschi's fellow robbers. Their individual identities are not distinguished. The rightmost figure hides his companion slightly and faces away. He stands in a contrapposto position, bending left at the waist with most of his weight on his right leg; his left leg is bent and extended backwards, with his left foot on tiptoe. He turns his head left and bends it down, so that his face is seen in profile looking down to the left. His right forearm, bent upward, is visible at the right of his torso. His right hand as well as his left hand, which appears above his right shoulder, are open with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure on the left faces forward in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight shifted to his left leg and his right leg bent backwards. He bends and twists slightly to the left and turns his head left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. Both of his forearms are raised horizontally, with his hands open, fingers spread, and palms out. Snakes abound on the floor of the trench. One appears to the right of Brunelleschi's feet, its body forming two incomplete loops and its head raised to look forward. The heads of two snakes are visible to the right of the rocky outcropping in the lower left corner of the design. Side-by-side, both look up; they may be watching the six-footed serpent attack Brunelleschi. Between Brunelleschi and Virgil, a snake appears in the distance on the floor of the trench. Its body coils into three raised loops. To the right of Brunelleschi's left hip, another serpent is visible in the distance undulating along the floor of the trench. Its head seems to be raised; it looks up. Just below the mountain on the right, a snake's body curves up from the floor of the trench. The head of another serpent is raised just to the left of the right edge of the design. It looks forward and to the left with its mouth open. The head and part of the body of a snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. The reptile's head is raised and looks left with its mouth open, displaying a fang and perhaps an extended tongue.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be bare earth.
A mountain range with two low peaks crosses the design in the distance. A smaller, lower mound or hill appears in front of each mountain.
Fire burns in the sky between the two mountains.
Wash above the mountain range suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. It is dark near the upper right corner of the design, but light above the mountain on the left.

A many-limbed serpent assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. Facing forward, Brunelleschi stands in a slightly crouching posture with his bent right leg forward and his bent left leg back slightly. Both feet seem to be on tiptoe. His head is bent sharply left by the serpent, which bites his jaw, and his mouth and eyes are wide with horror and pain. His open mouth displays his teeth and tongue. His right cheek may touch his right shoulder. His eyes are swiveled to the right towards the head of the serpent, and his short hair stands up. His slightly bent right arm is extended at 45 degrees and drawn back. His right hand is open, with fingers spread and palm out. His left arm is at his side, bent up at the elbow with the palm of this hand facing the viewer and the fingers spread. He casts a small shadow on the ground by his feet.

Cianfa Donati, in the form of a scaly limbed serpent, somewhat lizard-like, assaults Agnolo Brunelleschi, a nude and rather muscular male thief who stands at the center of the design. The giant creature bends or hunches forward over the man's back and clutches him with all six clawed feet, its limbs bent around his body. It lowers its head over the man's left shoulder and seizes his jaw in its own open mouth, bending his head sharply left. A hornlike protuberance grows from its head. Its long, snake-like tail emerges from between Brunelleschi's legs and coils twice around his right leg before trailing onto the ground. The monster's large, bat-like wings appear above its shoulders.
A small rocky outcropping rises in the lower left corner of the design. It may be covered with indistinct vegetation, perhaps grass.

Dante and Virgil stand together on a small ledge in the rocky outcropping at the left side of the design. Dante stands to the left, facing forward and partly hiding Virgil. He wears a long gown, but the shape of his shoulders and hips beneath it suggests that he stands in contrapposto. His straight arms are down by his side; his hands are open with palms down and fingers spread. He bends his head down to the right, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile, with his eyes lowered. He has long curly hair.

Dante and Virgil stand together on a small ledge in the rocky outcropping at the left side of the design. Virgil stands slightly to the right of Dante, facing forward and to the right. His head is lowered, and he holds his forearms across his torso. He grasps his right wrist with his left hand; his right hand rests on his chest. He wears a long gown and has long curly hair.

Two male figures stand together at the right side of the design. Both are nude. They represent the spirits of Puccio Sciancato and Buoso Donati, Brunelleschi's fellow robbers. Their individual identities are not distinguished. The rightmost figure hides his companion slightly and faces away. He stands in a contrapposto position, bending left at the waist with most of his weight on his right leg; his left leg is bent and extended backwards, with his left foot on tiptoe. He turns his head left and bends it down, so that his face is seen in profile looking down to the left. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his short hair stands on end. His right forearm, bent upward, is visible at the right of his torso. His right hand as well as his left hand, which appears above his right shoulder, are open with palms facing forward and fingers spread. The figure on the left faces forward in a slightly contrapposto position, with his weight shifted to his left leg and his right leg bent backwards. His right foot is on tiptoe. He bends and twists slightly to the left and turns his head left, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. Both of his forearms are raised horizontally, with his hands open, fingers spread, and palms out. His long curly hair falls over his shoulders. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth. His genitals are pictured.

Snakes abound on the floor of the trench. One appears to the right of Brunelleschi's feet, its body forming two incomplete loops and its head raised to look forward. It has several spiky scales behind its head and on its back, and a small whisker on either side of its snout. It casts a thin shadow on the ground.

The heads of two snakes are visible to the right of the rocky outcropping in the lower left corner of the design. Side-by-side, both look up; they may be watching the six-footed serpent attack Brunelleschi. They cast a shadow on the ground to the right.

Between Brunelleschi and Virgil, a snake appears in the distance on the floor of the trench. Its body coils into three raised loops. Its head is not visible. It seems to cast a shadow on the ground below.
To the right of Brunelleschi's left hip, another serpent is visible in the distance undulating along the floor of the trench. Its head seems to be raised; it looks up. It may have an extended tongue.

Just below the mountain on the right, a snake's body curves up from the floor of the trench. Its head is not clearly defined, but may be raised to look forward and/or left. Its shadow falls on the ground below and the small hill behind.
The head of a serpent is raised just to the left of the right edge of the design. It looks forward and to the left with its mouth open.

The head and part of the body of a snake appears in the lower right corner of the design. The reptile's head is raised and looks left with its mouth open, displaying a fang and perhaps an extended tongue.

desc.objtitle:
Agnolo Brunelleschi Half Transformed by the Serpent Agnello Brunelleschi Transformed by the Serpent,
Object 55 (Butlin 812.52)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "73" top left, "N 48 next at p. 57" at the top, "Hell Canto 25" partly erased along the right margin, and fragments of an erased inscription (probably the same as the one along the right margin) in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat bare earth. Two rock bridges cross the scene in the background of the design. One arches rightward from the left edge of the design. The second bridge extends leftward from the right edge of the design, and partially hides the base of the first. Clouds extend almost completely across the top of the design. Lightning erupts leftward from the cloud in the upper left corner, and flames burst from underneath the same cloud. Wash between the clouds and the rock bridges suggests the sky, which is dark above the left bridge where the lightning suggests a storm, and lighter across the rest of the design. The figure of Agnolo Brunelleschi, who is depicted here in the process of merging with the six-footed serpent from the previous design, fills much of this design. Nude, he stands at the center, facing forward and slightly left. His slightly bent left arm is down by his side, with the hand open, the fingers spread, and the palm facing away. His right arm is also down, but bent out to the left at the elbow. His head is bent sharply right, so that his left cheek touches his left shoulder. He bends backwards and his frame, especially in the shoulders and arms, seems to convulse. His staring eyes are rolled upwards and his lips are drawn into a grimace, displaying teeth that have become pointed. Tusks have emerged above his mouth. Short, curly human hair covers his head, but scales have begun to appear on his skin. They are particularly noticeable on his cheeks, his chest, his pubic area, and his thighs. His nails have sharpened into claws, especially on his feet. A long tail now snakes down through his legs and across his left ankle. Small bat-like wings grow above his shoulders. A large snake lies loosely coiled on the ground at Brunelleschi's feet. Its head is near the lower left corner of the design, facing right and possibly raised slightly to look at Brunelleschi. The snake's mouth is open. A spiky crest appears on and behind his head. Flames spring from the ground beneath the bridge on the right. The head and part of the body of a serpent curls up from the ground, out of the flames. The head of the serpent faces right. Flames also fill the space between the ground and the bottom of the bridge on the left. The head of a serpent appears before these flames as well. It is raised and looks forward. Another snake is partly visible between the two bridges. Its body emerges to the left but curls around so that its head faces forward and to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat bare earth.

Two rock bridges cross the scene in the background of the design. One arches rightward from the left edge of the design. The second bridge extends leftward from the right edge of the design, and partially hides the base of the first.
Clouds extend almost completely across the top of the design. Lightning erupts leftward from the cloud in the upper left corner, and flames burst from underneath the same cloud.
Wash between the clouds and the rock bridges suggests the sky, which is dark above the left bridge where the lightning suggests a storm, and lighter across the rest of the design.

The figure of Agnolo Brunelleschi, who is depicted here in the process of merging with the six-footed serpent from the previous design, fills much of this design. Nude, he stands at the center, facing forward and slightly left. Both legs are slightly bent. His slightly bent left arm is down by his side, with the hand open, the fingers spread, and the palm facing away. His right arm is also down, but bent out to the left at the elbow. His right palm faces out from his hip. His head is bent sharply right, so that his left cheek touches his left shoulder. He bends backwards and his frame, especially in the shoulders and arms, seems to convulse. His staring eyes are rolled upwards and his lips are drawn into a grimace, displaying teeth that have become pointed. Tusks have emerged above his mouth. Short, curly human hair covers his head, but scales have begun to appear on his skin. They are particularly noticeable on his cheeks, his chest, his pubic area, and his thighs. His nails have sharpened into claws, especially on his feet. A long tail now snakes down through his legs and across his left ankle. Small bat-like wings grow above his shoulders.

A large snake lies loosely coiled on the ground at Brunelleschi's feet. Its head is near the lower left corner of the design, facing right and possibly raised slightly to look at Brunelleschi. The snake's mouth is open. A spiky crest appears on and behind his head.
Flames spring from the ground beneath the bridge on the right.
The head and part of the body of a serpent curls up from the ground, out of the flames beneath the arch of the bridge on the right. The head of the serpent faces right.
Flames fill the space between the ground and the bottom of the bridge on the left.
The head of a serpent appears before the flames beneath the arch of the bridge on the left. It is raised and looks forward.
Another snake is partly visible between the two bridges. Its body emerges to the left but curls around so that its head faces forward and to the right.
