l.note: The word is written vertically, reading from bottom to top. The inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle:
The Serpent Attacking Buoso Donati The Serpent Attacks Buoso De' Donati,
Object 56 (Butlin 812.53 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "72" top center, "N39 next at p 69" top center, the latter in the center of the sheet, and "HELL Canto 23" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat earth. Tongues of fire leap from the floor of the trench nearly to the top of the design, forming a backdrop extending horizontally across the design. Clouds also cross the top of the design. More flames burst downward from the clouds in the upper left corner. Buoso Donati stands at the right side of the design; he has just been bitten by a snake. He is nude and his navel displays the wound from the serpent's bite. He bends to the left at the waist and lowers his head to look down at the serpent below and to the left. His mouth is open in a yawn, as Dante's text describes, displaying his teeth and tongue. Alternatively, he may be crying out in pain. His expression suggests surprised confusion. The short hair around his head stands on end; longer locks fall past his shoulders. Both of his arms are down, but bent upward at the elbow. His right arm crosses his torso with his open right hand raised, vertical palm facing away and fingers spread. His left arm is raised to the right with the palm of this hand facing out and up to the right and the fingers spread. The snake that has just bitten Buoso Donati appears below him to the left. It seems to be suspended in the air in the process of falling back to earth. Both the wound and the serpent emit smoke, together forming a cloud that links the snake's mouth with the injury it created. Dante and Virgil stand together at the left edge of the design, on a slightly raised stone mound in the lower left corner. Dante stands slightly to the left of Virgil, facing forward. He bends to the right and turns his head rightward so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is also bent down slightly. His arms are down by his side and bent at the elbows, so that his forearms are horizontal. His hands are raised, with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. Virgil, to the right of and slightly hidden by Dante, faces forward and to the right. He bends his head and turns it right, so that his face is visible in profile. The nude figure of Puccio Sciancato, one of Brunelleschi's fellow robbers, stands just to the right of Dante and Virgil. Sciancato stands in an awkward posture: his lower body faces right but he twists forward at the waist, while his shoulders face slightly left. He turns his slightly bent head back to the right, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile looking right. He also leans backward slightly, away from Buoso Donati. His right arm is extended down by his side and drawn back, with the palm of his open right hand facing down. His left arm is bent up at the elbow and drawn across his torso. His left hand makes a fist and may rest on his breastbone. His right leg is forward, while his left leg is drawn back. His mouth is open. His facial expression and his body language together suggest fear. A snake is crawling across the ground behind Sciancato. It faces left and moves with its mouth open. Small flames burn in a line across the floor of the trench. Faint lines suggest that these flames begin at the left edge of the design, to the left of Dante's legs, but they are first clearly visible between Virgil and Sciancato. They extend as far right as Donati's right leg.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench seems to be flat earth.
Tongues of fire leap from the floor of the trench nearly to the top of the design, forming a backdrop extending horizontally across the design.
Clouds cross the top of the design.
Flames burst downward from the clouds in the upper left corner.

Buoso Donati stands at the right side of the design; he has just been bitten by a snake. He is nude and his navel displays the wound from the serpent's bite. He stands with his left leg straight and his right leg bent, with his right foot on tiptoe. He bends to the left at the waist and lowers his head to look down at the serpent below and to the left. His mouth is open in a yawn, as Dante's text describes, displaying his teeth and tongue. Alternatively, he may be crying out in pain. His expression suggests surprised confusion. The short hair around his head stands on end; longer locks fall past his shoulders. Both of his arms are down, but bent upward at the elbow. His right arm crosses his torso with his open right hand raised, vertical palm facing away and fingers spread. His left arm is raised to the right with the palm of this hand facing out and up to the right and the fingers spread. His genitals are pictured.

The snake that has just bitten Buoso Donati appears below him to the left. It seems to be suspended in the air in the process of falling back to earth. The end of its tail may rest along Donati's right thigh; the rest of its body curls around to form an incomplete loop so that its head faces back up to the right towards Donati's face. Small spiky scales or a crest appears behind its head. Its mouth is open slightly.
Both the wound and the serpent emit smoke, together forming a cloud that links the snake's mouth with the injury it created.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the left edge of the design. Dante stands to the left of Virgil, facing forward. He bends to the right and turns his head rightward so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His head is also bent down slightly. His arms are down by his side and bent at the elbows, so that his forearms are horizontal. His hands are raised, with vertical palms facing out towards the viewer. He has long curly hair and wears a long gown that pools on the ground beneath him.

Dante and Virgil stand together at the left edge of the design. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, slightly hidden by him, and faces forward and to the right. He bends his head and turns it right, so that his face is visible in profile. Neither of his arms is visible. He has long curly hair, and wears a long gown.
Dante and Virgil stand on a slightly raised stone mound in the lower left corner of the design.

The nude figure of Puccio Sciancato, one of Brunelleschi's fellow robbers, stands just to the right of Dante and Virgil. Sciancato stands in an awkward posture: his lower body faces right but he twists forward at the waist, while his shoulders face slightly left. He turns his slightly bent head back to the right, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile looking right. He also leans backward slightly, away from Buoso Donati. His right arm is extended down by his side and drawn back, with the palm of his open right hand facing down. His left arm is bent up at the elbow and drawn across his torso. His left hand makes a fist and may rest on his breastbone. His right leg is forward, while his left leg is drawn back. His mouth is open. His facial expression and his body language together suggest fear. He has short curly hair.
A snake is crawling across the ground behind Sciancato. It faces left and moves with its mouth open.

Small flames burn in a line across the floor of the trench. Faint lines suggest that the flames begin at the left edge of the design, to the left of Dante's legs, but they are first clearly visible between Virgil and Sciancato. They extend as far right as Donati's right leg.

desc.objtitle:
Buoso Donati Transformed into a Serpent; Francesco De' Cavalcanti Retransformed from a Serpent into a Man The Transformation of Serpent into Man Completed,
Object 57 (Butlin 812.54)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "94" bottom left, "7" at the right margin, and "No 11 next at p 54" partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench suggests flat, bare earth. Two rock bridges cross the design in the background. The foremost is almost entirely visible, emerging from the left side of the design and arching to the right. The second is partially hidden behind the first, and also extends beyond the right edge of the design. A heavy cloud extends across the upper edge of the design from corner to corner. Tongues of fire rain down to touch the bridges from the cloud above. Wash visible between the flames at the top of the design, beneath the cloud, suggests a sky that is lit with fire at the left and dark with smoke at the right. Fire burns below the bridge on the right. A smaller cloud, or perhaps a column of smoke from the flames beneath the bridge on the right, rises diagonally across the upper right corner of the design. Flames burn beneath the foremost bridge as well, at both bases. Erratic lines above both fires suggest small clouds of smoke. Francesco Guercio de' Cavalcanti stands facing forward just to the left of the middle of the design, near the bottom. His weight is shifted to his right leg; his left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are raised horizontally out from his torso, and bent up vertically at the elbows. Both hands are open, with fingers spread and vertical palms facing forward. His head is turned slightly left. His eyes are raised. His mouth is open, displaying his tongue and teeth. His curly hair, which is short around his head and long at the nape of his neck, stands on end. Buoso Donati, in the form of a large serpent, lies near the bottom of the design. Most of its body lies horizontally behind de' Cavalcanti. Its head is to the right, raised and lifted to look left and up towards de' Cavalcanti's head. Its mouth is open. After crossing behind de' Cavalcanti's feet, its body and the end of its tail trails away into the distance up to the right. Another snake is penciled in lightly along the ground on the right, just before the bridges. Its head faces left, and is raised with mouth open. An undulating line beneath the fire at the left base of the foremost bridge may represent a third snake, indistinctly drawn.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in a trench in the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench suggests flat, bare earth.

Two rock bridges cross the design in the background. The foremost is almost entirely visible, emerging from the left side of the design and arching to the right. The second is partially hidden behind the first, and also extends beyond the right edge of the design.
A heavy cloud extends across the upper edge of the design from corner to corner.
Tongues of fire rain down to touch the bridges from the cloud above.
Wash visible between the flames at the top of the design, beneath the cloud, suggests a sky that is lit with fire at the left and dark with smoke at the right.
Fire burns below the bridge on the right.
A smaller cloud, or perhaps a column of smoke from the flames beneath the bridge on the right, rises diagonally across the upper right corner of the design.
Flames burn beneath the foremost bridge as well, at both bases. Erratic lines above both fires suggest small clouds of smoke.

Francesco Guercio de' Cavalcanti stands facing forward just to the left of the middle of the design, near the bottom. He is nude. His weight is shifted to his right leg; his left leg is bent and his left foot is on tiptoe. His arms are raised horizontally out from his torso, and bent up vertically at the elbows. Both hands are open, with fingers spread and vertical palms facing forward. His head is turned slightly left. His eyes are raised. His mouth is open, displaying his tongue and teeth. His curly hair, which is short around his head and long at the nape of his neck, stands on end.

Buoso Donati, in the form of a large serpent, lies near the bottom of the design. Most of its body lies horizontally behind de' Cavalcanti. Its head is to the right, raised and lifted to look left and up towards de' Cavalcanti's head. Its mouth is open. After crossing behind de' Cavalcanti's feet, its body and the end of its tail trails away into the distance up to the right.
Another snake is penciled in lightly along the ground on the right, just before the bridges. Its head faces left, and is raised with mouth open.
An undulating line beneath the fire at the left base of the foremost bridge may represent a third snake, indistinctly drawn.

l.note: The number is written vertically, reading from bottom to top.

desc.objtitle:
Ulysses and Diomed Swathed in the Same Flame Ulysses and Diomedes Wrapped in the Same Flame,
Object 58 (Butlin 812.55)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "58" top right, and "Pg canto 13" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. A rock bridge fills much of this design. Its bases are located in the lower left and right corners, and it curves through the top half of the design. The ground below the bridge seems to be flat earth. Through the arch of the bridge, in the distance, a low mound or small hill appears. Wash above and below the arch of the bridge suggests the sky. It is light in the upper right corner as well as near the base of the bridge on the right. The sky grows increasingly dark across the segment visible beneath the bridge, and is darkest in the upper left corner of the design. Shadow falls on the floor of the trench in the lower left corner of the design. Dante and Virgil perch on the bridge, near the top of the design. They are sketched lightly in pencil, so their features are difficult to discern and their identities difficult to tell apart. Both figures face forward. The figure on the left seems to sit with right knee drawn up. His right arm, bent up at the elbow, rests on his right knee. His raised right hand is at his chin. The figure on the right seems to sit with both knees bent and drawn up. His right hand is also bent up at the elbow, with elbow drawn forward and resting on right knee. His raised right hand may rest against his shoulder or breastbone area. His lower left arm may be similarly raised, visible to the right of his left shoulder, or may be extended down to the left. A third figure is very lightly sketched left of Dante and Virgil; this may be an alternative version of either character. Flames like large individual bulbs appear on the floor of the trench, each sending a tendril of fire upward. Each holds the spirit of an advisor who lied. Indistinct lines within the nearest flames suggest the presence of a figure inside each. The figure in the largest flame, nearest the bottom of the design, seems to sit facing forward with bent legs drawn up. One large flame with two points hovers near Dante and Virgil. Ulysses and Diomed are visible within this flame. The penciled figure of Ulysses sits at the right of the flame, facing forward and turning his head slightly right; he may be looking at Dante and Virgil on the bridge to the right. His form is somewhat indistinct, but his bent right leg seems to be drawn beneath him, while his bent left knee is raised. His right arm is down by his side, but bent at the elbow across his chest; his right hand may be raised or may rest against his left knee or left shoulder. Diomed is also visible within the same large flame that hovers near the summit of the rock bridge. He is seen mostly from behind; he bends right at the waist and his head and shoulders extend into the leftmost of the double points on the flame in which he appears with Ulysses. His upper body is turned partly to the right, so that his face is seen in profile looking right. His left arm is raised vertically overhead, and his upraised left hand is open with vertical palm facing out. His left leg extends down to the right. He seems to wear a gown, folds of which are visible to the right of his right thigh.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the eighth circle of hell. A rock bridge fills much of this design. Its bases are located in the lower left and right corners, and it curves through the top half of the design.

Dante and Virgil perch on the rock bridge, near the top of the design. They are sketched lightly in pencil, so their features are difficult to discern and their identities difficult to tell apart. Both figures face forward, and seem to be wearing gowns. The figure on the left seems to sit with right knee drawn up. His right arm, bent up at the elbow, rests on his right knee. His raised right hand is at his chin, and may rest on or support his chin. The figure on the right seems to sit with both knees bent and drawn up. His right hand is also bent up at the elbow, with elbow drawn forward and resting on right knee. His raised right hand may rest against his shoulder or breastbone area. He bends to the left slightly and may turn his head slightly left as well. His lower left arm may be similarly raised, visible to the right of his left shoulder, or may be extended down by his left leg. A third figure, or an alternative position for Dante or Virgil, is very lightly sketched just to the left of the others. He(?) appears to be standing, head bent down and facing to the left.
The ground below the bridge seems to be flat earth. Through the arch of the bridge, in the distance, a low mound or small hill appears.

Wash above and below the arch of the bridge suggests the sky. It is light in the upper right corner as well as near the base of the bridge on the right. The sky grows increasingly dark across the segment visible beneath the bridge, and is darkest in the upper left corner of the design. Yellow and rose colors upper left in the sky suggest a sunrise or sunset or possibly the fires of hell.
Shadow falls on the floor of the trench in the lower left corner of the design.

Flames like large individual bulbs appear on the floor of the trench, each sending a tendril of fire upward. Each holds the spirit of an advisor who lied. Indistinct lines within the nearest flames suggest the presence of a figure inside each. The figure in the largest flame, nearest the bottom of the design, seems to sit facing forward with bent legs drawn up
One large flame with two points hovers near Dante and Virgil. Ulysses and Diomed are visible within the flame.

The penciled figure of Ulysses sits within the large double-pointed flame that hovers near Dante and Virgil. Ulysses sits at the right of the flame, facing forward and turning his head slightly right. His form is somewhat indistinct, but his bent right leg seems to be drawn beneath him, while his bent left knee is raised. He may be wearing a gown that swathes his lower limbs. His right arm is down by his side, but bent at the elbow across his chest. His right hand may be raised, or may rest against his left knee or his left shoulder. His left arm is not visible. His mouth seems to be open, and may display teeth. His eyes seem to be raised towards Dante and Virgil, who sit on the bridge above and to the right. He seems to have short hair, and may also have a beard.

Diomed is visible within the same large flame that hovers near Dante and Virgil. He is seen mostly from behind; he bends right at the waist and his head and shoulders extend into the leftmost of the double points on the flame in which he appears with Ulysses. His upper body is turned partly to the right, so that his face is seen in profile looking right. He seems to have short hair. His left arm is raised vertically overhead, and his upraised left hand is open with vertical palm facing out. His left leg extends down to the right. It may be slightly bent. He seems to wear a gown, folds of which are visible to the right of his right thigh.

desc.objtitle:
The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Mohammed The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Mohammed and Ali,
Object 59 (Butlin 812.56 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "17" top right, "N 9 next at p 18" top center, "No 9 next at p 18" partly erased in the center of the sheet, "One of the whirlwinds of love" center right, and "Hell Canto 5 Paulo and Francesca" bottom right. These last two inscriptions apparently refer to the pencil drawing on the verso and not to the water color on the recto. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in hell. Most of the figures stand on a flat, narrow bank that runs across the bottom of the design from corner to corner. This bank may be covered with grass or moss. Above it a lake stretches the length of the design. Above the lake, two rock bridges arch across the design. Flames, visible through the arch of the foremost bridge on the left, burn on the surface of the lake. They may create smoke as well. Large flames also burn in a line above the bridges. More flames burn beneath the farther bridge. They blow to the right, as if in a wind, and seem to produce clouds of smoke. Wash above and below the bridges suggests the sky, which is light near the upper right corner and below the foremost bridge, but darker in the upper left corner and below the bridge on the right. Bertrand de Born, a tiny headless figure, walks down the foremost bridge. In his left hand he bears his own head, which sends out beams of light like a lantern. Its mouth may be open. A small island, perhaps covered with moss or grass, breaks the surface of the lake in the lower right quadrant of the design. A nude male demon wielding a sword stands on this little island. He faces forward in contrapposto, raising his right arm vertically overhead and brandishing the sword in this hand. His left arm is down, bent out to the right at the elbow, with his left wrist and hand hidden behind his back. His bat-like wings are raised vertically behind his back. Three sinners, representing schismatics or heretics, cower in the lower right quadrant beneath the demon with the sword. The sinner farthest right is a rather muscular nude male, who stands or strides facing left with his bent right leg forward. His left leg is extended backwards and his left foot and ankle may be missing. He leans forward and raises his right arm roughly vertically. His head is bent back sharply, so that he can look up at the demon towering above. His left arm is extended down and crosses the far side of his right knee; his left elbow may rest against the outside of this leg. The male sinner in the middle of this group stands or steps facing left. His bent left leg is forward; his bent right leg is extended behind him, with his right foot on tiptoe. Bending forward, he twists at the waist, so that his torso faces right and slightly forward. He also tilts his head back to look up at the demon above and to the right. His right arm is down but bent across his torso at the elbow. His left arm, slightly bent, is drawn back and raised vertically. The leftmost of the three sinners before the demon stands or walks to the left with bent left leg forward. He bends forward and twists at the waist, so that his torso faces forward and right. His head is tilted back and turned slightly right. His left forearm is visible above the head of his companion, extended vertically upward. His right arm is down, bent across his chest at the elbow and partially hidden by his companion. Blood stains his leg near the knee. Blood has also pooled on the ground beneath the three sinners who cower in the lower right quadrant, and appears on the gown of the middle figure. It also floats on the surface of the water between the bank where they stand and the island where the demon stands. Dante and Virgil stand together near the middle of the design, at the bottom. Dante is slightly right of Virgil, facing forward. Both of his arms are by his side but bent at the elbow. His right forearm crosses his chest and his upraised right hand is open with the vertical palm facing out and right. His left arm is drawn back, and his left hand is open with the vertical palm facing out towards the viewer. His head is tilted back to the left, and his eyes are wide with fear and shock. He may be looking at Mohammed, to the left. Virgil, slightly left of Dante, is largely hidden by him. Virgil faces forward but tilts his head back and turns it slightly to the left. His right arm, the only one that is even partly visible, is bent across his chest. He has long hair and wears a long gown. Mohammed stands to the left of Dante and Virgil. He faces forward. Nude, his torso is rent down the middle, displaying his vital organs. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and bent towards his torso at the elbow. With a hand on each side of his gaping laceration, he peels his skin back to show the organs inside. His viscera spill out of this wound and down past his genitals. A loop of his intestines circles around his head, over his shoulders; more of his intestines are visible below his right forearm, partially hidden behind his back. He has long hair and a long beard. Ali stands in the lower left corner of the design. Contrapposto in position, he faces forward with his right leg bent forward slightly and his right foot on tiptoe. His arms are folded across his chest, with his right forearm over his left wrist. His left hand rests on his chest, while his right hand is raised with the palm roughly vertical and facing right. A vertical cut through the center of his face drips blood from his chin. He is nude and has short curly hair. Three sinners proceed leftward, away from the demon that stands near the right side of the design. One is visible to the left of Virgil and partly hidden by him. This figure faces left with shoulders hunched and head bowed low. The figure's left arm is by its side and bent up before its torso. Its long hair is swept away over its neck and appears below its left elbow. It wears a long gown with a belt. The second of the sinners proceeding leftward is nude and walks or lunges between Ali and Mohammed, crouched low near the ground. His bent right leg is forward; his bent left leg is extended backward with his left knee near the ground. His shoulders are hunched and his head is lowered. His left arm is extended down by his side. His left hand is missing, as his arm is truncated above the wrist. The third of the sinners proceeding leftward is visible in the lower left corner, facing left and partly hidden by Ali. Its head is lowered and its shoulders are hunched. Its left arm is down but bent up at the elbow and its hand is by its head, perhaps resting on its hair. It seems to have long hair that falls over its shoulder and appears hanging below its raised forearm. It wears a long gown.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in hell. Most of the figures stand on a flat, narrow bank that runs across the bottom of the design from corner to corner. This bank may be covered with grass or moss. Above it a lake stretches the length of the design. Waves ripple across the surface of the lake.

Above the lake, two rock bridges arch across the design. The foremost bridge emerges from the left edge of the design and descends through the middle. The left side of its base breaks the water, while the right side seems connected to a bank of the lake that extends to the right side of the design. This bridge seems to cast a shadow on the surface of the water below. The second bridge emerges from the right edge of the design and curves through the upper right quadrant into the middle. Its left base is mostly obscured by the foremost bridge.
Flames, visible through the arch of the foremost bridge, burn on the surface of the lake. They may create smoke as well.
Large flames burn in a line above the bridges.
More flames burn beneath the farther bridge. They blow to the right, as if in a wind, and seem to produce clouds of smoke.
Wash above and below the bridges suggests the sky, which is light near the upper right corner and below the foremost bridge, but darker in the upper left corner and below the bridge on the right.

The tiny headless figure of Bertrand de Born walks down the foremost bridge. Apparently nude, he steps to the right along the bridge with his right foot leg forward and his slightly bent left leg extended backwards, his left foot on tiptoe. His torso is turned forward slightly. Both arms are extended down by his sides. In his left hand he bears his own head, which sends out beams of light like a lantern. Its mouth may be open.
A small island, perhaps covered with moss or grass, breaks the surface of the lake in the lower right quadrant of the design.

A nude male demon wielding a sword stands on the little island. He faces forward in contrapposto, with his weight shifted largely to his left leg and his right leg bent forward. His right foot is on tiptoe. His left arm is down, bent out to the right at the elbow, with his left wrist and hand hidden behind his back. He raises his slightly bent right arm vertically overhead, brandishing the sword in this hand; its blade angles down to the right over his head. His head is tilted back and turned slightly to the right, and his eyes are raised. He has short curly hair. His bat-like wings are raised vertically behind his back. He casts a small shadow on the island, between his feet.

Three sinners, representing schismatics or heretics, cower in the lower right quadrant beneath the demon with the sword. The sinner farthest right is a rather muscular nude male, who stands or strides facing left. His bent right leg is forward and his weight rests on his right foot. His left leg is extended backwards and may be bent away at the knee so that his lower leg forms an awkward angle and is difficult to see. Alternatively, his leg may end between the knee and ankle. He leans forward and raises his right arm roughly vertically. His right hand is open with the palm facing up. His head is bent back sharply, so that he can look up at the demon towering above. His mouth gapes open. His left arm is extended down and crosses the far side of his right knee; his left elbow may rest against the outside of this leg. His left hand is open, with the palm facing out. Tendrils of his short curly hair extend behind his head.

Three sinners, representing schismatics or heretics, cower in the lower right quadrant beneath the demon with the sword. The male sinner in the middle of this group stands or steps facing left. His bent left leg is forward; his bent right leg is extended behind him, with his right foot on tiptoe. Bending forward, he twists at the waist, so that his torso faces right and slightly forward. He also tilts his head back to look up at the demon above and to the right. His mouth is open, his eyes are raised, and his features are creased with fear. His right arm is down but bent across his torso at the elbow. His right hand is open, with the palm away. His left arm, slightly bent, is drawn back and raised vertically with the vertical palm of his left hand facing out towards the viewer and his fingers spread. He wears a long gown; blood stains its skirts and puddles on the ground below him. He has long hair and a long beard. He casts a shadow on the ground below.

Three sinners, representing schismatics or heretics, cower in the lower right quadrant beneath the demon with the sword. The leftmost of these, slightly obscured by the sinner in the middle, stands or walks to the left with bent left leg forward. He bends forward and twists at the waist, so that his torso faces forward and right. His head is tilted back and turned slightly right. His mouth hangs open, showing his tongue and perhaps his teeth, and his wide, upraised eyes are swiveled to the right to look at the demon above. His short hair stands on end with fright. His left forearm is visible above the head of his companion, extended vertically upward with hand open and palm facing out and up. His right arm is down, bent across his chest at the elbow and partially hidden by his companion. He may be nude. Blood stains his leg near the knee.

Blood has pooled on the ground beneath the three sinners who cower in the lower right quadrant. It also floats on the surface of the water between the bank where they stand and the island where the demon stands.

Dante and Virgil stand together near the middle of the design, at the bottom. Dante is slightly right of Virgil, facing forward. Both of his arms are by his side but bent at the elbow. His right forearm crosses his chest and his upraised right hand is open with the vertical palm facing out and right. His left arm is drawn back, and his left hand is open with the vertical palm facing out towards the viewer. Dante wears a long transparent gown that reveals his contrapposto position and the shape of his legs: his weight is shifted to his right leg and his left leg is bent at the knee. His head is tilted back to the left, and his eyes are wide with fear and shock. He may be looking at Mohammed, to the left. His long hair falls over his shoulders.

Dante and Virgil stand together near the middle of the design, at the bottom. Virgil is slightly left of Dante, and largely hidden by him. Virgil faces forward but tilts his head back and turns it slightly to the left. His eyes are raised towards Mohammed, to the left. His right arm, the only one that is even partly visible, is bent across his chest. He has long hair and wears a long gown.

Mohammed stands to the left of Dante and Virgil. He faces forward with his left leg bent slightly forward. Nude, his torso is rent down the middle, displaying his vital organs. His arm are raised at 45 degrees and bent towards his torso at the elbow. With a hand on each side of his gaping laceration, he peels his skin back to show the organs inside. His viscera spill out of this wound and down past his genitals. A loop of his intestines circles around his head, over his shoulders; more of his intestines are visible below his right forearm, partially hidden behind his back. His head is bent and turned slightly to the right. His mouth is open slightly, showing his upper teeth. He has long hair and a long beard. He casts a shadow on the ground to the left of his right foot.

Ali stands in the lower left corner of the design. Contrapposto in position, he faces forward with his right leg bent forward slightly and his right foot on tiptoe. His arms are folded across his chest, with his right forearm over his left wrist. His left hand rests on his chest, while his right hand is raised with the palm roughly vertical and facing right. His head is tilted down to the right and his eyes are raised. A vertical cut through the center of his face drips blood from his chin. He is nude and has short curly hair. He casts a shadow on the ground to the left of his right foot.

Three sinners proceed leftward, away from the demon that stands near the right side of the design. They are partly obscured by the forward-facing figures of Dante, Virgil, Mohammed, and Ali. One is visible to the left of Virgil and partly hidden by him. This figure faces left with shoulders hunched and head bowed low. It is difficult to tell whether this is a male or a female. The figure's left arm is by its side and bent up before its torso. Its head hides its left hand, even as its face is hidden by its shoulder; its forehead may rest on its left forearm. The figure's long curly hair is swept away over its neck and appears below its left elbow. It wears a long gown with a belt.

Three sinners proceed leftward, away from the demon that stands near the right side of the design. They are partly obscured by the forward-facing figures of Dante, Virgil, Mohammed, and Ali. One nude male figure walks or lunges facing left between Ali and Mohammed, crouched low near the ground. His bent right leg is forward; his bent left leg is extended backward with his left knee near the ground and his left foot on tiptoe. His shoulders are hunched and his head is lowered. His left arm is extended down by his side. His left hand is missing, as his arm is truncated above the wrist. His long hair is swept over his neck. A lock of it is just visible below his chin. He may have a thin mustache. His shadow falls on the ground below his lower left leg and to the left of his right foot.

Three sinners proceed leftward, away from the demon that stands near the right side of the design. They are partly obscured by the forward-facing figures of Dante, Virgil, Mohammed, and Ali. One of these sinners is visible in the lower left corner, facing left and partly hidden by Ali. It is difficult to tell whether this figure is male or female. Its head is lowered and its shoulders are hunched. Its left arm is down but bent up at the elbow and its hand is by its head, perhaps resting on its hair. It seems to have long hair that falls over its shoulder and appears hanging below its raised forearm. It wears a long gown. This figure may help to create the shadow visible below and to the right of the train of its gown.

lg.l: Canto 28 The inscription is extremely faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading is conjectural.

desc.objtitle:
The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Mosca De' Lamberti and Bertrand De Born The Schismatics and Sowers of Discord: Bertrand De Born and Mosca De'Lamberti,
Object 60 (Butlin 812.57)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "21" top right, "N 57 next at p 22" top center, and the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth trench of the eighth circle of hell. A flat, narrow bank runs across the bottom of the design from corner to corner. This bank may be bare earth, or may be partly covered with grass or moss. Deep shadow covers this bank in the lower left corner, or the ground here may be scorched. Above it a lake stretches the length of the design. Waves ripple its surface. The far bank is similarly narrow and flat, and may be covered with similar vegetation. A small rocky island breaks the surface of the lake near the far bank, midway across the horizontal length of the design. Flames burn on the surface of the water around the edge of the island in the lake. A line of flames burns on the near bank of the lake; this line stretches from the left edge of the design across two-thirds of the waterline. Smoke rises from the lower left corner of the near bank; behind it is a stone, boulder, or the foot of another bridge. A large stone bridge arches across the design. It is anchored on the far bank of the lake. Part of a second bridge is visible above the base of the first bridge, in the upper left corner of the design. Tall flames rise in a line running the length of the foremost bridge. More flames appear in front of the second bridge near the left edge of the design. Wash across the top of the design suggests the sky, dark with what may be smoke or clouds just above the intersection between the two bridges, and lighter elsewhere. A demon, seen from behind, stands on the island in the lake. Nude and muscular, he stands in contrapposto with his weight shifted to his right leg and his left leg bent; his left foot is on tiptoe. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent to the vertical at the elbow. He grasps the hasp of a large sword with this hand. His left hand is down and bent. Large bat-like wings are raised behind his back. Mosca de' Lamberti, who helped instigate a Florentine war in the thirteenth century, walks rightward in the lower right corner of the design. He is nude and muscular, and walks with his right leg forward and his left leg extended behind him. His arms, both of which end abruptly below the elbow, are raised vertically overhead. Dante and Virgil stand together facing left just to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. Dante stands to the left of Virgil and hides his companion slightly. Both stand with arms down and heads slightly bent. Dante also turns his head slightly forward, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. The headless Bertrand de Born stands at the left side of the design, facing forward and to the right with his legs spread. He extends his left arm out horizontally to the right and grasps the long hair of his own severed head with this hand, holding it aloft. The head's mouth is open, showing its tongue and teeth; it is speaking to Dante, who stands to the right. Lantern-like, the head also emits beams of light. Bertrand de Born's right arm is by his side, bent at the elbow. The fingers on his right hand are spread and he points to his severed head with his right index finger. He is nude except for a sheer cloak. Streaks of blood appear on the cloak as well as on de Born's neck, shoulders, arms, pelvic area, and severed head. The figures of sinners punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Three of them appear above the boulder or cloud of smoke in the lower left corner of the design. Three more cower beneath the sword-wielding demon near the center of the design; they are shown stumbling, falling, or kneeling below him. Two more sinners appear to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. Indistinct lines near the right edge of the design, to the right of de' Lamberti, may represent one or two more sinners.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth trench of the eighth circle of hell. A flat, narrow bank runs across the bottom of the design from corner to corner. This bank may be bare earth, or may be partly covered with grass or moss. Deep shadow covers this bank in the lower left corner, or the ground here may be scorched. Above it a lake stretches the length of the design. Waves ripple its surface. The far bank is similarly narrow and flat, and may be covered with similar vegetation.
A small rocky island breaks the surface of the lake near the far bank, midway across the horizontal length of the design.
Flames burn on the surface of the water around the edge of the island in the lake.
A line of flames burns on the near bank of the lake; this line stretches from the left edge of the design across two-thirds of the waterline.
Smoke rises from the lower left corner of the near bank; behind it is a stone, boulder, or the foot of another bridge.

A large stone bridge arches across the design. It is anchored on the far bank of the lake. Part of a second bridge is visible above the base of the first bridge, in the upper left corner of the design.
Tall flames rise in a line running the length of the foremost bridge. More flames appear in front of the second bridge near the left edge of the design.
Wash across the top of the design suggests the sky, dark with what may be smoke or clouds just above the intersection between the two bridges, and lighter elsewhere.

A demon, seen from behind, stands on the island in the lake. Nude and muscular, he stands in contrapposto with his weight shifted to his right leg and his left leg bent; his left foot is on tiptoe. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees and bent to the vertical at the elbow. He grasps the hasp of a large sword with this hand. The blade of the weapon angles diagonally down to the left over his head. His left arm is down, bent out to the left at the elbow. His left hand rests on and holds his left hip loosely. Large bat-like wings are raised behind his back. His head, with short curly hair, may be bent forward slightly.

Mosca de' Lamberti, who helped instigate a Florentine war in the thirteenth century, walks rightward in the lower right corner of the design. He is nude and muscular, and walks with his right leg forward and his left leg extended behind him. His left foot is on tiptoe. His arms, both of which end abruptly below the elbow, are raised vertically overhead. He bends his head down. He has long hair and a beard.

Dante and Virgil stand together just to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. Virgil stands to the right of Dante and is slightly hidden by him. Virgil faces left with his head slightly bent but his eyes raised. His left arm is down by his side. He has long curly hair and wears a long gown.

Dante and Virgil stand together just to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. Dante stands to the left of Virgil, facing left. His head is bent and turned slightly forward, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. His left arm is extended down by his side. His right hand is visible raised just to the left of his chest; this hand is open and the vertical palm faces out. Dante wears a long transparent gown. The toes of his left foot peek from beneath its hem. His hair is long and curly.

The headless Bertrand de Born stands at the left side of the design, facing forward and to the right with his legs spread. He extends his left arm out horizontally to the right and grasps the long hair of his own severed head with this hand, holding it aloft. The head faces forward and right. Its mouth is open, showing its tongue and teeth, and it is speaking to Dante, who stands to the right. Lantern-like, the head also emits beams of light. Bertrand de Born's right arm is by his side, bent at the elbow. The fingers on his right hand are spread and he points to his severed head with his right index finger. He is nude except for a sheer cloak that drapes his shoulders, falls behind his back, and pools on the ground beneath him. Streaks of blood appear on the cloak as well as on de Born's neck, shoulders, arms, pelvic area, and severed head.

The figures of sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. The upper body of the leftmost of these is visible above the boulder or smoke near the left edge of the design. He faces forward and slightly right, and raises both arms vertically overhead with palms facing out. His head is tilted back slightly. He has a beard and curly hair, and his mouth is open. Lines at his wrist suggest that he is wearing a gown or shirt.

The figures of sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. The head, torso, and upraised arms of the leftmost of these are visible above the boulder or smoke near the left edge of the design. Just to the right of his left arm, a head is partly drawn facing right and looking down. Only the head's right eye, eyebrow, and short curly hair are clearly defined.

The figures of sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Third from left, a male stands or walks facing forward and slightly right, although his bent head is turned right and seen in profile. Both of his arms are by his side and bent up at the elbow, and his hands are raised to rest on either side of his face. His hands may be clenched into fists. He seems to wear a gown and have short hair and a beard.

The figures of sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Three of them cower beneath the sword-wielding demon standing on the nearby island. The leftmost of these three is shown in the act of falling to his knees on the ground. The sinner faces right and leans backwards. His arms are raised at 135 degrees, bent to the vertical at the elbow. Both upraised hands are open and his right palm is vertical, facing out towards the viewer. His left hand is partially hidden from view by the beams of light from Bertrand de Born's severed head. His head is tilted back sharply. His right leg is bent and drawn up slightly; his right foot is on tiptoe. He wears a long gown that drapes to the ground behind him as he falls. He has a beard and long hair.

The figures of the sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Three of them cower beneath the sword-wielding demon standing on the nearby island. The middle of these is a nude female who stumbles rightward just to the left of the demon's left leg. She steps forward with her bent right leg; her bent left leg is extended behind her and her left foot seems to be on tiptoe. Leaning forward slightly, she twists at the waist so that her upper body faces out towards the viewer. She may be falling. Her right arm is raised vertically overhead, and her right hand is open with the palm facing out and up. Her left arm, raised at about 135 degrees, is partially visible through the demon's legs. Her face, visible in three-quarters profile looking forward and right, is creased with fear. Her eyes are raised to the demon above, and her mouth is open. Her tongue may be visible. She has long curly hair.

The figures of the sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Three of them cower beneath the sword-wielding demon standing on a nearby island. The rightmost of these kneels on the ground facing right, but turning his head forward and bending it back. His eyes are raised to look up at the demon above. He bends forward at the waist. One bent leg (perhaps his left) is drawn forward, while the other bent leg is extended backwards along the ground. His slightly bent right arm is raised vertically, up towards the demon. Only his upper arm is visible of the left arm; it is raised at roughly 45 degrees. He is wearing a gown and has a beard and long hair.

The figures of the sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Two of them are visible to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. The leftmost of these stands or walks facing right with head lowered and shoulders hunched. This figure may be a male with long hair and a beard. Both of his arms are extended straight down by his side. His hands are open with palms down. He wears a long gown; the shape of its folds suggests that one of its legs is bent forward.

The figures of the sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Two of them are visible to the left of Mosca de' Lamberti. The rightmost of these kneels facing forward but leaning to the right. She seems to be a woman with long hair. Her head is tilted back and her mouth is open; both of her arms are down by her side. She wears a gown.

The figures of the sinners being punished in this trench appear in series on the far bank of the lake. Indistinct lines at the right edge of the design, to the right of Mosca de' Lamberti, may be one or two of these sinners. It is difficult to discern anything about these figures, other than that they may be seated or kneeling.

lg.l:
Hell Canto 28
The inscription is very faint; it may have been partly erased. Our reading of the second word is conjectural.

desc.objtitle:
The Pit of Disease: The Falsifiers The Alchemists and Forgers,
Object 61 (Butlin 812.58)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "28" top right, and "For this see P 62" top center. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench stretches the length of the bottom of the design, and seems to be bare earth, furrowed in places. A rock bridge arches down from the upper right corner of the design to the floor of the trench. A second rock bridge arches from the upper left corner of the design down to the floor of the trench below, near the lower left corner. Nude human forms are visible in this bridge, petrified in contorted positions. Most of these forms are difficult to resolve into individuals. Two additional rock bridges in the distance are visible between the bridges that appear at either side of the design. Part of another distant rock bridge appears in the lower right corner of the design, to the right of the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. A dark cloud fills the top left corner of the design and extends most of the way across the top edge of the design. Tongues of flame lick down from beneath the cloud in the upper left corner. Wash below the cloud and below the bridges suggests the sky. It is red above and below the two bridges in the distance, perhaps with light from the flames raining down from the cloud, and paler elsewhere. Undulating lines in the sky in the lower right corner, below the distant bridge, suggest smoke or cloud. Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Dante stands to the left of Virgil and obscures his companion slightly. Both wear long gowns, and bend their arms up at the elbow in front of their torsos, with hands together in front of their faces. Each may hold his nose. Three nude "falsifiers," or forgers, who are now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the human bridge. The leftmost of these lies supine with his body partially resting against the sinner behind him, so that his torso faces forward as well as up. His legs extend to the right and are largely hidden by another sinner, a heavy male. His bent right arm is extended down along the ground to the left. His head is tilted back and to the left, so that his right cheek rests on his right shoulder. The heavy sinner to the right lies or crawls with his belly resting on his right leg, which is bent and drawn up beneath him and lies on the ground. This sinner's bent left leg is extended to the right and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He bends backwards and lifts his torso, bending his head back to look left. His mouth is open and his eyes are lowered or closed. His left arm is down and his elbow, forearm, and many of the spread fingers of his left hand all rest on the ground. The head and shoulders of a third sinner appear above the other two. This figure's gender is difficult to discern. Its shoulders face forward but it tilts its head back to look up, so that its face is seen from below. Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. Two males at the top of the pile sit with their backs together. They are Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, both of whom were alchemists. The rightmost of these faces right and away, and bends to the right slightly. His right arm is down and bent up at the elbow across his lower back; he raises his right hand and uses his spread fingers to scratch his back. His left arm is raised and bent down past his head, and he scratches his back between his shoulder blades with the fingers on this hand. The other seated male faces left. His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across his back, which he scratches with the spread fingers of his left hand. He bends forward sharply over his own lap, so that his left upper arm may rest on his thigh. The forms of the other sinners lumped into the pile are difficult to distinguish, though several heads and upper bodies emerge. They are forgers. The pile casts a shadow on the ground beneath.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. The floor of the trench stretches the length of the bottom of the design, and seems to be bare earth, furrowed in places.
A rock bridge arches down from the upper right corner of the design to the floor of the trench. It is partly dark with shadow.

A second rock bridge arches from the upper left corner of the design down to the floor of the trench below, near the lower left corner. The inside edge of the bridge is dark with shadow. Nude human forms are visible in the bridge, petrified in contorted positions. Most of these forms are difficult to resolve into individuals. A clearly distinguished arm extends roughly horizontally near the base of the bridge; it is slightly bent. Lines above and below may be a torso of the same figure, lying supine. Lines above this suggest another torso, facing forward with visible breasts. A horizontal shape above this torso may be a leg, perhaps with a knee or foot. A head facing forward with closed or lowered eyes is visible above this lower limb. The shapes above this head are even more indistinct.
Two additional rock bridges in the distance are visible between the bridges that appear at either side of the design.
Part of a distant rock bridge appears in the lower right corner of the design, to the right of the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand.
A dark cloud fills the top left corner of the design and extends most of the way across the top edge of the design.
Tongues of flame lick down from beneath the cloud in the upper left corner.

Wash below the cloud and below the bridges suggests the sky. It is red above and below the two bridges in the distance, perhaps with light from the flames raining down from the cloud, and paler elsewhere.
Undulating lines in the sky in the lower right corner, below the distant bridge, suggest smoke or cloud.

Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Dante stands to the left of Virgil and obscures his companion slightly. He faces forward and slightly left. His long gown covers his arms and hands, but both arms seem to be bent up at the elbow in front of his torso, with hands together in front of his face. He may be holding his nose. He tilts his head forward, and his eyes are lowered or closed. He has long hair.

Dante and Virgil stand side-by-side on a small shelf in the stone bridge at the right. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, obscured slightly by his companion. He faces forward and slightly left. His long gown covers his arms and hands, but both arms seem to be bent up at the elbow in front of his torso, with hands together in front of his face. He may be holding his nose. He has long hair.

Three nude "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The leftmost of these lies supine with his body partially resting against the sinner behind him, so that his torso actually faces partly forward as well as up. His legs extend to the right and are largely hidden by another sinner, a heavy male, but one lower leg and foot are visible, respectively above and below the heavy sinner's own extended left leg. His bent right arm is extended down along the ground to the left. His hand rests on the ground in a loose fist. His head is tilted back and to the left, so that his right cheek rests on his right shoulder. His mouth is open, and may show his teeth. His long hair falls away from his forehead.

Three nude "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The rightmost of these is a heavy male who lies or crawls with his belly resting on his right leg, which is bent and drawn up beneath him and lies on the ground. The sinner's bent left leg is extended to the right and his left foot rests on tiptoe. He bends backwards and lifts his torso, bending his head back to look left. His mouth is open and his eyes are lowered or closed. His left arm is down and his elbow, forearm, and many of the spread fingers of his left hand all rest on the ground. He is balding, but his remaining hair is short and curly.

Three nude "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. The head and shoulders of a third sinner appear above the two who lie flat on the ground. This figure's gender is difficult to discern. Its shoulders face forward but it tilts its head back to look up, so that its face is seen from below. It may have long hair falling away from its head.

Three nude "falsifiers" or forgers now afflicted with disease lie in a huddle in the lower left corner of the design, near the base of the bridge of human forms. A shadow appears on the ground to the left of them, just below the bridge.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. Two males at the top of the pile sit with their backs together. They represent Griffolino of Arezzo and Capocchio of Siena, who were alchemists. The rightmost of these faces right and away, so that viewers see him from behind. He bends to the right slightly. His right leg seems to be bent at the knee, over the bodies of his fellow sinners. His right arm is down and bent up at the elbow across his lower back; he raises his right hand and uses his spread fingers to scratch his back. His left arm is raised and bent down past his head, perhaps resting on it. He scratches his back between his shoulder blades with the fingers on his left hand. His head is bent down and turned to the right so that it is visible in profile. His mouth is open. He is nude and has short, curly hair. The leftmost of these faces left. His left leg seems to be bent at the knee. His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across his back, which he scratches with the spread fingers of his left hand. He bends forward sharply over his own lap, so that his left upper arm may rest on his left thigh. His head is down. He is nude and balding, and what is left of his hair is short.

Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The forms of most of the nude sinners, who represent forgers, are difficult to distinguish. At the right of the pile, the upper body of a male lies supine with head back and chin tilted up so far his face looks right. His eyes are closed. This figure may have long hair. Immediately to the left, the upper body of a supine woman extends down from the pile, facing slightly forward as well as up. Her head is tilted to the left, so that her face is seen in profile looking up. Her eyes are closed. Her long hair is spread on the ground around her head. Her mouth may be open. Her breasts are visible. To the left, the upside down head of another sinner hangs down, facing left. It is difficult to say whether this figure is a male or female, or what sort of hair it may have. Its shoulders just emerge from the pile. Its eyes are closed and its mouth may be open. Other forms between these heads represent additional indistinct figures. At the left side of pile, a figure's torso lies face down extending to the left. Wash suggests this single figure may be wearing a shirt or other garment. It has short hair. To the left of this figure, a head lies on the ground looking up. Its long hair is spread on the ground to the left. Its eyes are closed. Above these two figures at the left of the pile, a third figure lifts its head to look forward with eyes raised. It seems to be balding, with short hair at its temples. Its right shoulder is also visible.
Another group of diseased falsifiers lie together on the trench floor near the bridge on which Dante and Virgil stand. The pile casts shadows on the ground below, and perhaps to the left.

desc.objtitle:
The Pit of Disease: Gianni Schicchi and Myrrha The Counterfeiters of Persons: Gianni Schicchi and Myrrha,
Object 62 (Butlin 812.59 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "63" top right, and "Pg Canto 4" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. A rock bridge arches through the middle of the design, rising from the lower left corner and extending to roughly the midpoint of the right edge. Large flames burn above the rock bridge, filling two-thirds of the upper half of the design. This fire produces clouds of smoke that permeate the rest of the design above the bridge, particularly the upper right corner, but also the spaces between the flames and below them to the left. The floor of the trench crosses the bottom of the design and appears to be flat earth. Tall tongues of fire burn in a line across the floor of the trench, below the bridge. Wash beneath the rock bridge and above the figures suggests the sky, perhaps lit partly by the flames that burn on the floor of the trench. A small mound or hill rises from the floor of the trench in the lower right corner of the design. Dante and Virgil stand together on top of this low hill. Virgil stands to the left of his companion, and obscures him slightly. He faces away and may tilt his head back. Dante, to the right, faces left and slightly away, so that he is seen partly from behind. He tilts his head back slightly. Myrrha, who deceived her father into incest, leaps or falls through the flames in the upper left corner of the design. She has the body of a woman and the head of a dog. Her torso is horizontal, facing forward and down. Her bent right leg is extended behind her, while her slightly bent left leg is forward. Both of her feet are pointed into tiptoe position. Her arms are similarly spread wide. She is nude and has visible human breasts. Gianni Schicchi, who forged a will, is shown at the top of the design running or leaping along the rock bridge facing right. He has the nude body of man but the head of a dog with long canine ears. His bent right leg is forward, while his left leg is extended behind him and bent to the vertical at the knee. He is bent forward at the waist so far that his torso is horizontal, facing down. Both arms are drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. He grasps the neck of Capocchio of Siena in his muzzle and drags the alchemist along. Capocchio's torso faces forward and to the right. He is bent backward at the waist; his legs extend along the rock bridge to the left. Capocchio's head is crooked sharply left and down at an awkward angle and his right cheek may touch his right shoulder. Both arms are by his side, bent up at the elbow with hands raised. Another sinner is shown tumbling down from the rock bridge. His body is upside down in front of the bridge and below Myrrha. He faces away, with his head turned slightly to the left. Both slightly bent arms are extended past his head, with hands open and palms facing down. His left leg is bent forward and drawn up beneath him so that his left foot is next to his left buttock. His right leg is also bent forward but not drawn as deeply in towards his body. Several sinners afflicted with disease are depicted on the floor of the trench amid the flames beneath the bridge. One is visible between the arms of the falling sinner. A nude male, he sits or kneels facing forward and slightly to the left, with his right leg extended down to the left and bent away at the knee. His bent left leg may be visible below his torso with knee forward. His right arm is extended down between his knees, with hand open and resting palm down on the ground. His left arm is visible to the elbow, down by his side. His head is tilted sharply to the right so that his left temple may rest on his left shoulder. The head and shoulders of a second sinner beneath the bridge are visible to the left. This sinner's head is down and twisted to look left, so that his face is seen partly from above. He seems to be nude and to have short hair, but other features are indistinct and difficult to distinguish. Just to the left of Virgil, the head and shoulders of a third sinner appear. This sinner seems to bend his or her head back to look up so sharply that the face is seen from below. The figure may be nude, but other features are difficult to distinguish, including gender. A nude male sinner lies on his side beneath the rock bridge, his body visible on either side of Dante and Virgil. Nude, he rests on a diagonal support so that his head, near the right side of the design, is higher than his feet. His body faces forward, but he tilts his head back and turns it up so that his face is seen in profile. Both of his hands are raised and open with fingers spread and vertical palms facing out. The support on which he rests seems to be another small mound or hill on the floor of the trench, perhaps of earth or stone.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the tenth trench of the eighth circle of hell. A rock bridge arches through the middle of the design, rising from the lower left corner and extending to roughly the midpoint of the right edge.
Large flames burn above the rock bridge, filling two-thirds of the upper half of the design.

The fire that burns above the rock bridge produces clouds of smoke that permeate the rest of the design above the bridge, particularly the upper right corner, but also the spaces between the flames and below them to the left.
The floor of the trench crosses the bottom of the design and appears to be flat earth.
Tall tongues of fire burn in a line across the floor of the trench, below the bridge.
Wash beneath the rock bridge and above the figures suggests the sky, perhaps lit partly by the flames that burn on the floor of the trench.
A small mound or hill rises from the floor of the trench in the lower right corner of the design. It is cast in shadow.

Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower right corner of the design, on top of the low hill. Virgil stands to the left of his companion, and obscures him slightly. He faces away and may tilt his head back. He has long hair and wears a long gown that reaches the ground.

Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower right corner of the design, on top of the low hill. Dante stands to the right of his companion, obscured by him slightly. He faces left and slightly away, so that he is seen partly from behind. He tilts his head back slightly. His left upper arm is by his side. He wears a gown and has long hair.

Myrrha, who deceived her father into incest, leaps or falls through the flames in the upper left corner of the design. She has the body of a woman and the head of a dog. Instead of hair on her head, she has fur. Her mouth is open to display sharp canine teeth and a long tongue. Her torso is horizontal, facing forward and down. Her bent right leg is extended behind her, while her slightly bent left leg is forward. Both of her feet are pointed into tiptoe position. Her arms are similarly spread wide. Her slightly bent right arm is raised vertically and drawn back behind her, with her right hand open, fingers spread and vertical palm out towards the viewer. Her left arm is extended down at about 45 degrees, with fingers spread and palm down. Her head is bent back. She is nude and has visible human breasts.

Gianni Schicchi, who forged a will, is shown at the top of the design running or leaping along the rock bridge facing right. He has the nude body of a man, but the head of dog with long canine ears. His bent right leg is forward, while his left leg is extended behind him and bent to the vertical at the knee. His left foot is pointed into tiptoe position. He is bent forward at the waist so far that his torso is horizontal, facing down. Both arms are drawn back and raised at 135 degrees. His right hand is open with the fingers spread and the palm facing up. His left hand is also open, but with the palm vertical and facing out to the right. He grasps the neck of Capocchio of Siena in his muzzle and drags the alchemist along.

Gianni Schicchi is shown at the top of the design running or leaping along the rock bridge, facing right with his torso bent to the horizontal. Schicchi, who has the head of a dog, grasps the neck of Capocchio of Siena in his muzzle and drags the other man along the bridge. Capocchio's torso faces forward and to the right. He is bent backward at the waist; his legs extend along the rock bridge to the left. Capocchio's head is crooked sharply left and down at an awkward angle and his right cheek may touch his right shoulder. Both arms are by his side, bent up at the elbow with hands raised. His left hand may rest on his left shoulder, palm down. His right hand may rest against his right temple. His mouth is open and may display his tongue and teeth. His eyes seem to be raised. He is nude and has short, possibly curly hair.

Another sinner is shown tumbling down from the rock bridge. His body is upside down in front of the bridge and below Myrrha. He faces away, with his head turned slightly to the left so that his face is seen in quarter profile from behind, looking left. He also twists slightly at the waist, so that his torso is turned very slightly left and his pelvis faces very slightly right. Both slightly bent arms are extended past his head, with hands open and palms facing down. His left leg is bent forward and drawn up beneath him so that his left foot is next to his left buttock. His right leg is also bent forward but not drawn as deeply in towards his body. The bottoms of both of his feet are visible. He is nude with short curly hair.

Several sinners afflicted with disease are depicted on the floor of the trench amid the flames beneath the bridge. One is visible between the arms of the falling sinner. A nude male, he sits or kneels facing forward and slightly to the left, with his right leg extended down to the left and bent away at the knee. His bent left leg may be visible below his torso with knee forward. His right arm is extended down between his knees, with his hand open and resting palm down on the ground. His left arm is visible to the elbow, down by his side. His head is tilted sharply to the right so that his left temple may rest on his left shoulder. He may bend forward slightly at the waist. His mouth is open and his eyes are swiveled down to the right. He has short curly hair.

Several sinners afflicted with disease are depicted on the floor of the trench amid the flames beneath the bridge. One is visible between the arms of the falling sinner. The head and shoulders of a second sinner are visible to the left. His head is down and twisted to look left, so that his face is seen partly from above. He seems to be nude and to have short hair, but other features are indistinct and difficult to distinguish.

Several sinners afflicted with disease are depicted on the floor of the trench amid the flames beneath the bridge. One is visible between the arms of the falling sinner. To the right, the head and shoulders of another appear. This sinner seems to bend his or her head back to look up so sharply that the face is seen from below. The figure may be nude, but other features are difficult to distinguish, including gender.

Several sinners afflicted with disease are visible on the floor of the trench amid the flames beneath the bridge. One nude male lies on his side beneath the rock bridge, his body visible on either side of Dante and Virgil. Nude, he rests on a diagonal support so that his head, near the right edge of the design, is higher than his feet. His body faces forward, but he tilts his head back and turns it up so that his face is seen in profile. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his eyes may be rolled up or may be closed. Both of his hands are raised and open with fingers spread and vertical palms facing out. His legs extend to the left, with his right crossed behind his left. He has short hair.

One of the nude male sinners beneath the rock bridge lies on his side on a diagonal support that lifts his head, at the right side of the design, higher than his feet. The support on which he rests seems to be another small mound or hill on the floor of the trench, perhaps of earth or stone.

desc.objtitle:
The Primaeval Giants Sunk in the Soil The Primeval Giants,
Object 63 (Butlin 812.60)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "27" top right, "Hell Canto 29" bottom left, and "N52 next at p 25" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This design is set in a pit or large well near the ninth circle of hell. Enormous boulders frame the scene, one at each edge of the design. Level ground of earth or stone crosses the bottom of the design, forming the bank or edge of the pit or well that is visible between the boulders above. Dry, dead vegetation suggestive of moss or lichen covers the boulder at the left and the ground just below it. This vegetation also seems to form the material filling the pit or well. It covers the vertical surface visible past the giants on the other side of the pit also. Heavy, dark clouds cross the top edge of the design and fill the upper right corner. At least two jagged bolts of lightning snake across the design from these clouds. Tongues of fire also lick down from the cloud near the upper left corner; alternatively this may be more lightning. Pelting rain and/or sleet, visible as diagonal lines blowing from upper left to lower right, covers the design. Wash below the clouds, especially towards the right side of the design, suggests a sky dark with storm. Five nude male giants stand in identical positions, shoulder-to-shoulder and buried to the waist in the well. They face away, forming a horizontal line that stretches across the well. Their arms are extended down by their sides. All of the giants seem to lower their heads. Each has long, slightly curly hair that spreads over his shoulders and hangs down between his shoulder blades. Dante and Virgil are small figures standing together near the middle of the bank of the pit. Lightly sketched, their individual identities are impossible to distinguish. They seem to face away. The figure to the left raises his extended left arm at 135 degrees. His right arm seems to be by his side and bent up at the elbow with hand raised. The right arm of the figure to the right is not visible. This figure's left arm is bent up by his side with hand raised. The figures' footprints on the bank extend from below their feet diagonally down to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: This design is set in a pit or large well near the ninth circle of hell. Enormous boulders frame the scene, one at each edge of the design.
Level ground of earth or stone crosses the bottom of the design, forming the bank or edge of the pit or well that is visible between the boulders above.

Dry, dead vegetation suggestive of moss or lichen covers the boulder at the left and the ground just below it. This vegetation also seems to form the material filling the pit or well. It covers the vertical surface visible past the giants on the other side of the pit also.
Heavy, dark clouds cross the top edge of the design and fill the upper right corner.

At least two jagged bolts of lightning snake across the design from the heavy clouds at the top. Tongues of fire also lick down from the cloud near the upper left corner; alternatively this may be more lightning.
Pelting rain, visible as diagonal lines blowing from upper left to lower right, covers the design.
Wash below the clouds, especially towards the right side of the design, suggests a sky dark with storm.

Five nude male giants stand in identical positions, shoulder-to-shoulder and buried to the waist in the well. They face away, forming a horizontal line that stretches across the well. Their arms are extended down by their sides. Their hands are buried, except for the left hand of the giant second to left, which may rest palm down on the surface of the material in which the giants stand. All of the giants seem to lower their heads. Each has long, slightly curly hair that spreads over his shoulders and hangs down between his shoulder blades.

Dante and Virgil are small figures standing together near the middle of the bank of the pit. Lightly sketched, their individual identities are impossible to distinguish. They seem to face away. The figure to the left raises his extended left arm at 135 degrees. His right arm seems to be by his side and bent up at the elbow with hand raised. The right arm of the figure to the right is not visible. This figure's left arm is bent up by his side with hand raised. Both figures wear gowns.
