Dante and Virgil stand together near the middle of the bank of the pit. Their footprints on the bank extend from below their feet diagonally down to the left.

lg.l:
HELL Canto 31
This ink inscription is offset slightly to the left of its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle:
The Complaint of the Giant Nimrod The Giant Nimrod,
Object 64 (Butlin 812.61 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "26" top right, "N33 next at p 25" along the top margin, and with fragments of an erased inscription, probably the same as the one along the top margin, in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. Sharp rocks cross the top of the design and extend down the left edge. A brick wall extends from the right edge of the design most of the way across the bottom half of the design. This wall represents the ruined dungeons of Babylon. The ground near the bottom of the design seems to be flat earth. It rises into a small furrowed hill in front of the brick wall. Wash beneath the stone arch and above the wall suggests the sky. A brick tower, only partly finished, is visible in the lower left corner of the design. It represents the Tower of Babel. A niche at the bottom of the tower faces forward, much like a doorway. A small figure sits on a throne inside the niche, facing forward. This figure may be intended to represent Satan, attired like an earthly king. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a gown and a crown with large spikes. He holds a scepter in his raised left hand, and an orb in his right hand. Large bat-like wings rise behind the figure's back. The large figure of Nimrod kneels in the lower right corner of the design. He faces forward and right with his bent legs beneath him. His right arm is down by his side with his right hand resting on the ground and perhaps partly tucked beneath his right shin. The wrist of this arm is shackled to a chain that winds around his waist and then falls to the ground to the left. His left arm is also by his side, but bent upward across his chest at the elbow; he holds a horn or trumpet in his left hand. His head is tilted back and turned to the left slightly. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open, displaying teeth(?) and tongue. The text suggests he may be speaking. He wears a crown and has long, curly hair and a forked beard. His upper body is nude, but a skirt, cloth, or similar garment seems to cover his thighs. Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower left corner of the design. They are sketched indistinctly and are impossible to tell apart. They may face away and be seen from behind, or they may face right. Other features and aspects of their posture are difficult to discern.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. Sharp rocks cross the top of the design and extend down the left edge.
A brick wall extends from the right edge of the design most of the way across the bottom half of the design. This wall represents the ruined dungeons of Babylon.
The ground near the bottom of the design seems to be flat earth. It rises into a small furrowed hill in front of the brick wall.
Wash beneath the stone arch and above the wall suggests the sky.

A brick tower, only partly finished and yet a ruin, is visible in the lower left corner of the design. It represents the Tower of Babel. A niche at the bottom of the tower faces forward, much like a doorway.

A small figure sits on a throne inside the niche, facing forward. This figure may be intended to represent Satan, attired like an earthly king. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a gown and a crown with large spikes. His left forearm is raised and his left elbow may rest on the arm of his chair. He holds a scepter in his raised left hand. His right hand rests on his right thigh or the right arm of the throne. He holds an orb surmounted with a cross in this hand. Large bat-like wings rise behind the figure's back.

The large figure of Nimrod kneels in the lower right corner of the design. He faces forward and right with his bent legs beneath him. His right arm is down by his side with his right hand resting on the ground and perhaps partly tucked beneath his right shin. The wrist of this arm is shackled to a chain that winds around his waist and then falls to the ground to the left. His left arm is also by his side, but bent upward across his chest at the elbow; he holds a horn or trumpet in his left hand. This instrument is attached to a chain or cord that circles his neck. His head is tilted back and turned to the left slightly. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open, displaying teeth(?) and tongue. The text suggests he may be speaking. He wears a crown and has long curly hair and a forked beard. His upper body is nude, but a skirt, cloth, or similar garment seems to cover his thighs.

Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower left corner of the design. They are sketched indistinctly and are impossible to tell apart. Both wear gowns. They may face away and be seen from behind, or they may face right. Other features and aspects of their posture are difficult to discern.

desc.objtitle:
Ephialtes and Two Other Titans Ephialtes and Two Other Giants,
Object 65 (Butlin 812.62 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "46" top right, "No 60 next at p 65" top center, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 32" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. Dark, heavy clouds cross the top edge of the design, which is dark with storm. Rain, snow, and hail saturate the design, pelting down from the clouds diagonally from upper left to lower right. The bank of a well or pit crosses the length of the bottom of the design. It is transparent in places. Dry, dead vegetation suggestive of moss or lichen covers the surface of this bank. The giant figure of Ephialtes, sometimes considered a titan, fills much of the design. Punished for his attempt to attack the gods, Ephialtes is here shown immobilized and immersed waist-deep in the bank. His lower body is indistinctly visible; his legs seem to be bent and drawn up beneath his body, so that he kneels with his knees facing right. He twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward and even slightly left. His head is bent and turned to the left, and his eyes have swiveled left, perhaps to look at the tiny figures of Dante and Virgil in the lower left corner of the design. His left arm is extended down in front of him, with his left hand resting palm down on the outside of his left knee. He is nude, but a manacle binds his left wrist; a heavy chain attached to this cuff wraps his arm, circles his neck, and winds repeatedly around his torso. To the right of Ephialtes sits another giant, a nude young male with short curly hair, facing away. He is visible from the waist up, above the bank. He bends his head and turns it left, so that his face is visible above the nose in profile from behind. Both arms are down by his side. To the left of Ephialtes another giant sits facing forward. Like the others, he is nude and buried waist-deep beneath the bank. He is older than the others. His right arm is down by his side. His head is lowered and tilted to the right, and his left cheek may rest partly on his left shoulder. He has long hair and a beard. Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower left corner of the design. Their tiny size emphasizes by contrast the enormity of the three giants immersed in the bank. As both of these tiny figures are largely sketched in pencil, their separate identities are difficult to distinguish. The figure on the left faces forward but turns his head to the right. His right arm is by his side and bent across his chest; his left arm may be crossed or folded under the right, or may not be shown. The figure on the right faces forward and slightly to the right, but turns his head slightly left. His right arm is bent up across his chest and his right hand is raised.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. Dark, heavy clouds cross the top edge of the design.
Dark, heavy clouds cross the top edge of the design, which is dark with storm. Rain, snow, and hail saturate the design, pelting down from the clouds diagonally from upper left to lower right.
The bank of a well or pit crosses the length of the bottom of the design. It is transparent in places.
Dry, dead vegetation suggestive of moss or lichen covers the surface of the bank that crosses the length of the bottom of the design.

The giant figure of Ephialtes, sometimes considered a titan, fills much of this design. Punished for his attempt to attack the gods, Ephialtes is here shown immobilized and immersed waist-deep in a bank. The bank in which he sits is partly transparent, so that his lower body is indistinctly visible; his legs seem to be bent and drawn up beneath his body, so that he kneels with his knees facing right. He twists at the waist so that his torso faces forward and even slightly left. His head is bent and turned to the left, and his eyes have swiveled left, perhaps to look at the tiny figures of Dante and Virgil in the lower left corner of the design. In accordance with Dante's text, the position of his right shoulder suggests that his right arm has been drawn behind his back. His left arm is extended down in front of him, with his left hand resting palm down on the outside of his left knee. He is nude, but a manacle binds his left wrist; a heavy chain attached to this cuff wraps his arm, circles his neck, and winds repeatedly around his torso. He has short curly hair. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth.

To the right of Ephialtes sits another giant, facing away. This figure is a nude young male with short curly hair. He is visible from the waist up, above the bank. He bends his head and turns it left, so that his face is visible above the nose in profile from behind. He may be looking at Ephialtes. Both arms are down by his side. His hands are not visible.

To the left of Ephialtes another giant sits facing forward. Like the others, he is nude and buried waist-deep beneath the bank. He is older than the others. His right arm is down by his side. The position of his left shoulder suggests that his left arm, which is not visible, is drawn behind his back. He may be leaning backward slightly. His head is lowered and tilted to the right, and his left cheek may rest partly on his left shoulder. His eyes are raised to look to the right, perhaps to Ephialtes. His mouth is open slightly and his upper teeth show. He has long hair and a long beard.

Dante and Virgil stand together in the lower left corner of the design. Their tiny size emphasizes by contrast the enormity of the three giants immersed in the bank. As both of these tiny figures are largely sketched in pencil, their separate identities are difficult to distinguish. The figure on the left faces forward but turns his head to the right. His right arm is by his side and bent across his chest; his left arm may be crossed or folded under the right, or may not be shown. The shape of this figure's gown indicates that his right leg is bent forward slightly. The figure on the right faces forward and slightly to the right, but turns his head slightly to the left. His right arm is bent up across his chest and his right hand is raised. He wears a long gown as well. Both figures have long hair.

desc.objtitle:
Antaeus Setting Down Dante and Virgil in the Last Circle of Hell Antaeus Sets Down Dante and Virgil in the Ninth Circle,
Object 66 (Butlin 812.63)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "2" top right, "N 3 next at p 3" top center, and the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, also called Cocytus. A rocky cliff rises along the right edge of the design. A stone ledge in the lower left corner of the design represents the floor of the ninth circle of hell. A thin cloud forms a semi-circle that extends from the top edge of the design, down the middle of the left edge, and around through the lower half of the design before trailing off near the right edge. Hail volleys diagonally down from the inside of the cloud near the upper left corner of the design. Additional pellets of hail appear within the cloud near the top edge of the design. Tongues of fire burn on either side of the cloud in the upper left corner of the design, and on the lower edge of the cloud where it curves away from the left edge of the design. Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with distant clouds. These clouds are especially apparent below the semi-circular cloud. Flames burn in these distant clouds. The giant Antaeus, a son of Neptune (and in part a titan) whose superior strength depended on his feet remaining on the ground, fills much of the design. His nude, muscular body is largely horizontal; he bends backwards and twists at the waist so that his pelvis and thighs are turned slightly up while his torso is turned slightly down. His knees are bent and his feet rest on tiptoe on separate ledges in the cliff at the right side of the design. His head is turned down slightly, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His left arm is extended at 135 degrees and he holds a knob in the cliff with his left hand, palm down. He reaches his right arm down with his hand open, vertical palm facing forward. He is depositing Dante and Virgil on the floor of Cocytus with this hand. Dante's body faces forward and slightly to the left, hanging from Antaeus' hand. His feet dangle in tiptoe position. He grasps the giant's hand with both arms: his right arm is raised vertically and his right hand rests on Antaeus' wrist with the palm facing down, while his left hand rests palm down on the outside of Antaeus' palm. He bends and tilts his head to the left, perhaps to look at Virgil, who stands to the left. Virgil faces right and reaches out both arms at about 45 degrees to either side of Dante. Virgil's right hand may rest on Dante's left hip.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, also called Cocytus. A rocky cliff rises along the right edge of the design.
A stone ledge in the lower left corner of the design represents the floor of the ninth circle of hell.

A thin cloud forms a semi-circle that extends from the top edge of the design, down the middle of the left edge, and around through the lower half of the design before trailing off near the right edge.
Hail volleys diagonally down from the inside of the cloud near the upper left corner of the design. Additional pellets of hail appear within the cloud near the top edge of the design.
Tongues of fire burn on either side of the cloud in the upper left corner of the design, and on the lower edge of the cloud where it curves away from the left edge of the design.
Wash surrounding the figures suggests the sky, perhaps with distant clouds. These clouds are especially apparent below the semi-circular cloud.
Flames burn in the distant clouds below the semi-circular cloud.

The giant Antaeus, a son of Neptune (and partly a titan) whose superior strength depended on his feet remaining on the ground, fills much of this design. His nude, muscular body is largely horizontal; he bends backwards and twists at the waist so that his pelvis and thighs are turned slightly up while his torso is turned slightly down. His knees are bent and his feet rest on tiptoe on separate ledges in the cliff at the right side of the design. His left arm is extended at 135 degrees and he holds a knob in the cliff with his left hand, palm down. He reaches his right arm down with his hand open, vertical palm facing forward. He is depositing Dante and Virgil on the floor of Cocytus with this hand; Virgil stands already, but Antaeus is still supporting Dante. Antaeus' head is turned down slightly, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His mouth is open slightly, displaying his teeth, and his eyes look down towards the tiny figures below him. He has short, curly hair. He may cast a shadow on the cliff below him, to the right of his right foot.

Antaeus is shown depositing Dante on the floor of Cocytus, in the lower left corner of the design. Dante's body faces forward and slightly to the left, hanging from Antaeus' right hand. His feet dangle in tiptoe position. He grasps the giant's hand with both arms: his right arm is raised vertically and his right hand rests on Antaeus' wrist with the palm facing down, while his left hand rests palm down on the outside of Antaeus' palm. He bends and tilts his head to the left, perhaps to look at Virgil to the left. His mouth is open. He wears a long gown and has long hair.

Antaeus is shown depositing Dante on the floor of Cocytus, in the lower left corner of the design. Virgil already stands on the ledge, facing right. He reaches out both arms at about 45 degrees to either side of Dante, who is still hanging from Antaeus' right hand. Virgil's right hand may rest on Dante's left hip. Virgil wears a long gown; its shape indicates that his right leg is bent backwards at the knee. He has long hair.

desc.objtitle:
The Circle of Traitors: The Alberti Brothers,
Object 67 (Butlin 812.64)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "22" top right, and "N58 next at p 47 this should be N61" in the center of the sheet. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design. The surface of this lake is suspended in frozen ripples across the bottom of the design, and in larger waves above the sinners who appear in the scene. Wash in the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. It is dark to the right, and lighter at the left. Dante and Virgil stand together near the left edge of the design. Dante stands facing away to the right of Virgil, obscuring him slightly. He bends to the right at the waist. His right arm is by his side but bent up at the elbow; he raises his open right hand and holds it with the vertical palm facing away. Virgil, to the left, faces forward but turns his head to the right. His right arm is down by his side; this hand is open with the palm facing down. The sinners punished here are traitors of various stripes. One lies supine just to the left of Virgil. The figure's head extends out toward the viewer, bent backwards so that it faces forward and up but is seen upside down. Its body extends away and its legs may be bent up. Its head seems to be partly submerged in the ice of the frozen lake. The face of another sinner, seen in profile looking up, partially emerges from the surface of the frozen lake just above the bottom edge of the design. Two sinners sit on the ice, positioned shoulder-to-shoulder at the right side of the design. They are Alessandro and Napoleone degli Alberti, brothers who murdered each other. The rightmost brother sits facing forward and right, bending forward slightly. His left arm is down by his side, while his right arm is hidden behind his brother. He bends his head back sharply: his long curly hair and beard are tangled with the hair of his brother, to the left; their hair is frozen together. The leftmost brother sits facing left and away; bending or leaning backwards slightly, he twists at the waist so that his torso in particular is seen from behind. His right arm is down and drawn back slightly, and he may brace his weight on his right hand, which seems to rest on the ice behind him with the palm down. His left arm is down and drawn away across his lap. His head is bent back sharply and his short hair is frozen in tangles with his brother's hair. This brother also has a short beard. To the right of the rightmost brother, another sinner lies supine on the ice with his head out towards the viewer and his lower body extending away. His knees are bent up. His head is tilted back so that his face looks forward, seen upside down. His figure is sketched lightly, making other features difficult to distinguish, but his right arm seems to be raised and bent over his torso; his right lower arm and hand may rest on his raised thighs. Just to the right of Dante, the head and right shoulder of one sinner barely emerge from the frozen surface, facing up and seen from above. This sinner's eyes are down or closed. Just to the right of Dante's knee, the head of another sinner is visible looking forward and slightly left. A scarf or hood wraps this sinner's head, and a larger hat may surmount this covering. He may be a priest. To the right of Dante a sinner dressed like a knight is visible from the waist up looking forward. His head is tilted to the left so that his right cheek rests on his right shoulder. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow. His grasps the handle of a sword with this hand; the sword lies along the surface of the ice to the right. His right elbow may rest on the shoulder of the sinner to the left. He is wearing a cloak that drapes his shoulders over a full suit of armor, including a breastplate. He is also wearing a helmet. Above the leg of the leftmost Alberti brother, the upper body of a sinner wearing the garb of a monk faces forward. This figure is visible from the chest up, above the ice. He wears a monk's cowl with the hood drawn around his face. His eyes are lowered and frozen tears stand on his face. The face of another sinner appears just to the left of the leftmost Alberti brother's left shoulder. This sinner wears a faintly sketched crown, like a king. He faces forward with eyes lowered slightly. To the left of the monk, the head of a sinner wearing a crown appears. This figure looks forward with mouth open slightly.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design. The surface of this lake is suspended in frozen ripples near the bottom edge of the design, and in larger waves above the sinners who appear in this scene.
Wash in the top half of the design suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds. It is dark to the right, and lighter at the left.

Dante and Virgil stand together near the left edge of the design. Dante stands facing away to the right of Virgil, obscuring him slightly. He bends to the right at the waist. His head is lowered slightly and turned to the right, so that his face is seen in profile from behind. His eyes seem to be lowered and he may be looking at the sinners ranged below him. His right arm is by his side but bent up at the elbow; he raises his open right hand and holds it with the vertical palm facing away. The long gown he wears is transparent, so that his legs are visible through its folds. His right leg is bent forward slightly at the knee. His long curly hair falls down his back.

Dante and Virgil stand together near the left edge of the design. Virgil stands slightly to the left of Dante, and partly obscured by him. He faces forward, but turns his head to the right. He may be looking at the sinners below. His right arm is down by his side; this hand is open with the palm facing down. He wears a long gown and has long curly hair.

The sinners punished here are traitors of various stripes. One lies supine just to the left of Virgil. The figure's head extends out toward the viewer, bent backwards so that it faces forward and up but is seen upside down. Its body extends away and its legs may be bent up. Its eyes may be closed or lowered. Its head seems to be partly submerged in the ice of the frozen lake. This figure is sketched lightly in pencil, so additional features are difficult to discern.

The sinners punished here are traitors of various stripes. The face of one sinner, seen in profile looking up, partially emerges from the surface of the frozen lake just above the bottom edge of the design. Shadows on the frozen surface to the left and right of the face suggest the sinner's body beneath the ice, but it is impossible to distinguish anything about its position or features.

The sinners punished here are traitors of various stripes. Most are submerged in the frozen lake, but two sit on the ice, positioned shoulder-to-shoulder at the right side of the design. They are Alessandro and Napoleone degli Alberti, brothers who murdered each other. The rightmost brother sits facing forward and right, bending forward slightly. His thighs slant downward together and disappear beneath the surface of the ice. His left arm is down by his side, while his right arm is hidden behind his brother. He bends his head back sharply: his long curly hair and beard are tangled with the hair of his brother, to the left; their hair is frozen together. His mouth may be open slightly. He is nude. The leftmost brother sits facing left and away; bending or leaning backwards slightly, he twists at the waist so that his torso in particular is seen from behind. His right arm is down and drawn back slightly, and he may brace his weight on his right hand, which seems to rest on the ice behind him with the palm down. His left arm is down and drawn away across his lap. His left leg extends to the left and submerges beneath the ice at the knee. His head, seen in profile, is bent back sharply and his short hair is tangled with the hair of his brother, to the right; their hair is frozen together. He also has a short beard. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth and perhaps tongue. He is nude and muscular.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake, but two sit on the ice at the right side of the design. They are the Alberti brothers. To the right of the rightmost brother, another sinner lies supine on the ice with his head out towards the viewer and his lower body extending away. His knees are bent up. His head is tilted back so that his face looks forward, seen upside down. His figure is sketched lightly, making other features difficult to distinguish, but his right arm seems to be raised and bent over his torso; his right lower arm and hand may rest on his raised thighs.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake. Just to the right of Dante, the head and right shoulder of one sinner barely emerge from the frozen surface, facing up and seen from above. It is difficult to discern the sinner's gender. This sinner's eyes are down or closed. Its hair is swept back into the ice, and may be long or short. The right shoulder of this figure seems to be nude. Its mouth may be open.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake. Just to the right of Dante's knee, the head of a sinner is visible looking forward and slightly left. A scarf or hood wraps the sinner's head, and a larger hat may surmount this covering. He may be a priest. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open, perhaps showing his teeth. His right shoulder is just visible below his chin.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake. To the right of Dante, a sinner dressed like a knight is visible from the waist up looking forward. His head is tilted to the left so that his right cheek rests on his right shoulder. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow. He grasps the handle of a sword with this hand; the sword lies along the surface of the ice to the right. His right elbow may rest on the shoulder of the sinner to the left. He is wearing a cloak that drapes his shoulders over a full suit of armor, including a breastplate. He is also wearing a helmet. His long curly hair spills out of his helmet and down over his shoulders. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open slightly.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake, but two sit on the ice at the right side of the design. They are the Alberti brothers. Above the leg of the leftmost brother, the upper body of a sinner wearing the garb of a monk faces forward. This figure is visible from the chest up, above the ice. He wears a monk's cowl with the hood drawn around his face. A line of buttons extends down the front of the garment, below his collar. A wisp of curly hair escapes from beneath the hood, over his forehead. His eyes are lowered and frozen tears stand on his face. His mouth is open, displaying teeth and tongue.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake, but two sit on the ice at the right side of the design. They are the Alberti brothers. The face of a sinner in the lake appears just to the left of the leftmost Alberti brother's left shoulder. This sinner wears a faintly sketched crown, like a king. He faces forward with eyes lowered slightly. He may be bald, or may have short hair. Only his head is visible.

Most of the traitorous sinners punished here are submerged in the frozen lake, but the two Alberti brothers sit on the ice at the right side of the design. Above the legs of the leftmost brother, the upper body of a sinner wearing the garb of a monk faces forward. The head of a sinner wearing a crown, like a king or queen, appears to the left of the monk. Only the head of this figure, which seems to have feminine features, is visible. He or she looks forward with mouth open slightly. The figure's hair may be long or short.

lg.l:
Virgil
dante These names are inscribed just to the left ("Virgil") and above and slightly to the right ("dante") of the heads of the two figures standing on the left.
HELL Canto 32 This ink inscription is offset slightly above its pencil under-writing.

desc.objtitle:
Dante Striking Against Bocca Degli Abati Dante Strikes Against Bocca Degli Abbati,
Object 68 (Butlin 812.65)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design. The base of a rock bridge is visible at the right side of the design, rising from the surface of the frozen lake to the upper right corner of the design. Petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the bridge. Wash to the left of the rock bridge at the right edge of the design suggests a dark sky, perhaps with clouds, which grows lighter as it approaches the left edge of the design. A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. This may be stone or frozen ice. An upside down face may appear in the mound, looking forward. Shadow covers the surface of the lake in the distance to the right of this mound. There are slight indications of another hill, or the foot of a rock bridge, just above the low mound. Dante stands on the ice at the left side of the design, facing forward and slightly to the right. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down. His left arm is down by his side, and he holds his left hand very slightly forward, with his vertical palm facing out. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; his open right hand is raised with the vertical palm facing out. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly. Virgil faces forward and slightly to the right. He bends his head and tilts it to the right. His left arm is bent up at the torso, and his left hand rests palm down on his shoulder. He may rest his cheek on this hand gently. The head and shoulders of Bocca degli Abbati, a traitor to his hometown of Florence, rise above the surface of the frozen lake in the lower left corner of the design. He faces forward, but turns his head up and slightly to the left, tilting it back as well; he may be looking towards Dante, above. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his eyes are wide. His open hands are raised above the ice. The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. One appears in profile looking up in the lower right corner of the design. A slight convexity to the left may be this figure's torso. To the left of this torso, another face seen in profile looks up. One appears in the distance to the right of Virgil, looking forward and slightly up. This figure's eyes are closed or lowered. Other shapes surrounding this head may be other heads, but their features are impossible to distinguish. Another head, looking forward with closed eyes, is visible on the surface of the lake to the right of this grouping. Other indistinct shapes on the surface of the lake may be body parts of additional figures, or may be frozen ripples.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell, on a frozen lake that stretches across the bottom of the design.

The base of a rock bridge is visible at the right side of the design, rising from the surface of the frozen lake to the upper right corner of the design. Petrified or frozen nude human forms appear in the bridge. These are sketched lightly in pencil, making gender and other details difficult to distinguish. One face appears upside down and looking forward near the surface of the lake, just to the left of the right edge of the design. A second upside down face looking forward and up is visible to the left of the first. A nude body with legs together extends upward from this second face. The figure seems to bend forward at the waist and its arms may be extended out horizontally from the shoulders, resting on the surface of the frozen lake. A third figure may huddle facing forward just to the left of the second figure's torso. This figure's knees seem to be bent and drawn up. It may rest its hands on its knees.
Wash to the left of the rock bridge at the right edge of the design suggests a dark sky, perhaps with clouds, which grows lighter as it approaches the left edge of the design.

A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. This may be stone or frozen ice. An upside down face may appear in the mound, looking forward. This petrified or frozen form echoes those in the rock bridge at the right side of the design. There are slight indications of another hill, or the foot of a rock bridge, above the low mound.
A rock or low mound is visible at the left edge of the design, near the lower left corner. Shadow covers the surface of the lake in the distance to the right of this mound.

Dante stands on the ice at the left side of the design, facing forward and slightly to the right. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down. His left arm is down by his side, and he holds his left hand very slightly forward, with his vertical palm facing out. His right arm is down and bent forward at the elbow; his open right hand is raised with the vertical palm facing out. His feet emerge from beneath the hem of his long transparent gown. He has long hair.

Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly, at the left side of the design. Virgil faces forward and slightly to the right. He bends his head and tilts it to the right. His left arm is bent up at his torso, and his left hand rests palm down on his shoulder. He may rest his cheek on this hand gently. His eyes are lowered. He has long hair and wears a long gown.

The head and shoulders of Bocca degli Abati, a traitor to his hometown of Florence, rise above the surface of the frozen lake in the lower left corner of the design. He faces forward, but turns his head up and slightly to the left, tilting it back as well; he may be looking towards Dante, above. His mouth is open, displaying his teeth, and his eyes are wide. His open hands are raised above the ice: his vertical right palm faces forward, while his left palm faces out and slightly left. His long, curly hair falls behind his shoulders. He seems to be nude. The ice in front of his torso is cracked.

The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. One appears in profile looking up in the lower right corner of the design. A slight convexity to the left may be this figure's torso.

The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. One appears in profile looking up in the lower right corner of the design. To the left of this sinner's convex torso, another face seen in profile looks up. Penciled lines to the left of this face may be an additional body part belonging to the same figure—perhaps an arm. Other features of this figure's body are impossible to discern.

The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. One appears in the distance to the right of Virgil, looking forward and slightly up. This figure's eyes are closed or lowered. He seems to have a short beard. Other shapes surrounding this head may be other heads, but their features are impossible to distinguish.

The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. One appears in the distance to the right of Virgil, looking forward and slightly up, and surrounded by what may be additional heads. Another head, looking forward, is visible on the surface of the lake to the right of this grouping. This figure's eyes seem to be closed.

The faces of frozen traitors punished in this circle of hell emerge from the surface of the lake. Two seen in profile looking up appear near the lower edge of the lake; two more appear above, looking forward. Other indistinct shapes on the surface of the lake may be body parts of additional figures, or may be frozen ripples.

desc.objtitle:
Dante Tugging at Bocca's Hair Dante Grabs Bocca Degli Abbati by the Hair,
Object 69 (Butlin 812.66 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "47" and "Hell Canto 33" bottom right, and "N 59 next at p 46" top left. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. A frozen lake stretches across the bottom of the design. Wash above the frozen lake suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds particularly in the upper right corner of the design. A cave rests on the ice of the frozen lake at the left side of the design. Irregular lines on the outside of the cave suggest that it too is frozen. Shadow fills the opening above the figures inside the cave. Dante stands near the middle of the design, braced as he wrenches the hair of Bocca degli Abati, who is immersed in the lake below. Dante faces away and to the left, with his bent left leg drawn forward and his slightly bent right leg extended backward. His right arm is extended at 45 degrees and he grasps Bocca's hair with this hand. Dante's body leans forward and to the left with his effort. His long curly hair spills down over his left shoulder. A transparent gown sweeps over his legs to the ground, its folds suggesting the force of Dante's motion. Virgil stands to the left of Dante, facing away and to the right. He is seen partly from behind, though he turns his head to display his face in profile, perhaps because he is watching Dante. His right arm is by his side, bent away at the elbow across his chest. Bocca degli Abati, who betrayed his own army in battle, is immersed in the frozen lake up to his mid-torso. Only his head, shoulders, and the top of his chest are visible in the lower right corner of the design. Dante's right hand is grasping Bocca's hair, which seems to be relatively long; Dante's force has yanked the traitor's head back. Bocca's face is thus seen in profile, looking up and slightly right. His mouth is open wide, and the text suggests he is speaking or screaming ("barking" in some translations) in pain. The veins of his neck stand out with the effort. To the right of Bocca degli Abati, Buoso da Duero of Cremona is also submerged in the frozen lake, as punishment for betraying the army he commanded. He is visible above the mid-torso, facing forward. His head is bent back and turned to the left. His eyes are raised, perhaps to look at Dante, and his mouth is open, showing his teeth and perhaps his tongue. The upper body of Archbishop Ruggieri degli Ubaldini of Pisa is visible huddled inside the cave at the left side of the design. During his life Ruggieri betrayed Count Ugolino della Gherardesca, who himself betrayed his relatives; Ugolino is here shown attacking the archbishop. Ruggieri faces left and leans heavily on his left arm, which is extended down to the left. His left hand is braced on the surface of the lake, palm down. Ruggieri's head is lowered, and a lock of his long curly hair hangs down past his forehead. Blood stains his hair above his shoulder. His abandoned crosier rests on the ground below the opening of the cave. Ugolino's head and left shoulder are shown resting on Ruggieri's bent back, facing left and down. Ugolino bends over and leans against the archbishop in the act of biting Ruggieri's head. Ugolino's mouth is open, displaying his teeth prominently. Drops of blood drip from Ugolino's mouth.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the ninth circle of hell. A frozen lake stretches across the bottom of the design.
Wash above the frozen lake suggests the sky, perhaps with clouds particularly in the upper right corner of the design.

A cave rests on the ice of the frozen lake at the left side of the design. Irregular lines on the outside of the cave suggest that it too is frozen. Shadow fills the opening above the figures inside the cave.

Dante stands near the middle of the design, braced as he wrenches the hair of Bocca degli Abati, who is immersed in the lake below. Dante faces away and to the left, with his bent left leg drawn forward and his slightly bent right leg extended backward. His right foot is on tiptoe. He turns his head to the right so that his face is seen in profile from behind. His right arm is extended at 45 degrees and he grasps Bocca's hair with this hand. Dante's body leans forward and to the left with his effort. His long curly hair spills down over his left shoulder. A transparent gown sweeps over his legs to the ground, its folds suggesting the force of Dante's motion.

Virgil stands to the left of Dante, facing away and to the right. He is seen partly from behind, though he turns his head to display his face in profile, perhaps because he is watching Dante. His head is also bent down slightly. His right arm is by his side, bent away at the elbow across his chest. He has long curly hair. His right foot partly emerges from beneath his transparent gown.

Bocca degli Abati, who betrayed his own army in battle, is immersed in the frozen lake up to his mid-torso. Only his head, shoulders, and the top of his chest are visible in the lower right corner of the design. His shoulders face forward, but he leans to the right slightly. The upper portion of his left arm is down by his side; his right arm and lower left arm are not visible. Dante's right hand is grasping Bocca's hair, which seems to be relatively long; Dante's force has yanked the traitor's head back. Bocca's face is thus seen in profile, looking up and slightly right. His mouth is open wide, and the text suggests he is speaking or screaming ("barking" in some translations) in pain. The veins of his neck stand out with the effort. He is nude.

To the right of Bocca degli Abati, Buoso da Duero of Cremona is also submerged in the frozen lake, as punishment for betraying the army he commanded. He is visible above the mid-torso, facing forward. His head is bent back and turned to the left. His eyes are raised, perhaps to look at Dante, and his mouth is open, showing his teeth and perhaps his tongue. He is nude and has short curly hair. Only his upper arms are visible; they seem to be down.

The upper body of Archbishop Ruggieri degli Ubaldini of Pisa is visible huddled inside the cave at the left side of the design. During his life Ruggieri betrayed Count Ugolino della Gherardesca, who himself betrayed his relatives; Ugolino is here shown attacking the archbishop. Ruggieri faces left and leans heavily on his left arm, which is extended down to the left. His left hand is braced on the surface of the lake, palm down. Ruggieri's head is lowered, and a lock of his long curly hair hangs down past his forehead. Blood stains his hair above his shoulder. He seems to be wearing a shirt or gown. His abandoned crosier rests on the ground below the opening of the cave.

The upper body of Archbishop Ruggieri degli Ubaldini of Pisa is visible huddled inside the cave at the left side of the design. During his life Ruggieri betrayed Count Ugolino della Gherardesca, who himself betrayed his relatives; Ugolino is here shown attacking the archbishop. Ugolino's head and left shoulder are shown resting on Ruggieri's bent back, facing left and down. Ugolino bends over and leans against the archbishop in the act of biting Ruggieri's head. Ugolino's mouth is open, displaying his teeth prominently. Drops of blood drip from Ugolino's mouth. His long curly hair drapes over his shoulder and falls to Ugolino's lowered head. Ugolino also has a long beard. He may be nude, or may wear a shirt or gown.

lg.l:
Canto 32
The inscription is very faint and covered with gray wash. Our reading of the number is conjectural.
Ugolino This faint inscription is above the head of the figure on the left biting into another figure's head or neck.

desc.objtitle:
Ugolino Relating His Death Ugolino Tells of His Fate,
Object 70 (Butlin 812.67)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "48" top right. This inscription is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place on a frozen lake in the ninth circle of hell. The mound of a cave extends three-quarters of the way across the design from the left edge. Shadows appear in its opening around the figures who crouch inside. Irregular lines on the surface of the cave's mound suggest that it too is frozen. Similar lines appear on the ground of the cave's mouth, and cross through the figures who huddle there. Wash at the top of the design above the cave suggests the sky. It may be streaked with clouds, particularly in the upper left corner. Dante stands to the right of the cave's mouth, facing left. His head is lowered and turned forward, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His arms are crossed over his chest, and both hands rest on his breastbone, left over right. He may rest his chin on his hands. Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly. Virgil faces away and to the left, so that he is seen partly from behind. His head is lowered, but his face is mostly hidden. Archbishop Ruggieri degli Ubaldini kneels at the mouth of the cave in the lower left corner of the design. He faces left, but hunches over with drooped shoulders; his head hangs and he looks down. His left leg is bent and drawn up beneath him. His left arm is extended down and his left hand seems to rest on the ground, tucked beneath his left shin. His ecclesiastical gown has been wrenched down and now circles his torso and upper arm loosely; his shoulder is nude. Red tinting indicates blood on his gown. His long curly hair hangs in strings and blood drips thickly from his neck. The archbishop's crosier, or staff, rests abandoned on the ice near the lower edge of the design. His hat, another potent symbol of his office, sits on the cave near his head; it is also bloody. It has a wide brim and a long tassel. Count Ugolino della Gherardesca kneels to the right of Ruggieri, whose body obscures him slightly. Ugolino faces forward. His left leg is bent beneath him. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down slightly. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open, revealing his teeth and perhaps tongue. The text indicates that he is speaking, telling his story to Dante and Virgil. Both of his forearms are bent up on either side of his torso; his open hands are raised with the vertical palms facing forward. Sketched lines near the ground to the right of Dante and Virgil suggest the indistinct pictures of several additional sinners punished as traitors in this trench.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place on a frozen lake in the ninth circle of hell. The mound of a cave extends three-quarters of the way across the design from the left edge. Shadows appear in its opening around the figures who crouch inside. Irregular lines on the surface of the cave's mound suggest that it too is frozen. Similar lines appear on the ground of the cave's mouth, and cross through the figures who huddle there.

The frozen lake extends across the bottom of the design, and is also visible to the right of the cave. Ripples on its surface may be frozen wavelets. Shadow falls on the surface of the lake near the middle of the right edge of the design.
Wash at the top of the design above the cave suggests the sky. It may be streaked with clouds, particularly in the upper left corner.

Dante stands to the right of the cave's mouth, facing left. His head is lowered and turned forward, so that his face is seen in three-quarters profile. His eyes seem to look up. His left arm is by his side, bent up across his chest. His lower right arm is bent up across his chest from the far side of his body, and both hands rest on his breastbone, left over right. He may rest his chin on his hands. He has long curly hair, and wears a long transparent gown, below which his left foot is visible.

Virgil stands to the right of Dante, who hides him slightly. Virgil faces away and to the left, so that he is seen partly from behind. His head is lowered, but his face is mostly hidden. He has long hair and wears a long gown.

Archbishop Ruggieri degli Ubaldini kneels at the mouth of the cave in the lower left corner of the design. He faces left, but hunches over with drooped shoulders; his head hangs and he looks down. His left leg is bent and drawn up beneath him. His left arm is extended down and his left hand seems to rest on the ground, tucked beneath his left shin. His ecclesiastical gown has been wrenched down and now circles his torso and upper arm loosely; his shoulder is nude. Red tinting indicate blood on his gown. His long curly hair hangs in strings and blood drips thickly from his neck. His tongue is visible in his open mouth.
The archbishop's crosier, or staff, rests abandoned on the ice near the lower edge of the design.
The archbishop's hat, another potent symbol of his office, sits on the cave near his head. It has a wide brim and a long tassel. Red tinting indicates blood on the hat.

Count Ugolino della Gherardesca kneels to the right of Ruggieri, whose body obscures him slightly. Ugolino faces forward. His left leg is bent beneath him. He tilts his head to the right and bends it down slightly. His eyes are raised and his mouth is open, revealing his teeth and perhaps tongue. The text indicates that he is speaking, telling his story to Dante and Virgil. Both of his forearms are bent up on either side of his torso; his open hands are raised with the vertical palms facing forward. He may bend to the right slightly. He has long curly hair and a long beard, and wears a gown.

Sketched lines near the ground to the right of Dante and Virgil suggest the indistinct figures of several additional sinners punished as traitors in this trench. They seem to sit, kneel, or crouch. Other features of their positions are impossible to discern.

desc.objtitle:
Ugolino and His Sons in Prison,
Object 71 (Butlin 812.68)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene is set in the cell where Count Ugolino della Gherardesca was imprisoned with his sons and grandsons. The design is only sketched in pencil, but lines to the left and right of Ugolino, who sits at the center, indicate the shape of the bare room, perhaps of stone, that became their tomb. A small square window(?) is visible above Ugolino's head. Count Ugolino sits facing forward with his legs bent up together before him. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and his arms and hands rest on the figures of his grandsons, Anselmuccio and Nino il Brigata, who sit at his sides. The grandson on the left sits with his knees drawn up before him. He leans to the right, against his grandfather. His head is bent back slightly, turned to the right, and tilted to the left. His mouth may be open. The grandson on the right sits with his knees drawn up in front of his chest. His left arm may be down by his legs, with his left hand resting on his left ankle. His head is bent and turned left slightly. Two angels fly or hover over Ugolino and his grandsons. The angel on the left faces right and down, with his(?) body extended down to the left. He may also be turned away, so that his head and body are seen from behind. The angel on the right faces left and down, but her(?) body is also turned slightly forward. Her arms are by her side but bent up across her chest, with her right arm folded over the left. Both angels wear long gowns and have large wings folded behind their backs. Ugolino's adult sons, Gaddo and Ugoccione, sit in the lower corners of the design. The son on the left sits facing right and slightly forward with his bent legs extended together out to the right. His slightly bent arms are down by his side and both hands rest on the floor, palms down. His head is bent back and his mouth is open; his teeth and tongue are visible. The son on the right sits facing left with his legs extended together along the floor. He may rest his back against a wall of the cell. His left arm is down by his side and his left hand rests on the floor, palm down. He bends his head and turns it forward slightly; his mouth may be open.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene is set in the cell where Count Ugolino della Gherardesca was imprisoned with his sons and grandsons. The design is only sketched in pencil, but lines to the left and right of Ugolino, who sits at the center, indicate the shape of the bare room, perhaps of stone, that became their tomb.
A small square window(?) is visible above Ugolino's head.

Count Ugolino della Gherardesca sits facing forward with his legs bent up together before him. His arms are raised at 45 degrees and his arms and hands rest on the figures of his grandsons, who sit to either side of him and lean against him. He has a long beard and his long curly hair spills over his shoulders. It is difficult to discern whether he is nude or wears clothing. He and his offspring are no doubt despairing.

Ugolino's two grandsons, Anselmuccio and Nino il Brigata, sit at his sides beneath the tiny window(?) in their prison. The grandson on the left sits with his knees drawn up before him. His hands may rest atop his knees. He leans to the right, against his grandfather. His head is bent back slightly, turned to the right, and tilted to the left. His mouth may be open. He has long curly hair. He may be nude, or may be wearing clothes. The grandson on the right sits with his knees drawn up in front of his chest. His left arm may be down by his legs, with his left hand resting on his left ankle. His head is bent and turned left slightly. He may be nude, or may be wearing clothes. He seems to have long hair.

Two angels fly or hover over Ugolino and his grandsons. The angel on the left faces right and down, with his(?) body extended down to the left. He may also be turned away, so that his head and body are seen from behind. The position of his arms is difficult to discern, but his right arm seems to be by his side and bent at the elbow. He wears a long gown and his hair is drawn back into a bun near the nape of her neck, although curly strands frame his face. His large wings are folded behind his back.

Two angels fly or hover over Ugolino and his grandsons. The angel on the right faces left and down, but her(?) body is also turned slightly forward. Her arms are by her side but bent up across her chest, with her right arm folded over the left. She wears a long gown. Tendrils of curly hair frame her face. Her large wings are folded behind her back.

Ugolino's adult sons, Gaddo and Ugoccione, sit in the lower corners of the design. The son on the left sits facing right and slightly forward with his bent legs extended together out to the right. His feet rest on their heels. He may lean his back against the wall of the cell on the left. His slightly bent arms are down by his side and both hands rest on the floor, palms down. His head is bent back and his mouth is open; his teeth and tongue are visible. He has long curly hair and seems to be nude. The son on the right sits facing left with his legs extended together along the floor. He may rest his back against a wall of the cell. His left arm is down by his side and his left hand rests on the floor, palm down. He bends his head and turns it forward slightly; his mouth may be open. He may be nude. He has long curly hair.

desc.objtitle:
Lucifer,
Object 72 (Butlin 812.69 recto)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "66" top right, "N 33 next at p 51" top right, the latter partly erased in the center of the sheet, and "Hell Canto 21" along the right margin. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the center of the earth, which is also the center of hell. The enormous figure of Lucifer stretches from top to bottom of this design. Facing forward, he is immersed to the waist in ice, which is opaque in areas and transparent in other areas. The smaller figures of sinners are frozen within the ice. The top half of the design is dark around the figure of Lucifer, except along the top edge above Lucifer's three heads. Of these heads, only the middle looks forward. The heads to left and right are bent down slightly, and look left and right respectively. His arms are by his side, bent up and away from his body at the elbows. His legs are bent and extend diagonally down to the right with his feet seemingly on tiptoe. He is nude. All three of his heads have beards and short curly hair; each wears a crown. The middle head, which is also the head most clearly delineated, holds the tiny figure of Judas Iscariot clamped in the teeth of its open mouth. Only Judas' lower body is visible: his legs dangle, slightly bent, from Lucifer's large mouth. Lucifer's two bat-like wings are spread wide on either side of his body. Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. They represent traitors. The head of one lies near the right edge of the design, not far from the lower right corner. He alone of the four giants appears young and clean-shaven. His face looks forward and his eyes are closed. His body stretches horizontally leftward across the design. His legs lie side-by-side; a serpent has wound itself around them. The reptile's head hangs down with mouth open and teeth showing. To the left of the serpent, a small male figure clings to the giant's lower legs. This figure hangs facing up with his torso horizontal and his arms and legs raised vertically and encircling the giant's legs. His head is turned slightly forward, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile, upside down and looking up. The head and shoulders of a second small figure are visible above and to the left of the head of the first, looking forward. This figure seems to be a male with short hair, holding its mouth open. The head of one of the other, older giants lies facing up just above the bottom edge of the design. He has long hair and a long beard, both of which meld into the ice. His eyes are closed. He wears a crown. The head of a third giant is visible lying to the right of Lucifer's left hip. This head is tilted back so that it is seen upside down, facing forward and to the right. He wears a crown and has long hair and a long beard. His eyes are closed. His supine body extends down to the left and seems to merge with the ice. A fourth giant is visible lying to the left of Lucifer's right thigh. He faces forward and up, with closed eyes. His body extends horizontally to the right and seems to merge with the ice. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a crown. Just below this giant's head, the upper body of a much smaller figure is visible. This figure seems to be male. His left arm is bent, with his hand down; his right arm is wrapped around his head. He faces forward with head lowered. He kneels on his right leg; his left leg is bent sharply at the knee. Above the giant's head sits a much smaller male, facing left and bending over with lowered head. He sits within a kind of cave in the ice. His slightly bent left arm reaches down below his left leg, which is bent and drawn up to his chest. He may lean on his thigh and rest his chin on his knee. He seems to have long hair, and may be nude. Flames rise around him inside the cave. Shadows fill the spaces between the flames inside the cave.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place in the center of the earth, which is also the center of hell. The enormous figure of Lucifer stretches from top to bottom of this design. He is immersed to the waist in ice, which is opaque in areas and transparent in other areas. The smaller figures of sinners are frozen within the ice.
The top half of the design is dark around the figure of Lucifer, except along the top edge above Lucifer's three heads.

Lucifer's large figure stretches from top to bottom of this design. Facing forward, he is immersed to the waist in ice, which is transparent in places and opaque in others. He has three heads, and only the middle looks forward. The heads to left and right are bent down slightly, and look left and right respectively. His arms are by his side, bent up and away from his body at the elbows. His hands are raised, but they are sketched indistinctly so that it is difficult to tell the position of his fingers. His legs are bent and extend diagonally down to the right with his feet seemingly on tiptoe. He is nude. All three of his heads have beards and short curly hair; each wears a crown. The middle head, which is also the head most clearly delineated, holds the tiny figure of Judas Iscariot clamped in the teeth of its open mouth. His two bat-like wings are spread wide on either side of his body.

Lucifer's large figure stretches from top to bottom of this design. He has three heads. The middle head holds the tiny figure of Judas Iscariot clamped in the teeth of its open mouth. Only Judas' lower body is visible: his legs dangle, slightly bent, from Lucifer's large mouth.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of one lies near the right edge of the design, not far from the lower right corner. He alone of the four giant figures appears young and clean-shaven. His face looks forward and his eyes are closed. His body stretches horizontally leftward across the design. His arms are not clearly visible. His legs lie side-by-side; a serpent has wound itself around them. To the left of the serpent, a small human figure also clings to the giant's legs.

The head of one giant is visible near the right edge of the design, not far from the lower right corner; his body stretches horizontally leftward across the design. A serpent has wrapped its body around his legs, which extend to the left. The reptile's head hangs down with mouth open and teeth showing.

The head of one giant lies near the right edge of the design, not far from the lower right corner; his body stretches horizontally leftward across the design. A small male figure clings to his lower legs, to the left of a serpent that has also wrapped itself around the giant's legs. The figure hangs facing up with his torso horizontal and his arms and legs raised vertically and encircling the giant's legs. His head is turned slightly forward, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile, upside down and looking up. His eyes are closed and he has short hair. He may be nude, or may be wearing clothes.

The head of a giant lies near the right edge of the design, not far from the lower right corner; his body stretches horizontally leftward across the design. A serpent has coiled itself around his legs, and a much smaller human figure similarly clings upside down to the left of the serpent. The head and shoulders of a second small figure are visible above and to the left of the head of the first, looking forward. This figure seems to be a male with short hair, holding its mouth open. His eyes may be raised.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of an older giant lies facing up just above the bottom edge of the design. He has long hair and a long beard, both of which meld into the ice. His eyes are closed. He wears a crown.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of an older giant is visible lying to the right of Lucifer's left hip. This head is tilted back so that it is seen upside down, facing forward and to the right. He wears a crown and has long hair and a long beard. His eyes are closed. His supine body extends down to the left and seems to merge with the ice.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of an older giant is visible lying to the left of Lucifer's right thigh. He faces forward and up, with closed eyes. His body extends horizontally to the right and seems to merge with the ice. He has long hair and a beard, and wears a crown.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of one of the three older giants is visible lying to the left of Lucifer's right thigh. Just below this giant's head, the upper body of a much smaller figure is visible. This figure seems to be male. His left arm is bent with the hand down; his right arm is wrapped around his head. He faces forward with head lowered. He kneels on his right leg; his left leg is sharply bent with a prominent left knee.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of one of the three older giants appears to the left of Lucifer's right thigh. A much smaller male form sits above this head, facing left and bending over with lowered head. He sits within a kind of cave in the ice. His slightly bent left arm reaches down below his left leg, which is bent and drawn up to his chest. He may lean on his thigh and rest his chin on his knee. He seems to have long hair, and may be nude. Flames rise around him inside the cave.

Four giant forms are visible frozen beneath the ice in the bottom half of the design. The head of one appears to the left of Lucifer's right thigh. A much smaller form sits above this head, facing left and bending over with lowered head. He seems to sit within a kind of cave in the ice. Flames rise around him inside the cave. Shadows fill the spaces between the flames inside the cave.

desc.objtitle:
Dante with Virgil and Cato,
Object 73 (Butlin 812.71)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "60" and "Pg. Canto 1" top right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Dante, Virgil, and Cato stand together on the shore at the base of the mountain of Purgatory. The shore runs across the bottom of the design. The mountain of Purgatory forms a wall that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending from the lower left corner. Four stars glitter in the sky above the figures' heads. Virgil stands at the left side of the grouping of three figures. He faces left and away, and is seen mostly from behind. His bent left leg is extended behind him, with his left foot on tiptoe. He bends and twists to the right at the waist, and turns his head right so that his face is seen in profile. His slightly bent right arm is down and he points at the ground with his right index finger. His left arm is raised vertically, with the hand opened and vertical palm facing away. Dante stands to the right of Virgil at the bottom of the design. He faces forward and bends to the right slightly. His head is bent slightly, and turned and tilted to the right slightly. His arms are by his side, bent forward at the elbows with both of his open hands raised. His vertical palms face forward. His long curly hair cascades over his shoulders. Of the three figures, Cato stands nearest the right edge of the design. He faces forward and to the left. His right arm is extended and raised at 45 degrees. He points to the ground with his right index finger. His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across the chest with his open left hand raised, vertical palm facing in towards the body. Cato has long hair and a long beard. A cloud surrounds his figure from head to foot.

component.illusobjdesc: Dante, Virgil, and Cato stand together on the shore at the base of the mountain of Purgatory. The shore runs across the bottom of the design.
The mountain of Purgatory forms a stone wall that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending from the lower left corner. A few pencil lines on its top do not clearly represent anything.
Four stars glitter in the sky above the figures' heads.

Virgil stands at the left side of the grouping of three figures at the bottom of the design. He faces left and away, and is seen mostly from behind. His bent left leg is extended behind him, with his left foot on tiptoe. He bends and twists to the right at the waist, and turns his head right so that his face is seen in profile. His slightly bent right arm is down and he points at the ground with his right index finger. His left arm is raised vertically, with the hand opened and vertical palm facing away. He wears a transparent long gown and has long curly hair.

Dante stands to the right of Virgil at the bottom of the design. He faces forward and bends to the right slightly. His head is bent slightly, and turned and tilted to the right. His arms are by his side, bent forward at the elbows with both of his open hands raised. His vertical palms face forward. His long curly hair cascades over his shoulders. He wears a long gown.

Of the three figures, Cato stands nearest the right edge of the design. He faces forward and to the left. His right arm is extended and raised at 45 degrees. He points to the ground with his right index finger. His left arm is by his side, bent up at the elbow across his chest with his open left hand raised, vertical palm facing in towards his body. Cato has long hair and a long beard, and wears a long gown. A cloud surrounds his figure from head to foot.

lg.l:
Canto 1
The inscription is very faint. A few pencil strokes below this line may be another inscription, but it is illegible.
Dante Canto The inscription is extremely faint; our reading is conjectural.
Cato This faint inscription appears above the nimbus surrounding the head of the figure on the right.

desc.objtitle:
Virgil Girding Dante's Brow with a Rush Virgil Girds Dante's Brow with a Reed,
Object 74 (Butlin 812.70)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "61" top left, and "Pg Canto 2" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Dante and Virgil kneel on the sandy shore at the base of the mountain of Purgatory. The shore runs across the bottom of the design. The mountain of Purgatory forms a wall that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending from the lower left corner. The sea stretches across the design, above the shore, from the right edge of the design to the mountain of Purgatory on the left. Small waves ripple its surface. Shadows appear near the horizon, particularly towards the left side of the design. A row of reedy rushes with small leaves lines the shore behind the figures of Dante and Virgil. Wash in the top half of the design indicates the sky. The sun peeks over the horizon near the right edge of the design, sending long beams through the sky in the upper half of the design and over the water below. A large cloud stretches across the top of the design and arches from the middle of the top edge down to the left to meet the sea at the horizon line. This cloud may cast the shadows visible on the water. It is especially heavy and dark nearer the upper right corner of the design. Dante rests on hands and knees at the bottom of the design, facing right. Both of his arms are slightly bent. His hands rest palm down on the bank. He looks down. Virgil rests on his knees facing left, just to the right of Dante, twisting slightly at the waist so that his upper body faces partly forward. He is tying a rush around Dante's head. Virgil's left arm is by his side, bent forward at the elbow. He holds one end of the rush with the fingers of his left hand, which is near Dante's forehead. His right arm is by his side but bent upward; his right hand is raised to chest-level, over Dante's head, and he holds another end of the rush with this hand. His head is bent and turned forward, and his mouth may be open slightly.

component.illusobjdesc: Dante and Virgil kneel on the sandy shore at the base of the mountain of Purgatory. The shore runs across the bottom of the design.
The mountain of Purgatory forms a wall that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending from the lower left corner.

The sea stretches across the design, above the shore, from the right edge of the design to the mountain of Purgatory on the left. Small waves ripple its surface. Shadows appear near the horizon, particularly towards the left side of the design.
A row of reedy rushes with small leaves lines the shore behind the figures of Dante and Virgil.
Wash in the top half of the design indicates the sky.
The sun peeks over the horizon near the right edge of the design, sending long beams through the sky in the upper half of the design and over the water below.

A large cloud stretches across the top of the design and arches from the middle of the top edge down to the left to meet the sea at the horizon line. This cloud may cast the shadows visible on the water. It is especially heavy and dark nearer the upper right corner of the design.

Dante rests on hands and knees at the bottom of the design, facing right. Both of his arms are slightly bent. His hands rest palm down on the bank. He looks down. He wears a long gown, below which at least his right foot shows. His long hair is drawn back behind his neck and shoulders. Virgil, to the right, is tying a rush around Dante's head.

Virgil rests on his knees facing left, just to the right of Dante, twisting slightly at the waist so that his upper body faces partly forward. He is tying a rush around Dante's head. Virgil's left arm is by his side, bent forward at the elbow. He holds one end of the rush with the fingers of his left hand, which is near Dante's forehead. His right arm is by his side but bent upward; his right hand is raised to chest-level, over Dante's head, and he holds another end of the rush with this hand. His head is bent and turned forward, and his mouth may be open slightly. He has long curly hair and wears a long gown.

desc.objtitle:
The Angel in the Boat Departing after Wafting Over the Souls for Purgatory The Angelic Boat Returning after Depositing Souls on the Shore with Cato Chiding,
Object 75 (Butlin 812.72)

illustration.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place on the shore below the mountain of Purgatory. The sandy shore stretches across the bottom of the design. The mountain of Purgatory forms a wall or cliff that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending up from the lower left corner. The mouth of a cave opens in the base of the wall or cliff, in the lower left corner of the design. A table supporting a lit candle and an altar -- perhaps a diptych -- is visible through the mouth of the cave. The sea extends across the design, above the shore, from the right edge of the design to the mountain of Purgatory on the left. Small waves ripple its surface. Wash in the top half of the design, above the sea, suggests the sky. It is darkest in the upper left corner. A crescent-shaped boat, reminiscent of a waxing or waning moon, rests lightly in the sea near the middle of the right edge of the design. A bright angel stands in the boat with his large wings spread wide. He seems to face away. His arms are raised at 45 degrees on either side of his body. His long hair flies around his head and the skirts of his gown sweep leftward as if in a wind. Light beams from his body and brightens the sky around him. Cato stands in the lower left corner of the design, partially hiding the entrance to the cave. He faces right. His right arm is bent across his chest. His arms may be folded and his left hand may be visible on his right elbow. A group of spirits destined for Purgatory stand on the shore below the mountain, having just arrived on the boat that is now some distance from the shore. At the far left of the group an indistinctly drawn figure stands looking forward. This figure is just visible between the mountain and another figure to the right, who stands facing away and wearing a long gown. This figure may be male or female. Both arms are down by its side and bent forward, up, and out at the elbows. The figure's hands are raised and may be open with palms facing up. Third from left, a figure stands facing forward with right leg forward and left leg extended backward. This figure's left foot may be on tiptoe. His or her arms are raised overhead at 135 degrees, bent to the vertical at the elbows. The figure's head is tilted to the right. Fourth from left, a figure stands facing forward, tilting his or her head back and turning it left. This figure's arms are down and bent across his or her chest. The figure's hands are slightly raised, with palms together. Fifth from left, one stands facing right and possibly turning his or her head away. This figure's right arm may be bent across his or her torso. Faint lines to the right of this figure suggest a sixth standing figure. Other features of this sixth figure are impossible to discern. Dante and Casella face one another and embrace at the right side of the group. Their indistinct features make their identities difficult to specify. The figure on the left faces right and clasps his friend with bent right arm raised and his lower right arm and hand resting on the other figure's left shoulder. The shape of the long gown he wears suggests that his right leg is extended backwards. The figure on the right faces left and returns the embrace with his left arm wrapped around the first figure's torso. He wears a long gown as well, and seems to extend his left leg backward. The head of the figure on the right may rest on the right shoulder of the figure on the left. To the right of the group of spirits, and a short distance from them, Virgil stands facing left. He wears a long gown and seems to have long hair.

component.illusobjdesc: This scene takes place on the shore below the mountain of Purgatory. The sandy shore stretches across the bottom of the design.
The mountain of Purgatory forms a wall or cliff that is visible at the left edge of the design, extending up from the lower left corner.

The mouth of a cave opens in the base of the wall or cliff, in the lower left corner of the design. A table supporting a lit candle and an altar -- perhaps a diptych -- is visible through the mouth of cave.
The sea extends across the design, above the shore, from the right edge of the design to the mountain of Purgatory on the left. Small waves ripple its surface.
Wash in the top half of the design, above the sea, suggests the sky. It is darkest in the upper left corner.
A crescent-shaped boat, reminiscent of a waxing or waning moon, rests lightly in the sea near the middle of the right edge of the design. It may cast a shadow on the water below and to the right.

A bright angel stands in the boat with his large wings spread wide. He seems to face away. His arms are raised at 45 degrees on either side of his body.
