The arc second from the top is associated with the Cherubim, which Blake illustrates as a group of female angels at either end of the arc, and with the Fixed Stars. Blake depicts the Fixed Stars as two angelic figures standing near each other at the center of the arc. The figures seem to face one another, with the one on the left facing right, and the one on the right facing left. They bend their heads and wear long gowns; their wings are bent up behind their backs. At each side of the arc, the heads of three Cherubim are grouped together, looking forward. The angel nearest the Fixed Stars on both sides raises her inside arm vertically. The head and shoulders of God appear above the uppermost arc, just below the top edge of the design. He faces forward and may lower his head, turning it slightly to the right. His right arm is raised and bent upward at the elbow. His elbow rests on the arc below. He holds his raised right hand open with the palm facing forward, and may be bestowing a blessing with this hand. The fingers of his left hand, which is palm down, rest gently on the arc. His wings are spread wide on either side of his body, just below the upper edge of the design. He has a beard and long hair, and wears a gown. Sketched circles to the left of God's right arm and to the right of his left arm suggest the heads of two crowds of Seraphim, whose other features are impossible to discern.

component.illusobjdesc: This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. Although the Paradiso describes Dante's vision as being of concentric rings, Blake has drawn the rings as curved layers or arcs that cross the design horizontally. A heavenly body is associated with each arc, and its representation appears at the center of that arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. Flat ground covered with grass runs across the bottom of the design and represents the earth, the material world. A low hill or knoll, also covered with grass, rises in the center of this flat ground.

This design depicts Dante's Paradisal vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. Wash throughout the design suggests the sky.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. Although the Paradiso describes Dante's vision as being of concentric rings, Blake has drawn the rings as curved layers or arcs that cross the design horizontally. A pair of figures, or paired groupings of figures, appear on each arc. Clouds surround these figures.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The lowest arc is associated with the angels and the moon. The moon appears as a small sphere at the center of the arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The lowest arc is associated with the moon and the angels. Blake depicts the head and shoulders of two of these angels, one at either end of the arc. The angel on the left, who may be male, looks forward steadily. His wings are folded and raised behind his head. His long curly hair falls down his neck. Clouds mostly hide his body below the neck, although his left shoulder is just suggested.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The lowest arc is associated with the moon and the angels. Blake depicts the head and shoulders of two of these angels, one at either end of the arc. The nude shoulders of the angel on the right face forward and slightly left. This angel, who may be male, tilts his head back and turns it to the left slightly. His eyes are raised. He may have short hair, or longer hair may be drawn behind his neck. His folded wings are raised behind his head.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second to lowest is associated with Mercury and the archangels. Mercury is depicted as a small sphere, surrounded by a cloud, at the center of this arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second to lowest is associated with Mercury and the archangels. Blake depicts the head and shoulders of two archangels, one at each end of the arc. The archangel on the left, probably male, looks forward. He turns his head slightly to the right and tilts it back, eyes raised. His mouth is open slightly and his upper teeth are just visible. He has short curly hair. A circle around his head suggests a halo. His large wings are bent up behind his back. A second set of wings drawn up inside the first may be just visible to either side of his head. He may be nude, or may wear a gown, the draping neckline of which seems just visible at his collar. His right shoulder is visible, but his left is hidden behind the head of the angel below.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second from lowest is associated with Mercury and the archangels. Blake depicts the head and shoulders of two archangels, one at each end of the arc. The shoulders of the male archangel on the right face to the right, but he turns his head to the left, tilting it back and raising his eyes to look up. His face is visible in three-quarters profile looking forward and left. He has short curly hair. A semi-circular line above his head suggests a halo. His wings are folded and raised behind his back. A second set of wings drawn up inside the first may be visible just to either side of his head. He may be nude, or may wear a gown.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from lowest is associated with Venus and the Principalities, which appear here as a pair of youthful female angels. Venus is depicted as a sphere, surrounded by a cloud, at the center of the arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from lowest is associated with Venus and the Principalities, which appear here as a pair of youthful female angels visible from the shoulders up, one on each end of the arc. The shoulders of the one at the left side of the arc appear to face forward and right, while she turns her head to look forward and left. Her eyes are raised, and her mouth may be slightly open. Her long curly hair floats around her shoulders. Her large wings are raised and at least the right wing seems to be folded around her body. It is impossible to discern whether she is clothed or nude.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from lowest is associated with Venus and the Principalities, which appear here as a pair of youthful female angels visible from the shoulders up, one on each end of the arc. The shoulders of the one on the right appear to face forward and left, while she turns her head to look forward and slightly right, tilting it back slightly as well. Her eyes are raised and her mouth is open. She has long curly hair. Her large wings are folded behind her back. Her shoulders seem to be nude.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fourth from the bottom is associated with the Powers, here shown as a pair of middle-aged female angels, and the sun. The sun is depicted as a glowing sphere emitting beams of light at the center of this arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fourth from the bottom is associated with the Powers, here shown as a pair of middle-aged female angels, one on each end of the arc. The angel on the left is visible only from the neck up. She looks forward and left, with her head tilted back and her eyes raised. An expression of concern creases her brow. Her long curly hair floats around her head. Her large folded wings are visible to either side of her head.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fourth from the bottom is associated with the Powers, here shown as a pair of middle-aged female angels, one on each end of the arc. The angel on the right is visible only from the neck up. She looks forward and right, with her eyes raised slightly. Her long curly hair floats around her head. Her large folded wings are visible to either side of her head; the left wing may be wrapped around her left shoulder.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fifth from the bottom is associated with the Virtues, which appear here as helmeted male soldiers, and with Mars. Blake depicts Mars as a circle or sphere marked with a cross and surrounded with a cloud.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fifth from the bottom is associated with the Virtues, which appear here as a pair of male soldiers, one on each end of the arc. The soldier on the left is visible from the shoulders up. His shoulders face forward and slightly right, though he turns his head forward and tilts it back slightly. He wears a crested helmet with a chin piece, and may have a short beard. His feathered wings are folded and drawn up, and at least the right wing may be partially wrapped around his right shoulder. Lines at the base of his neck may represent the top of a breastplate, or feathers from his wings.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc fifth from the bottom is associated with the Virtues, which appear here as a pair of male solders, one on each end of the arc. The soldier on the right is visible from the neck up, facing forward with eyes raised. He wears a helmet with cheek guards. His raised and folded wings are visible to either side of his head; at least the left wing may be wrapped around his body.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc sixth from bottom is associated with the Dominions, which appear here as bearded men, and with Jupiter. Blake depicts Jupiter as a sphere surrounded by a cloud at the center of the arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc sixth from bottom is associated with the Dominions, which appear here as a pair of bearded men visible from the shoulders up, one at either end of the arc. The Dominion on the left faces forward, but may tilt his head back slightly. His mouth is open, displaying his upper teeth. He has a beard and long curly hair, and seems to wear a shirt or gown. His large folded wings are visible to either side of his head.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc sixth from bottom is associated with the Dominions, which appear here as a pair of bearded men visible from the shoulders up, one at either end of the arc. The Dominion on the right faces forward. He has a beard and long curly hair, and wears a shirt or gown. His large folded wings are visible to either side of his head.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from the top is associated with the Thrones, which appear here as a pair of bearded old men, and with Saturn. Blake depicts Saturn as a sphere surrounded by a cloud at the center of this arc.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from the top is associated with the Thrones, which appear here as a pair of bearded old men, one at either end of the arc. The older man on the left is visible mostly as a head facing forward, but bent to the right and tilted down. His eyes are lowered slightly. He has a beard and long curly hair, merging with sketched lines that may indicate his shoulders and/or a shirt or gown. His large wings are visible to either side of his head.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc third from the top is associated with the Thrones, which appear here as a pair of bearded old men, one at either end of the arc. Only the head and large wings of the old man on the right are visible. His bent head faces left and forward, so that his face is visible in three-quarters profile. His eyes may be raised, and his mouth may be open slightly. He has a long beard, and long curly hair that hangs past his head. His wings are folded and raised on either side of his head, the right wing raised higher than the left.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second from top is associated with the Cherubim, which Blake illustrates as a group of female angels at either end of the arc, and with the Fixed Stars. Blake illustrates the Fixed Stars as two angelic figures standing near each other at the center of the arc. The figures seem to face one another, with the one on the left facing right, and the one on the right facing left. They bend their heads. They wear long gowns; their wings are bent up behind their backs. It is impossible to tell if the angels are female or male.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second from top is associated with the Fixed Stars, and with the Cherubim, which Blake illustrates as a group of youthful female angels at either end of the arc. At the left side of this arc, the heads of three Cherubim are grouped in a diagonal slanting up to the left. All three angels face forward with their mouths slightly open. They have short curly hair. The rightmost angel raises her bent left arm vertically overhead. The position of her hand is difficult to discern.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The arc second from top is associated with the Fixed Stars, and with the Cherubim, which Blake illustrates as a group of youthful female angels at either end of the arc. At the right side of this arc, the heads of three Cherubim are grouped in a diagonal slanting up to the right. All three angels face forward, but the two leftmost turn their heads very slightly right. All three angels have short curly hair. They raise their eyes and open their mouths slightly. The leftmost angel raises her bent right arm vertically overhead, with the palm of her open hand facing forward and up.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The head and shoulders of God appear above the uppermost arc, just below the top edge of the design. He faces forward and may lower his head, turning it slightly to the right. His right arm is raised and bent upward at the elbow. His elbow rests on the arc below. He holds his raised right hand open with the palm facing forward, and may be bestowing a blessing with this hand. The fingers of his left hand, which is palm down, rest gently on the arc. His wings are spread wide on either side of his body, just below the upper edge of the design. His mouth may be open slightly, and his eyes are lowered to the right. He has a beard and long hair, and wears a gown.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The head and shoulders of God appear above the uppermost arc, just below the top edge of the design. Sketched circles to the left of God's right arm suggest the heads of a crowd of Seraphim, whose other features are impossible to discern.

This design depicts Dante's vision of the divine order, which extends from God at the top of the design through the ranks of angels to the earth at the bottom. The head and shoulders of God appear above the uppermost arc, just below the top edge of the design. Sketched lines and circles to the right of God's left hand suggest the heads of a crowd of Seraphim, whose other features are impossible to discern.

desc.objtitle:
Dante in the Empyrean Drinking at the River of Light Dante in the Empyrean Drinks from the River of Light,
Object 101 (Butlin 812.98)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "37" top right, "N49 next at p 16" top center, and "Hell Canto 26" bottom right. These inscriptions are not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, which is partially visible as a semi-circle at the top edge of the design. On either side of the river, beams of light issue from the sun; its radiant light suffuses the sky in the top third of the design. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky. This wall is visible to either side of the river of light. The ground below the wall extends to the lower edge of the design; it is flat and may be covered in grass or similar vegetation in places. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. At least one is descending head first, arms extended. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines. A poet sits just before the wall to the left of the river of light. He faces forward and slightly right with his left leg bent forward. A scroll rests on his left knee, draping down past his leg to the right. His right arm is down and bent forward, and his right hand lies on the scroll on his knee. He may hold a pen in this hand, using it to write on the scroll. He tilts his head back and raises his eyes to look up; his mouth may be open. He seems to be seated on a low rock or stone, which is just visible to the right of his legs and the scroll he holds. A small oak tree or branch grows behind him, in front of the wall. Below the poet, a group of figures create art of various forms. At the top of the group, two men(?) stand on either end of what may be an engraver's press. Below them, a female figure who may be an angel stands to the left of an artist's easel. A canvas rests on the easel's frame. Flames surround all of these figures in the group, licking upward from the ground. A bat-winged devil stands at the left side of the grouping, facing right with his wings raised behind his back. Below this grouping, Dante kneels just to the left of the river of light, near the bottom of the design. He faces right and bends forward, hunching his shoulders and lowering his head. He holds his right arm out from his body and bent up at the elbow. His raised right hand supports a wide, shallow bowl beneath the stream of the river. His head is bent to bring his lips to the edge of the bowl to drink its contents. His eyes are lowered. A patch of vegetation grows in the lower left corner of the design, to the left of the river of light. Two taller trees stand side by side near the top of the patch, sending thickly leaved branches upward. A human form appears amid the leaves of each tree. A flower bears two blooms and several leaves between the trees. A third tree, much smaller, grows below and slightly to the left of the two taller trees. A vine grows along the ground below and to the right of the trees; it bears sparse leaves and large, lush, rose-like buds and blossoms. A small leafy plant with a single bloom grows to the right of the rightmost tree. Grass covers much of the ground between the trees and plants in this patch. An old woman sits to the right of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. She faces forward. Her face is only faintly visible beneath the transparent veil or cloak she wears over her head, which also drapes her shoulders and hides much of her shape. Her right arm is extended forward at chest level, and she rests her right hand on the top of a large stone tablet. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. She faces forward, with her legs bent forward, but turns and tilts her head to the left slightly. Her left arm is down by her side, and the fingers of her left hand seem to be loosely clasped. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent to 135 degrees at the elbow; she holds up a hand mirror in her right hand. With mouth open and eyes raised she seems to be looking at her reflection in this mirror. Her long curly hair wafts around her head. She wears a transparent gown that reveals her figure. Her feet seem to rest on a cloud. A group of the same tiny figures that play and leap in the river of light also circle her body; they collect around her head and around her legs.

component.illusobjdesc: A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. It streams downward from the sun, which is partially visible as a semi-circle at the top of the design. On either side of the river, beams of light issue from the sun, which also emanates radiant light.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. It streams downward from the sun, visible at the top of the design. On either side of the river, beams of light issue from the sun; its radiant light suffuses the sky in the top third of the design.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. The sun from which it streams suffuses radiant light through the sky in the top third of the design, to either side of the river. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky. This wall is visible to either side of the river of light.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. The sun from which it streams suffuses radiant light through the sky in the top third of the design, to either side of the river. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky. The ground below the wall extends to the lower edge of the design; it is flat and may be covered in grass or similar vegetation in places.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. One such figure, possibly a nude female with visible breasts, is visible near the left side of the river just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. She faces forward with arms extended horizontally. Another such figure is indicated with a few pencil lines to the right.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. One such figure, possibly a nude female with visible breasts, is visible near the left side of the river just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. A second more distinct figure, outlined in pen and ink, appears just below on the left. This nude figure may be male or female; it faces forward. Its body is bent into almost a crescent shape, with both arms raised vertically and legs bent upward.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. One such figure appears near the middle of the river of light, descending upside down with its body vertical and facing right. It may be flying or swimming in the stream of the river of light. The outline of one breast suggests that this figure is female. It bends its head back to look down and extends its right arm vertically past its head. Its left arm is extended vertically upward, along its body.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. One such figure appears near the middle of the river of light, descending upside down with its body vertical and facing right. To the right, another nude figure, partly outlined in pen and ink, emerges from the river. We see her(?) from the back, at least one leg bent, and with prominent buttocks.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. One figure leaps or flies from the right side of the river of light near the bottom edge of the design. It faces to the right with its body nearly horizontal in a prone position. Its arms are raised and bent upward. Its right leg is bent and drawn up slightly, while its right leg is mostly extended with the foot pointed into tiptoe. Apparently nude, this figure may be male or female.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design, which represents the Empyrean. It streams downward from the sun, at the top edge of the design, all the way to the bottom edge of the design. Tiny figures cavort in the river's waves of light; some appear to be flying or leaping from its waves. Most are very indistinct, represented by faintly sketched lines, but a few have more distinct shapes. Two figures appear together at the left side of the river of light near the bottom of the design. The figure on the right faces left and bends or leans forward, out of the river. Its head seems to be lowered and one arm seems to be raised at 45 degrees. The second figure seems to sit facing right on the ground to the left of the river of light. Either figure may be either male or female.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of the design. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky, which fills the top third of the design to either side of the river. A poet sits just before the wall to the left of the river of light. He faces forward and slightly right with his left leg bent forward. His right leg is down and bent backward at the knee. A scroll rests on his left knee, draping down past his leg to the right. His right arm is down and bent forward, and his right hand lies on the scroll on his knee. He may hold a pen in this hand, using it to write on the scroll. The position of his left arm is not clear, if represented at all. He tilts his head back and raises his eyes to look up; his mouth may be open. His long curly hair and beard suggest that he is older. His lower body is draped in a gown or cloth, but his upper body may be entirely or partly nude.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of the design. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky, which fills the top third of the design to either side of the river. A poet sits just before the wall to the left of the river of light. He seems to be seated on a low rock or stone, which is just visible to the right of his legs and the scroll he holds.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of the design. A wall, perhaps of stone, crosses the design horizontally below the sky, which fills the top third of the design to either side of the river. A poet sits just before the wall to the left of the river of light. He seems to be seated on a low rock or stone, which is just visible to the right of his legs and the scroll he holds. A small oak tree or branch grows behind him, in front of the wall. Its leaves are visible to either side of his body; they drape onto the poet's stone seat to the right of his scroll.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. One of these figures stands in the upper left corner of the group; he faces right and leans forward with his or her hands resting on what may be an engraver's press to the right. This figure, facing right and with arms raised at 45 degrees, may be holding a rectangular object, probably a copperplate or leaf of paper, and placing it on the bed of the press. The figure, facing right, is somewhat hunched over and wears a gown. Across the press to the right, the head and perhaps shoulders of another figure are just visible above an easel. This figure, seen from behind, may help to work the press by turning its star wheel, visible to the left of his upper body. Perhaps we can identify the figure on the left with Catherine Blake and the figure on the right with William Blake, working together at their rolling press.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. At the top of the group, nearest the poet, two figures stand on either end of a table-like object that may be an engraver's rolling press. The object just left of the figure on the right may be the star wheel of a press, with projecting spokes. The scene may be fiery, as indicated by flames(?) above the press and possibly smoke left of the figure on the left. The figures may be "printing in the infernal method" ( The Marriage of Heaven and Hell , Erdman page 39) with a devil figure below and to the left.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. At the bottom of the group, a female figure who may be an angel stands to the left of an artist's easel. Wearing a long gown, she faces forward and slightly to the right. Her right arm seems to be down by her side, while her left arm is down but bent up at the elbow. She may hold an artist's palette in her left hand and a brush in her right. Wings may be visible folded and raised to either side of her head.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. At the bottom of the group, a female figure who may be an angel stands to the left of an artist's easel. A canvas rests on the easel's frame.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. Two male figures stand on either side of an engraver's press, at the top of the group. Below them, a female angel stands before a canvas propped on an easel. Flames surround each of these figures, licking upward from the ground.

A poet sits to the left of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. Below him a group of figures create art of various forms. A bat-winged devil stands at the left side of the grouping, facing right with his wings raised behind his back. Other features of this figure are difficult to discern. The association of this figure with the scene of printing at an engraver's press suggest that he is a printer's devil—that is, an apprentice printer.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. Dante kneels just to the left of the river of light, near the bottom of the design. He faces right and bends forward, hunching his shoulders and lowering his head. He holds his right arm out from his body and bent up at the elbow. His raised right hand supports a wide, shallow bowl beneath the stream of the river. His raised left arm is just visible beneath his right armpit; his left hand helps to support the bowl. His head is bent to bring his lips to the edge of the bowl to drink its contents. His eyes are lowered. He has long curly hair and wears a long gown. His feet, on tiptoe, may be just visible beneath the hem of his gown.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A patch of vegetation grows in the lower left corner of the design, to the left of the river of light. Two taller trees stand side by side near the top of the patch, sending thickly leaved branches upward. A flower bears two blooms and several leaves between the trees. A third tree, much smaller, grows below and slightly to the left of the two taller trees. A vine grows along the ground below and to the right of the trees; it bears sparse leaves and large, lush, rose-like buds and blossoms. A small leafy plant with a single bloom grows to the right of the rightmost tree. Grass covers much of the ground between the trees and plants in this patch.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A patch of vegetation grows in the lower left corner of the design, to the left of the river of light. Two taller trees stand side by side near the top of the patch, sending thickly leaved branches upward. A human form appears amid the leaves of each tree. The figure on the right, in the rightmost tree, seems to be male. He is nude, and visible from the shoulders up. He faces forward, but turns his head slightly to the left. He may lean forward slightly. His mouth may be open slightly, and his eyes may be raised. Other details of his figure are impossible to discern.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A patch of vegetation grows in the lower left corner of the design, to the left of the river of light. Two taller trees stand side by side near the top of the patch, sending thickly leaved branches upward. A human form appears amid the leaves of each tree. The figure on the left, in the leftmost tree, seems to be female. She is visible from the waist up, facing forward but turning her head slightly right. She may wear a cloak or similar covering over her head. A garment, perhaps a loose gown, drapes her torso.

An old woman sits to the right of the river of light, just below the wall that crosses the design horizontally. She faces forward. Her face is only faintly visible beneath the transparent veil or cloak she wears over her head, which also drapes her shoulders and hides much of her shape. Her mouth may be open. Her right arm is extended forward at chest level, and she rests her right hand on the top of a large stone tablet.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. She faces forward, with her legs bent forward, but turns and tilts her head to the left slightly. Her left arm is down by her side, and the fingers of her left hand seem to be loosely clasped. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent to 135 degrees at the elbow; she holds up a hand mirror in her right hand. With mouth open and eyes raised she seems to be looking at her reflection in this mirror. Her long curly hair wafts around her head. She wears a transparent gown that reveals her figure. Her feet seem to rest on a cloud.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. The same tiny figures that cavort in the river's waves of light also circle around the young woman. Four of them appear in a vertical row to the left of the woman's right leg. All four seem to be nude and may be either male or female. The highest of them flies or hovers in a contracted position, with its torso facing forward and left and its head bent sharply down to the right. It may also bend right sharply. Its right arm is raised vertically. Its left leg is bent forward and drawn up, and its right leg is bent backwards with feet pointed. Its left arm is drawn across its torso and raised at 45 degrees; this arm may rest on its left thigh. The figure second from top flies or hovers facing forward with its head turned slightly to the right and its body extended away. Its arms are not visible but its legs seem to be bent. The figure third from top seems to fly or hover facing forward. It may raise its right arm vertically. Other features are difficult or impossible to discern. The lowest figure is the faintest and least delineated, but it seems to fly or hover facing forward. Finally, to the left and just next to the river of light, are some sketchy lines that may be another figure, legs bent and possibly facing left.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. The same tiny figures that cavort in the river's waves of light also circle around the young woman. A group of at least five form a ring around her head of floating hair. These figures are sketched indistinctly and their individual details are difficult to discern. They seem to fly or hover with arms outstretched, holding hands.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. The same tiny figures that cavort in the river's waves of light also circle around the young woman. Two fly or hover, one above the other, to the right of her body. These figures seem to face forward. Their other features are sketched too loosely to determine.

A river of light pours vertically through the center of this design. A young woman sits between the river of light and the right edge of the design. The same tiny figures that cavort in the river's waves of light also circle around the young woman. Lightly sketched lines below the cloud beneath the woman's feet may be intended to represent several of these flying or hovering figures.

desc.objtitle:
The Queen of Heaven in Glory,
Object 102 (Butlin 812.99)

objnote.p: The collection stamp of the Felton Bequest, National Gallery of Victoria, appears in the lower right corner.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. Its petals support multiple figures. The leaf-like sepals of its calyx are visible near the bottom of the design, below its petals. Wash in the upper left and right corners of the design indicates the sky. A series of five celestial objects, including planets, stars, and a crescent moon, extend in a diagonal line across the sky in the upper left corner. A series of eight celestial objects, including stars, planets, a crescent moon, and perhaps a sun, form a second gentle arch through the sky in the upper right corner. The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of the highest petals. Her lower body faces right but she twists her torso forward at the waist. She holds her arms out horizontally, grasping a large hand mirror in one hand and a large scepter in the other hand. A halo circles her head. A ring of tiny cherubs forms a larger ring around her. Faintly sketched female figures recline facing away, one to either side of Mary. A head to the right of this figure may be an alternative position for this female. To the left of Mary, near the left edge of the Rose, is a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover. A chain is wrapped multiple times around the book, holding it shut. This book represents the Old or New Testament of the Bible; its counterpart appears as a large closed book, also wrapped with a chain, near the right edge of the Rose. A figure rests on the cover of each book. These figures, visible from the mid-torso up, may be angels or sphinxes. A halo of radiant light circles the heads of each, and they may also wear headdresses. Below and to the right of the tome on the left is a third, smaller book lying open with "Homer" written on one of the pages. Below and to the left of the tome on the right is a fourth book, lying open with "Aristotle" written on its pages. Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits beneath Mary. Her lower body faces forward and left but she twists her torso to face forward, raising her right arm nearly vertically. The figures of several nude female figures in various postures of repose surround Beatrice. One of these kneels on her knees below Beatrice to the right, facing left and away and leaning to the right. Another sits or kneels facing forward below and to the left of Beatrice, with bent left knee propped on a flower petal and right leg extended down to the left. A third reclines to the left of Beatrice, facing away with her legs to the left and her torso leaning against a petal to the right. A fourth reclines to the right of Beatrice, facing away and leaning against a petal to the left. Figures also appear in several of the Celestial Rose's petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Just to the right of center, in the layer second to outermost, one petal contains a seated female figure facing left and bending her head over a tablet(?) propped in her lap. Another, smaller figure, perhaps a cherub, hovers or flies above and to the left of her bent knees. One or two reclining figures are loosely sketched to the right. An angel is loosely sketched in the petal approximately second from right in the outer ring. This figure faces forward and perhaps slightly left, wearing a gown, with its wings spread one either side of its body. A male angel is visible in the petal approximately third from right in the outer ring. His body faces forward, with his weight resting on his bent left knee and his right leg extended down to the left. He twists his torso to the left and seems to raise both slightly bent arms horizontally leftward. He may rest his hands on the frame of a harp or similar instrument that stands behind his right leg, or he may play this instrument. His large wings are folded behind his back. A female angel seated to the left and perhaps playing a harp is visible in the foremost petal of the outer ring, approximately fourth from right. Her lower body faces right, but she twists forward at the waist, leaning backwards, and turns her head to look forward and left. Her left arm is extended horizontally to the right and she may rest her left hand on a tall object, perhaps part of her instrument. Another angel, perhaps a nude male, is visible in the petal approximately third from left in the outer ring. He faces forward and right, and kneels or crouches with his left leg extended out in front of him and his right leg bent backwards and drawn up. His wings are folded behind his back. His left arm may be raised at roughly 135 degrees. An angel, perhaps a nude male, is visible in the petal approximately second from left in the outer ring. This angel flies, hovers, or runs facing away and slightly left with his right leg down and his left leg extended backward. His wings are spread to either side of his body and he seems to hold his arms raised outward at 45 degrees. Lightly sketched lines in the leftmost petal of the outer ring suggest the head and torso of at least one, but perhaps two standing figures. Similarly, lightly sketched lines in the rightmost visible petal of the ring second to outermost suggest the heads and part of the upper bodies of two figures. Various rounded forms to the left may be more indications of figures.

component.illusobjdesc: The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. Its petals support multiple figures. The leaf-like sepals of its calyx are visible near the bottom of the design, below its petals.
The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. Wash in the upper left and right corners of the design indicates the sky.

The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. Wash in the upper left and right corners of the design indicates the sky. A series of five celestial objects extend in a diagonal line across the sky in the upper left corner. The object nearest the left edge of the design is a planet that seems to emit beams of light, which are visible particularly at its right side. Six small satellites, perhaps moons, circle the planet. A star appears to the right of this planet. The third object from the left is another planet, with four satellite moons. This planet's beams of light are visible to left and right. The object second from right is a crescent moon. Nearest the upper edge of the design is a planet with a single satellite moon.

The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. Wash in the upper left and right corners of the design indicates the sky. A series of eight celestial objects form a gentle arch through the sky in the upper right corner. The object nearest the upper edge is a star. To the right of the star appears a sun, or perhaps a planet emitting radiant light. The next five objects include three stars and two planets (each planet within its own circle of radiance) in alternation. The final object, nearest the right edge of the design, is a tiny crescent moon.

The Celestial Rose or Rose of Heaven, a giant upward-facing blossom, fills much of this design. The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of the highest petals. Her lower body faces right, but she twists forward at the waist, bending her torso to the right slightly. Her head is turned to the left slightly. She extends her slightly bent left arm out horizontally out to the right and grasps a large hand mirror in her upraised left hand. Her right arm is raised at 45 degrees and bent upward to 135 degrees at the elbow. She holds a large scepter topped with a fleur-de-lis in her upraised right hand. The rod of the scepter is propped against the outside of her right elbow. Her legs are together, and at least her right foot seems to be pointed into tiptoes. She is dressed in a transparent gown that drapes her body but does not hide it. Her long curly hair falls over her shoulders and a halo circles her head.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. A ring of tiny cherubs forms a large halo around her head. Those at the right side of the ring are the most defined. The cherub to the right of the hand mirror Mary holds flies or hovers facing forward and bending left, with its nude body extended diagonally down to the left. Its wings are spread to either side of its head, which seems to be turned to the left slightly. It may raise its arms at roughly 135 degrees. The cherub hovering or flying just above this cherub seems to echo the position of the first, although it is less well defined. At least three more loosely sketched cherubs complete the arch of the halo as it curls up to the left. A very faint, loose cherub may also appear beneath the well defined cherub to the right of the hand mirror. The cherubs that form the top of the arch are so loosely sketched as to be indistinguishable from one another. The cherubs at the left side of the halo fly or hover facing forward with wings spread, bending right. There may be six or seven cherubs forming this part of the arch, but they are lightly sketched and loosely defined.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits beneath her. Her lower body, with legs bent, faces forward and left. She twists her torso to face forward. Her head is turned to the right slightly and tilted back. She raises her right arm nearly vertically; her upraised right hand is open with the palm facing forward and up. Her left arm is by her side but bent up at the elbow. Her long curly hair hangs down her back and is visible to the right and left of her waist. Vertical lines below her left elbow might be part of a cloak draped over her left shoulder. She might hold something in the left hand.

Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits near the center of the Celestial Rose, beneath the Virgin Mary. The figures of several young women surround her. One of these kneels on her knees below Beatrice to the right, facing left and away. This figure leans to the right, resting against a petal of the Celestial Rose. Her right upper arm is raised at about 45 degrees and seems to be propped against the same petal. Her left arm is not visible. She tilts her head back to look up and left. She wears a thin, transparent gown and seems to have long hair swept over her left shoulder. There appears to be an alternative position for her head.

Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits near the center of the Celestial Rose, beneath the Virgin Mary. The figures of several young women surround her. One of these sits or kneels facing forward below and to the left of Beatrice. Her bent left knee is propped on a flower petal; her slightly bent right leg is extended down to the right and her right foot seems to rest on tiptoes on a lower petal. Her torso twists to the left slightly, and her right arm is not visible. Her left arm is down and drawn back slightly, and her left hand lies palm down on a petal. A few sketchy lines might indicate possible positions for her right arm. She tilts her head back and to the right and raises her eyes. Her mouth may be open. She seems to be nude, although an article of clothing may drape her left thigh, and to have long hair.

Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits near the center of the Celestial Rose, beneath the Virgin Mary. The figures of several young women surround her. One of these is visible to the left of Beatrice, reclining and facing away. She lies with her legs to the left and her torso leaning against a petal to the right. Her right upper arm is raised horizontally and rests along the petal, while her left arm may lie at her side along her hip and leg. She turns her head to the left, bending it down so that her face is visible in profile looking down and left. Sketched rather loosely, her other details are difficult to discern, but she may wear a gown and have long hair. There appears to be an alternative position for her head.

Beatrice, nude with visible breasts, sits near the center of the Celestial Rose, beneath the Virgin Mary. The figures of several young women surround her. One of these is visible to the right of Beatrice, reclining and facing away. She lies with her legs to the right and her torso leaning against a petal to the left. Her left arm seems to be raised at 135 degrees and to lie along the same petal. Her head is turned to the left and bent back. She seems to wear a gown with a belt or a visible waistband. Other features are difficult to discern.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. To the left of Mary, near the left edge of the Rose, is a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover. A chain is wrapped multiple times around the book, holding it shut. This book represents the Old or New Testament of the Bible; its counterpart appears to the right of Mary, near the right edge of the Rose. Lightly inscribed on the edges of the book's pages is the phrase "Chained round" or possibly "Corded round."

To the left of the Virgin Mary, who kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover rests on the Rose's petals. Below the book to the right, a second smaller book lies open. The name "Homer" is written on one of the pages.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. To the left of Mary, near the left edge of the Rose, is a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover. This figure, visible from the mid-torso up, may be an angel or a sphinx. It faces forward and left, and may lean forward slightly. Its arms are extended and raised at 45 degrees, and it rests its hands on the cover of the book. A halo of radiant light circles its head, which may also bear a headdress.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. To the right of Mary, near the right edge of the Rose, is a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover. A chain is wrapped multiple times around the book, holding it shut. This book represents the Old or New Testament of the Bible; its counterpart appears to the left of Mary, near the left edge of the Rose. The word "Bible" is written on the edges of its pages; the phrase "Chaind round" appears below.

To the right of the Virgin Mary, who kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover rests on the Rose's petals. Below the book to the left, a second smaller book lies open. The name "Aristotle" is written on one of the pages.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. To the right of Mary, near the right edge of the Rose, is a large closed book with a figure seated on its cover. This figure, visible from the mid-torso up, may be an angel or a sphinx. It faces forward and left, and may lean forward slightly. Its arms seem to be extended and raised at about 45 degrees, and it rests its hands on the cover of the book. A halo of radiant light circles its head, which may also bear a headdress.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. Other figures populate the petals surrounding her. The upper body of one, lightly sketched, is visible below and to the right. This figure seems to be seated, facing forward and leaning to the left with legs extended to the right and lowered head turned to the left. The suggestion of breasts hints that this figure may be female, but other details are too faint to discern.

The Virgin Mary kneels at the center of the Celestial Rose, on one of its highest petals. Other figures populate the petals surrounding her. The upper body of one lightly sketched figure is visible below and to the left, facing away and to the right. This figure seams to be seated. It may bend its head back. The head to the right may be an alternative position for the head of this seated female.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Just to the right of center, in the layer second to outermost, one petal contains a seated female figure facing left. She bends her head over a tablet propped in her lap. Her left arm is down by her side, bent up at the elbow so that her lower arm rests on the easel. She may be drawing or writing with this hand. She wears a long gown. Her long hair is just visible behind her back, which may rest against the back of a chair. Another, smaller figure, perhaps a cherub, hovers or flies above and to the left of her bent knees. This figure seems to face forward, but other details are difficult to discern. One or two reclining figures, probably facing right, are loosely sketched to the right.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. An angel is loosely sketched in the petal approximately second from right in the outer ring. This figure faces forward and perhaps slightly left, wearing a gown, with wings spread on either side of its body. Its head may be bent and turned left. Its legs extend down to the left.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. A male angel is visible in the petal approximately third from right in the outer ring. His body faces forward. His weight rests on his bent left knee, which seems to be propped on a small rock; his right leg extends down to the left. He twists his torso to the left and seems to raise both slightly bent arms horizontally leftward. He may rest his hands on the frame of a harp or similar instrument that stands behind his right leg; alternatively he may play this instrument. His head, looking left, is tilted back slightly. He may have a beard and long hair. His large wings are folded behind his back.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. A female angel seated near and perhaps playing a harp is visible in the foremost petal of the outer ring, approximately fourth from right. Her lower body faces right, but she twists forward at the waist, leaning backwards. She turns her head to look forward and left. Her left arm is extended horizontally to the right and she may rest her left hand on a tall object, perhaps part of her instrument. Her right arm is raised and bent upward to the left, and this hand may rest on a section of the instrument that crosses behind her back. Both of her legs are bent; the right may be crossed over the left at the knee. She seems to wear a long gown with a belted waist. Her wings may be just visible to the left of her head.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. An angel, perhaps a nude male, is visible in the petal approximately third from left in the outer ring. He faces forward and right, and kneels or crouches with his left leg extended in front of him and his right leg bent backwards and drawn up. His wings are folded behind his back. His left arm may be raised at roughly 135 degrees.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. An angel, perhaps a nude male, is visible in the petal approximately second from left in the outer ring. This angel flies, hovers, or runs facing away and slightly left with his right leg down and his left leg extended backward. His wings are spread to either side of his body and he seems to hold his arms raised outward at 45 degrees.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Lightly sketched lines in the leftmost petal of the outer ring suggest the head and torso of at least one, but perhaps two standing figures.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Lightly sketched lines in the rightmost visible petal of the ring second to outermost suggest the heads and part of the upper bodies of two figures.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Lightly sketched lines in the leftmost visible petal of the ring second to outermost suggest the head and upper body of a figure.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Lightly sketched lines in the second to leftmost visible petal of the ring second to outermost suggest the head and upper body of a figure.

The open bloom of the Celestial Rose fills much of this design. Figures appear in several of its petals, particularly those forming the outer two layers. Lightly sketched lines in the third to leftmost visible petal of the ring second to outermost suggest the heads and upper bodies of two figures side by side. Other rounded forms to the left may be more figures.

lg.l: Mary The word is inscribed above the head of the large kneeling figure, upper center.

Sun
The word is inscribed in the circle upper right.

Sceptre
Looking The first word is written just to the left of the scepter held in the right hand of the large kneeling figure, upper center. The second word is written just above the looking glass held in her left hand. "Looking" may be followed by another word, probably "glass," but if so the word is obscured by the design.
Laws The word is inscribed above the head of the large seated figure, above and to the left of the center of the design.

Dominion
The word is inscribed above the head of the right-most seated figure.
corded round These two words are inscribed on the side of the book held by the large seated figure, above and to the left of the center of the design. Our reading of the second word is conjectural.

Homer
Aris totle
Bible The first word is written on the open book to the left of the seated figure seen in profile, just left of the center of the design. The second word ("Aristotle") is written on the open book below and to the left of the right-most seated figure. The third word is written on the side of the book held by this same figure.

Chaind round
This line is written just below the book held by the right-most seated figure. These two words form a syntactic unit with the final word in line 7.
